PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes any United Nations inspired intervention by the Federal Government in the democratically enacted laws of the State of Tasmania noting that the Attorney-General, Mr Lavarch, admits that the recent ruling by the United Nations has no direct impact on Australian or Tasmanian law.

Your petitioners request that the Senate uphold the purposes of its formation and support the right of the State of Tasmania to determine its own social laws through its democratically elected Parliament and oppose any legislation seeking to override Tasmania's laws.

PETITION.TITLE: Aerial Spraying
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to phase out aerial spraying in accordance with recommendation 89 of the report of the Senate Select Committee on Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Women: Pension Age
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned strongly opposes attempts by the government to raise the pension age for women from 60 to 65 years.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate oppose this proposed change.

PETITION.TITLE: Homeless Rate Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows that:
1.We are concerned that teenagers are able to leave home by obtaining young homeless rate benefits without adequate investigation.
2.We believe that the flawed nature of the guidelines governing eligibility for young homeless rate benefits is in some circumstances encouraging family breakdown.

3.With the number of young people receiving youth homeless rate benefits increasing by a factor of ten over the past six years, we consider that there are insufficient programs to help keep families together.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Call on the Government to:
(a) review the guidelines for young homeless rate benefits; and
(b) show a greater commitment to programs which prevent family breakdown.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.

PETITION.TITLE: Chemical Spraying
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned, whilst fully supporting the Dorset Council's call for a moratorium on Atrazine spraying by the Tasmanian Forestry Corporation in the water catchment of Scottsdale, Branxholm and Derby, respectfully call upon the Federal Government to ensure that the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary chemicals gives priority to:

PARA.TAB: (1) Review existing chemicals Atrazine and all other S-Triazines, Glyphosate (Roundup) and Hexazinone (Velpar); and
(2) In particular their application in locations of high rainfall and high slope areas where these chemicals have been, or will be, applied.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Breeders Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

PETITION.PARA: that we are strongly opposed to the Government's proposed Plant Breeders Rights Bill 1994 in its entirety.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament, should oppose the Plant Breeders Rights Bill (1994) in its entirety.

PETITION.TITLE: UHF Transmission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.The UHF line-of-sight transmission is not suited to Tasmania's mountainous terrain.
2.It is unjust that compulsory UHF has resulted in poorer reception for many Tasmanians and that those living in weak "pockets" have outlaid of up to $450 in order to receive the signal.
3.It is unjust that many low-income Tasmanians and pensioners do not have the means to outlay hundreds of dollars so they can view their own television sets.
4.Compulsory UHF has resulted in some Tasmanians being denied a signal.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled:
Call on the Government to:

PETITION.PARA: (a)honour its commitment to ensure that first class television reception is delivered to all the residents of Tasmania by providing additional funding for the urgent implementation of the necessary number of transmitters.
(b)provide all Tasmanians with access to their own national broadcasters, the ABC and the SBS.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: (1)That the standing reference of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on the central administration of the Australian Government be discharged.
(2)That the following matters, referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on 22 March 1994, be transferred on 10 October 1994 to the Economics References Committee:

TAB.TAB: (a)Taxation of financial arrangements—consultative document issued by the Treasurer; and
(b)Taxation, regulation and international competitiveness; and

SPEECH.PARA: that, in considering these matters, the Economics References Committee may consider the evidence and records of the former Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration relating to these matters.

PARA.TAB: (3)That, from 10 October 1994, the current standing references on statutory authorities, non-statutory bodies and companies and associations, be the responsibility of the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I seek leave to make a short statement relating to the notice of motion.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion seeks to assist the smooth transition to the new committee structure. The Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration has had a standing reference for some years on the central administration of the Australian government. The committee resolved before its imminent dissolution that, as the performance of relevant departments and agencies is to be an inherent responsibility of the new Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee, it was unnecessary to explicitly provide for such a general continuing reference to either of the incoming finance and public administration committees.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the two taxation matters, the relevant portfolios are now to be within the responsibility of the economics committees from 10 October. It is, therefore, appropriate for the transfer to be made, especially in view of the fact that no hearings have yet been held, only written submissions having been received so far.

On the third matter, the question of the statutory authorities, non-statutory bodies and companies and associations, that proposal will allow the legislation committee to continue to maintain the list of Commonwealth bodies which the existing finance and public administration committee has maintained for some years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes the worthwhile construction of the wetland project at New Norfolk, Tasmania, to be officially opened on 3 October 1994;
(b)acknowledges the pro-active role of the mayor and council of the municipality of New Norfolk in their acceptance of the challenge to undertake this project;
(c)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the aims of the project were to treat wastewater and create a wetland, a wetland that is already attracting water birds and platypuses, and
(ii)notes community support for the project and the lack of vandalism associated with the project;

PARA.TAB: (d)recognises the achievement of objectives in creating an artificial wetland including:

TAB.TAB: (i)reduced discharges of suspended solids, nutrients levels and biological oxygen demand into the Derwent River,
(ii)establishment of a southern Tasmanian wetland tourism attraction,
(iii)an improved environmental link between Tynwald Park and the Esplanade,
(iv)an increased experimental database on growing wetland plant species, and
(v)reduced maintenance costs of utilised land in the control of the council; and

PARA.TAB: (e)congratulates the people of New Norfolk on this excellent combination of environmentally friendly treatment of wastewater and extended recreation areas.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the time for the presentation of the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Australia's relations with the People's Republic of China be extended to 29 June 1995.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the time for the presentation of the report of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs on the adequacy of the Rural Adjustment Scheme, the extent of rural debt and mechanisms for the management of rural reconstruction be extended to the first sitting day in December 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to make a short statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The notice of motion I have just given seeks an extension of time for the presentation of the report of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs on its inquiry into the rural adjustment scheme, rural debt and rural reconstruction. Senators should note that this very important matter was referred to the committee only six months ago and, in this time, the committee has given the inquiry top priority, convening 17 days of public hearings in all states and territories.

PARA.TAB: As usual, the committee took the time to gather evidence not only from major organisations and groups centred in capital cities but also from farmers and graziers in rural and regional Australia: Murchison in Western Australia; West Wyalong and Gilgandra in New South Wales; and Dalby, Roma, Charleville and Longreach in Queensland.

During the course of the inquiry, 287 submissions have been received and over 250 witnesses have given evidence, generating over 3,000 pages of Hansard. The final hearing was held last week—on 12 September. I believe these statistics are a real indication of the committee's commitment to this very important inquiry. However, the committee considers that, in order to effectively reflect the views raised in evidence, it will need more time to draft and finalise its report.

The extension of time that the committee seeks will also allow it to monitor the implementation of the government's initiatives to be announced today on drought and the rural adjustment scheme. I can assure the Senate that the committee will endeavour to table its report at the earliest opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the National Transmission Agency has failed to provide adequate television reception to many Tasmanians because UHF line-of-sight transmission is not suited to Tasmania's rugged terrain,
(ii)the Government acknowledges that even after existing equipment is upgraded in 1995 and new transmitters are installed during the next 2 years, areas of poor reception will remain,
(iii)in 1989, the Labor Government assured Parliament that all existing services would remain on VHF and that first-class television reception would be delivered to all residents of Tasmania, and
(iv)existing national and commercial services in the flat Riverland area of South Australia are to stay on VHF, but hilly Tasmania has been forced to relocate to the unsuitable UHF band;

PARA.TAB: (b)condemns the Government for ignoring the true extent of the problem and not honouring its previous commitments; and

(c)calls on the Government to urgently investigate all areas of poor reception and provide additional transmitters so that all Tasmanians receive first-class television reception as previously promised.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)a Victorian Government audit of the forest industry code of practice found that in 30 per cent of instances studied the code was breached by the timber industry, and
(ii)the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) is considering the formation of a federal monitoring capability to oversee woodchipping operations; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Government, as a matter of urgency, to establish a monitoring arm within the environment portfolio before the next round of woodchip licence renewals.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that Triple J Radio is the only national radio station for young people in Australia, with around one million listeners;
(b)congratulates Triple J Radio on its expansion into regional Australia from 1995;
(c)notes that Triple J Radio provides exposure and promotion for Australian artists;
(d)expresses concern that Triple J Radio's current affairs and news programs are not monitored by the Media Information, Current Awareness and Hansard group (MICAH) in Parliament House; and
(e)calls on the presiding officers to investigate the means by which MICAH could monitor Triple J Radio for the benefit of those members of Parliament who need to be properly informed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)notes that as a result of the tax simplification project team's proposals, Australia will have its current Income Tax Assessment Act together with a new Act running in tandem with the result that taxpayers and practitioners will have to examine both the old and a new parallel Act in order to work out their obligations; and

(b)alerts the Government to the dangers involved in not taking the utmost care in simplifying the income tax legislation as exemplified by the streamlined sales tax legislation which, whilst consolidating the sales tax laws, created many anomalous situations which have become increasingly apparent as time passes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)applauds the results of the community survey of the people of Mandurah where 64 per cent voted against the proposed canal development on the Creery wetlands;

(b)welcomes the quick and positive move by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) to discuss with the Western Australian Government the need to protect this valuable Ramsar site; and

(c)calls on the Western Australian Minister for the Environment (Mr Minson) to respond equally positively and work with both the Federal Government and the local council to ensure once and for all that this valuable breeding ground for migratory birds will be preserved.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Communications Towers in Australian Capital Territory

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that communication towers have been erected on designated land in the Australian Capital Territory contrary to Commonwealth legislation; and

(b)asks what steps the Government will take to have towers already erected in breach of the National Capital Plan removed, in particular that erected on Oakey Hill in contravention of the `clear hills' policy of the National Capital Plan.

(c)calls on the Government to further strengthen provisions in the Telecommunications National Code to allow for adequate community consultation on the construction of further towers, including widespread notification by carriers of their intention, and sufficient time to negotiate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate notes that—
(a)the Government must accept responsibility for the Australian National Line (ANL) debacle;
(b)the amount of NSW agricultural cargo tied up as a result of the dispute included $28 million of wool, $35 million of meat, $16 million of wheat, $10 million of cotton and $1 million of sugar;
(c)in NSW, it will take another 3 weeks to clear the backlog of cargo, imposing further costs on the State's businesses through lost sales and delays in filling orders;
(d)this politically motivated dispute came at a time when more than 80 per cent of NSW is drought-declared;
(e)through its sweetheart deal with the unions, the Government has set a dangerous precedent that will cost taxpayers dearly;
(f)primary producers would be delighted with a similar tax deal to help them through the worst drought in 70 years; and
(g)by giving such gratuitous favouritism to a sectional group, the Government has demonstrated that it is not serious about continuing waterfront reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)Commonwealth public servants deemed as `stressed' and on leave under the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988:
(A)cost $24 308 421 in the 1992-93 and 1993-94 financial years,
(B)increased from 1 271 to 1 615, an increase of 344 or 27 per cent, in this period, and
(C)averaged 19 weeks leave in the 1993-94 financial year, an increase of 4 weeks from the previous year, and

PARA.TAB: (b)recognises that self-employed business people such as farmers do not enjoy similar access to stress leave pay-outs, and yet often endure amounts of stress not imaginable within the walls of a bureaucrat's office; and
(c)calls on the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters (Mr Johns) to redefine:

TAB.TAB: (i)the eligibility for such payments under the Act in light of the associated cost burden upon Australian taxpayers, and
(ii)Comcare Australia's policy as outlined in the supervisor's handbook for stressed employees, that:
(A)long cigarette breaks are a sign of stress,
(B)long coffee breaks are a sign of stress,
(C)too little work causes stress, and
(D)a supervisor must offer crying employees a tissue and a glass of water.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: (1)That the Senate notes that:

TAB.TAB: (a)there are now available, in the public domain or otherwise, at least five official valuations of the Australian National Line (ANL);
(b)these include:
(i)the Price Waterhouse/Salomon Brothers due diligence report, which was commissioned by the Asset Sales B Task Force and which valued ANL at between minus $75 million and minus $118 million,

(ii)the audited accounts of ANL itself, signed off by the Auditor-General and by Ernst and Young, as contracted auditors to the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO), which valued ANL at between break even and $33 million,

(iii)the joint ANL management/Arthur Andersen report on ANL, delivered 3 days before the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) said that ANL `could not be given away', which valued ANL at between $56 million and $90 million,
(iv)the 1992 report by Macquarie Corporate Finance, which concluded that ANL had substantial net worth, and which the Minister refused to permit ANL management to have updated, and
(v)unreleased 6-monthly audits undertaken by Arthur Andersen, as contracted auditors to the ANAO, of which the latest would have been for the period ending February 1994;
(c)these valuations are a source of confusion to the Parliament, policy advisers and the public as to the real commercial value of ANL, both as a going concern or in liquidation; and
(d)without a single, authoritative valuation, the Senate is unable to accurately assess the implications of the policy decisions made with respect to ANL in recent times.

PARA.TAB: (2)That, to enable a definitive clarification of ANL's financial position to be made available to the Parliament and the public, the Senate resolves that, as soon as practicable, a report by the Auditor-General be laid on the table which, taking into account as far as is necessary the valuations described in paragraph (1)(b) and any other information which the Auditor-General requires and is authorised or empowered to obtain, answers the following questions:

TAB.TAB: (a)what is the best commercially acceptable valuation of ANL:
(i)as a going concern, and
(ii)in the event that it were liquidated; and
(b)is it possible to reconcile the valuations available to date, including those set out in paragraph (1)(b), and if so, what is the most acceptable reconciliation.

(ii)according to comments by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner, Mr Dodson, payment of compensation to Mr Condren would be in line with Australia's obligations under Article 14(6) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 1029, standing in my name and relating to comments by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to the media about drought relief, be taken as formal.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion standing in my name, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Margetts moving a motion relating to the conduct of business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 1029 standing in the name of Senator Margetts for this day, relating to drought and climatic change.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion that I propose we debate today is important because we have had a great deal of discussion in this chamber about the drought and its implications socially and on primary industry. We have also had a number of debates in this chamber about the implications of climatic change and the need for the acceptance of that change. This will be the second occasion on which we have debated this issue, but I feel that the need to raise these issues and bring about a combined debate is obvious.

PARA.TAB: The Greens have always accepted the concept that a reasonable debate is acceptable, and we generally support motions for a reasonable debate on such issues. I ask for support in the Senate for the debate to take place. I do not believe that it will be a lengthy debate, but it is an important issue and it is important that the Senate have the chance to discuss it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the government will support Senator Margetts's motion to suspend standing orders. I will go into the reasons for this when we get to the substance of the debate.

—In view of the government's support of the motion to suspend standing orders, I indicate that the Democrats will also support it. I will take pleasure in debating this matter when the suspension of standing orders is formally passed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as Senator Margetts's motion for the suspension of standing orders is concerned, I believe that it is rather premature to call on the Senate to debate this issue at this stage while we are waiting for the government's statement on the rural adjustment scheme today. I think it would have been better to have a full debate about the drought and the government's statement at a later stage. I am not speaking against Senator Margetts's motion, but I think it might have been better if we had had a decent debate on this issue at a later date.

PARA.TAB: I think it would be better to wait and see what the government has to offer in its package on the rural adjustment scheme. The government is now starting to realise the inadequacies of the rural adjustment scheme. It is also starting to understand that there is a calamity going on out there as far as the drought is concerned. On the evidence that we have had from the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs—Senator Burns earlier today asked that the committee have more time to report to the Senate; he wants the committee to report to the Senate in early December—I think it would have been better to wait until we have seen the government's statement today. Had we seen the government's statement, we could have debated Senator Margetts's motion and all the other things that the government is raising today.

At the moment, people affected by the drought have no meat on their bones and they have no fat on their meat because of a lot of the government's policies in the past 10 years. All those things should be debated if we are going to debate this issue. The opposition does not oppose the suspension of standing orders, but we make the point that it would have been much better to debate this issue at a later stage today after we had seen what the government is doing about the drought. All these other issues that Senator Margetts wants to bring up could have been discussed then.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join in this debate, too. As Senator Margetts would be well aware, the drought has been going on for four years. I certainly do not object to her motion to suspend standing orders and debate the drought. I think it is an issue that needs as much debate in this parliament as possible. However, I say to Senator Margetts that perhaps it would have been better if she had moved this motion after Senator Collins had brought down his package today. I believe the Senate and the House of Representatives should closely examine Senator Collins's package and debate the points that are raised.

PARA.TAB: I have many concerns that I want to address. Before I address what is needed to offset the drought and the effects of it, I believe it is essential that we wait for the package to be introduced, go through it in great detail, have an informed debate on what is right and what is wrong with it and then we can take it from there. I feel that it is futile to raise the issue of drought at this stage.

We are now past that debate. The debate has moved on from there. The government has recognised the problem and now it is bringing forward what it sees as the answers. It is our role as members and senators of the parliament to investigate that, go through the package and then raise the issues that concern us, after Senator Collins has reported to the parliament or made a statement by press release. Senator Margetts's concern is welcome, but I had hoped that this matter could have been raised at a later hour today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also share concern about the procedural basis on which this motion is now being presented. I think all of us in this chamber are genuinely concerned about the issues relating to drought and the effects that are being felt throughout Australia, and we look forward to receiving and being able to study the government's announcements later today. Many of the issues that are canvassed in the context of drought relief in this particular motion presented by Senator Margetts ought to be considered in the context of such a major policy announcement that is due and should be properly part of that debate and discussion.

PARA.TAB: The way in which Senator Margetts chose to raise this matter is, to a certain extent, opportunistic in just seeking to put on the agenda the broader issues that relate to the changing climatic conditions. If we look at the motion in detail, we see the problems of an agricultural sector facing massive climatic disruption and, in the last part of the motion, the concentration on the protocol to ensure the reduction of pollutants that may worsen the climatic instability. This whole issue is compounded by Senator Margetts's motion.

I find it a strange irony that the Australian Democrats and the government would now want to join forces to pass this motion before we have been able to look at and properly canvass the solutions relating to drought relief, which is the thrust of part (a) of Senator Margetts's motion. There is a strange irony because of the pressures that are obviously now being exerted on the Labor Party through the Left and the debates and the issues that will arise at its conference next week. Also press releases, such as one that was issued yesterday by the Wilderness Society and the Environment Centre of the Northern Territory, canvass similar issues. That press release states:

SPEECH.PARA: While serious for farmers, the so-called drought in the Northern Territory is, in fact, a normal climatic fluctuation. This region of the Northern Territory is one of the driest areas and up to three years without rain is not uncommon.
It also states:

The availability of subsidies just encourages bad management . . . We should not further subsidise unviable businesses. We must keep people on the land to manage it, but only in the context of a major restructure of the pastoral industry.

I am afraid that if those sorts of issues are now canvassed by Senator Margetts's motion, then the government has a lot to answer for. Senator Collins, not only as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy but also as a Senator for the Northern Territory, will face a serious debate. I find that this particular debate is premature and ought to be considered after the government's announcement and incorporated more properly into that debate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Margetts) agreed to:

That general business notice of motion No. 1029, standing in the name of Senator Margetts for this day, relating to drought ad climatic change, may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business this day till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)notes the comments of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on Radio 4RK, Rockhampton, on 19 July 1994 and on SBS News Extra on 20 July 1994, in the context of drought relief, that drought is not an intermittent disaster but is probably a manifestation of climate change effects and is becoming a permanent feature of the Australian landscape;
(b)recognises the importance of agricultural exports to our economy, and the impact of climatic disruption on the security of that sector;
(c)supports the call for the development of a policy to effectively assist farmers to adjust to changing climatic conditions; and
(d)calls for:

TAB.TAB: (i)a major commitment of funding to address the longer term structural problems of an agriculture sector facing massive climatic disruption,

(ii)provision of assistance to farmers at least equivalent to drought relief to ameliorate the personal impact of climatic change on these farmers, as well as assistance in adjusting to new climatic conditions, and

(iii)a strong policy designed to limit the source of the pollutants that lead to climatic change domestically and support for a strong international protocol to ensure the reduction of pollutants that may worsen the climatic instability.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to mention at this stage that notice of this motion was given not yesterday or this week but at the end of the last session. Those people who in the last few minutes have stood up and suggested that this motion is opportunistic, trying to jump the gun on the government's statement today, should be reminded that this motion was on the Notice Paper before the government notified us that it would be making a statement today about drought relief.

PARA.TAB: It is, therefore, important today not only to discuss the reason for this motion but also to discuss the links between it and the possible ways of dealing with this issue. If I had waited until after the government's statement on drought relief, the debate would be based on a to and fro discussion about particular government policies on drought relief and would be shying away from whether simply looking at drought relief is a broad enough way to deal with the implications for this country, particularly for the rural sector, of possible climatic change. That is why it is important to deal with this issue in this way and not simply be part of a reactive agenda or political mudslinging from one side to the other in relation to government policy or government reactions to a particular situation.

Drought has always been a problem in Australia. We have always been a dry country. But we have always depended on our land based industries—agriculture, horticulture and pastoral industries—to generate much of the wealth that this country lives on. Major drought has always been a problem affecting not only the farmers but the nation as a whole.

In the past, drought could be seen as a risk for the industry—natural variation at its low point—a time when farmers and the rest of us would try to survive until nature turned a more benign face. Recently the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) stated his acceptance that drought is liable to be the effect of long-term anthropogenic changes in climate and his concern over this issue. We note his words at this time:

SPEECH.PARA: The issue is not to doubt that drought is there. Of course it's there and it's there probably because of climate change effects. What the Commonwealth Government has said is look, rather than simply this be part of the natural disaster relief arrangements, disaster means it is intermittent and unlikely and therefore when it comes it has to have arrangements which reflect those kinds of circumstances. Whereas what we know is with these climate change effects is it is much less intermittent than it was, it's becoming a permanent feature of the Australian landscape in one place or another each year. . .
He also said on SBS News Extra on 20 July 1994:
The Government's view is it—
drought—

should be treated under the Rural Adjustment Scheme programs rather than, say, natural disasters relief because it is not an intermittent disaster. This is coming quite regularly with climate change effects.

Indeed, this is in line with the government's recent argument that drought would not be considered a disaster but the norm, and that farmers would have to adjust to the new conditions rather than be helped through a time of trouble because, until they adjust, their troubles will not end. That is the government's position.

PARA.TAB: Let us consider for a moment what this means. A major drought event is liable to reduce our GDP, the measure of economic growth, by one to two per cent a year. It can result in the loss of hundreds of thousands of jobs. This is the general impact on the economy from the agricultural sector alone. Direct losses of this particular drought are estimated as being in excess of $1 billion in lost sales. The general impact will be greater and estimates of the damage range from $2 billion to $3.5 billion with a reduction in GDP of over one per cent. As several commentators have noted, this is with the cushion of rising prices to partially offset the devastation of drought. Already this year we have heard that some pasta manufacturers will be importing grain into Australia for their product.

The motion before us today arose from the comments of the Prime Minister quoted earlier. He stated that drought was not an intermittent disaster but is probably a manifestation of climate change effects, and is becoming a permanent feature of the Australian landscape. I could not agree more. The Intergovernment Panel on Climate Change, which incidentally released a report in Geneva last week confirming yet again that global climate change is inevitable, has pointed in the past to the devastating effect of climate change on the agricultural sector. Evidence of this impact from the IPCC is contained in the excellent report produced by Greenpeace entitled Climate time bomb. It states, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The warning signs are already here: 1990—world grain reserves drop to just 60 days after poor harvests, in the drought-affected US in 1988 and in India in 1987. California 1990 the five-year drought, the longest this century. By 1992 agricultural production is crippled and insect plagues proliferate. Voters rate water second only to crime as their main concern. Peru, 1990—the worst drought this century leads to food and water shortages. UK 1991—while total UK rainfall remains normal, the most severe drought since the turn of the century is withering southern Europe.

It goes on and on about various sectors of the world and the specific impacts that have occurred that may be the worst this century or the worst on record. I have mentioned this before, but I do not think from what we are hearing that this is beginning to sink in. Officials say that the consequences of the drought will be `severe and permanent'.

PARA.TAB: While many of these droughts can be linked to the El Nino effect, it is now believed that these events will become more frequent and more intense under the impact of global warming. It is also apparent from the Greenpeace report that the effects of global warming will not be confined to temperature increase and drought. There are also concerning trends that indicate that floods and violent storms and other extreme weather patterns will become more prevalent. The evidence is clearly there for everybody but most are too blinkered to see.

This motion for consideration today is therefore designed to acknowledge that climate change reality and to link it to the plight being faced by our farming communities. As many in this place have indicated in recent times, our farming community is suffering greatly. My concern is that the fundamental but admittedly long-term solution to many of those problems is not being confronted by either of the major parties in this parliament, and that the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions is the ultimate cause of the farmers' plight.

I would like us to consider again the Prime Minister's words and their implications. If this is the effect of a drought, what will be the effect of such droughts becoming commonplace? It is not a crisis; it is a catastrophe of major proportions. When such a drought occurs, its impact goes beyond the years in which it occurs. Pastoralists reduce stock and it may take several years to bring herd numbers back up. Pushes to expand export markets are hurt and it may take years to re-establish them if inability to supply means that buyers find new sources. Capital in farms is run down and may take years to recover, impairing the farmers' ability to adapt, to buy, to maintain equipment or fences and so on. Again it may take years to recover from an industry standpoint.

On an individual basis, some farmers never recover. They lose their farms and move away. Their experience, their investment, their capital, is simply lost. For thousands it is a personal tragedy. In this particular drought it is worse than usual because the drought comes on the back of an economy in recession, on the back of a recent history of low and declining primary commodity prices.

Many farmers went into this drought scraping the bottom of the barrel, the bottom of their reserves, hoping that this year would prove good. Economically it has. Prices are good this year, but good prices mean nothing if one has nothing to sell. So the rising prices create a bitter irony about the situation of this drought.

Take this situation and extend it—multiply it. Drought may not become a permanent fixture, but the implications of climate change say that it will come far more frequently and may start hitting harder. The good years may be drier and the bad ones even worse. Farmers will find themselves in this position far more frequently.

Farmers live on a basis where economies are averaged over a decade, with good years making up for bad, living often close to the margins over that period. How will that farmer plan or build up to cope with a much higher number of bad years? Where will farmers find the reserves? One likely impact we should consider is that banks, already not very sympathetic to the realities of annual cropping and profits averaged over a decade, will look at the inevitable rise in failure rates and say that farm loans are risky and should attract even higher interest rates. The farmers' problems get worse and worse.

Things will get worse. News from the climate change scientists is that greenhouse gases are definitely increasing, and average global temperature is expected to rise by four degrees over some time. This is an average figure. The actual rises will vary a bit with location, but by rule of thumb we know that the rise will be least around the equator and greater as we go towards the poles. The temperature rise at the poles from an average rise of four degrees may be as much as 15 degrees, while the rise at the equator may be only 1.5 to two degrees.

Agricultural sections of Australia may experience rises of six or seven degrees. Four degrees, even seven degrees, may not seem like a lot of difference. Let me assure honourable senators it is huge. It is easy enough to change current patterns, wind directions and rainfall and affect the distribution of plants. It is estimated that a change of as little as 1 1/2 degrees average temperature at 30 degrees latitude may be enough to essentially reverse the ENSO, that is, the El Nino southern oscillation, which is the weather pattern that is frequently behind drought in Australia. This pattern has two main forms: the normal one and the one called El Nino, which occurs about one year out of seven or eight when conditions are right. Scientists believe that just a bit of global warming would mean that conditions will be right for El Nino most of the time and the other phase will become the rare one. This would mean that the drought conditions we are currently experiencing may become normal.

The kinds of temperature changes that scientists are talking about would mean changes in all kinds of climatic things. The gulf stream may disappear. Prevailing wind patterns may change. All of this will have an effect on rainfall. All of this will have an effect on setting of fruit and other plants, growing periods, distribution of weeds and so on.

With climate change we are talking about adjustment of a similar sort on the scale of the entire agropastoral industry. If regions will no longer be able to grow the crops they have traditionally grown, what can they grow? Can they grow anything commercially? If not, what happens to the farmers in those areas? If large numbers of farmers try to change their crops and agricultural practices in relation to climate change, what will happen to the markets for goods that they are trying to produce? What security is there in prices for these new crops?

For how long will the new climatic conditions prevail, since climate continues to change? Can farmers adjust to continual climatic change, a continually changing environment? How can farmers plan? What possible security in price or crop output can they have? Without such security, how can an agricultural industry exist? Do we really expect farmers to deal with this all on their own?

When we start talking about climatic change effects, we are talking about drought becoming normal in some regions, but also we are talking about a situation where climate changes continually in an ongoing manner. We are talking about asking farmers to adjust to a continually changing situation, about the loss of all security, about the weather or the long-term viability of anything they do. We are talking about something that may see the end of the position of agriculture as a central industry in Australia.

We are talking about billions and billions of dollars a year and a major change in trade flows. We are talking about the death of rural Australia, because without an agri-pastoral industry almost no-one will live out there. We are also talking about the death of an industry based on value added food products, unless we seriously believe we will import food for processing and re-export.

Let me say here that I do not believe this is going to happen tomorrow. We are talking 20, 30, 50 years of erosion of the industry, of good years doing less and less to cover the bad ones. While this seems long in political terms, it is blindingly fast in terms of climatic change, and express train speed in terms of the work and commitment involved in establishing an area as an agricultural region producing a certain crop. That kind of work is not simply putting different seeds in the seeder and, presto, business as usual.

In the first place, farmers are liable to need a different seeder. They may need other new or different equipment. They will need different practices in planting and harvesting. They may need different practices and equipment for handling and storage. They will have to get involved in a whole new market, find buyers, develop relationships, build a reputation and so on. This is just the farmers' work up to the farm gate, so to speak.

For a region to get ahead, it requires more than just one farmer. The infrastructure must be developed; transport established appropriate to the crop and market, food industries or downstream processes established in the region; and support and service industries established for the new crops. Seed and plant stocks will be needed, as will correct types of fencing, equipment or whatever, and they will have to be available regionally. Rural communities are living, dynamic things.

All of this will need to be considered in agricultural adjustment. For such rural adjustment to be done well will be expensive. If the conditions keep changing, the cost will escalate while any security as to return diminishes. Not to undertake such adjustment is likely to be far more expensive in human terms, in economic terms and in environmental terms. Environmental costs of not adjusting will include mainly degradation of land through attempting to make a go of a deteriorating situation, through over-farming and through inappropriate farming.

Despite the comments made by the Prime Minister that are referenced in this motion, this government has consistently failed to acknowledge the realities of climate change and to provide policies that respond to the very urgent need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Instead, we have the government regurgitating the arguments of the business lobby in this country that, because we are so heavily dependent on fossil fuels, we should be excused from the need to contribute to the international effort to reduce greenhouse emissions. What an astounding proposition! As I stated in a recent media statement, that is analogous to an alcoholic claiming that his dependence excuses him from the need to reduce his intake of alcoholic beverages.

The opposition is not immune from such claims. The opposition consistently suggests that any efforts to reduce greenhouse emissions will cost the business community too much and that this will reduce international competitiveness. This is again a blind acceptance of the facile arguments of the business community. Mr Tony Beck of the Business Council of Australia is one of the key proponents of this propaganda. In a recent edition of the APEA journal, he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: For a country like Australia with growing energy demand and a dependence on fossil fuels, the potential costs of meeting stringent greenhouse emission constraints are high, both in terms of domestic economic costs and lost export markets. We need to be vigilant with respect to policy developments in other countries and need to ensure that domestic greenhouse policies are appropriate to our circumstances.

I can only say to Mr Beck, and to the majority of senators in this place who appear to support his proposition, that the cost of not meeting our greenhouse targets will be very high from both an environmental and an economic perspective. Environmentally, we will suffer enormous climatic changes and an increasing prevalence of natural disasters such as floods and cyclones. In addition, this climate change will have an inevitable effect on vegetation and may lead to the loss of biodiversity.

PARA.TAB: Economically, we will increasingly find ourselves unable to compete on the international market as our energy costs and our energy inefficiency in manufactured goods remain high. Why will we have comparatively high energy costs? Because internationally many nations are discovering that energy conservation and efficiency is the cheapest form of energy production. This fact has obviously been lost on our political and business leaders because they talk about no-regrets options such as these, but they are not being pursued.

In addition, despite relatively high establishment costs, many nations are now acknowledging that renewable energy options are also substantially lower in the long term. Pursuing the renewable energy options also provides many export and domestic opportunities for business. Yet again, Australia has not been sufficiently perceptive to see the opportunities that are available.

As indicated earlier, this failure to acknowledge the realities of climate change has been felt most evidently in the farming sector. I wonder if the Business Council is prepared to see the farming sector as a sacrificial lamb on the altar of corporate profits, for that is the inevitable consequence of the failure to take action on greenhouse emissions. Any compromise will only be a bandaid solution for both the environment and for the farming sector.

We understand that the government is supporting this motion, and has been working up a program for addressing the problems of farmers. We hope that it is not simply drought relief on the old model, since we agree with government that farmers will need to adjust to new conditions, and there is little point trying to help them hang on in doing something that no longer works, particularly if it only degrades their land further.

What we would like to see is a comprehensive package for rural adjustment, with particular attention to the need to adjust to the likely impacts of climate change. We think that the government needs to make a substantial commitment in this adjustment process—and we mean really substantial—not just some training schemes and a few information bulletins at the local ag department.

The fact that the Greens do not think that drought relief works any more does not mean we oppose emergency relief. Quite the opposite. This rural adjustment should have been already under way. Climate change is not news. The warnings went out from CSIRO, international scientific and intergovernmental fora and NGOs. It has been a major issue for decades. If the government has not heeded information on the implications of climate change, that is not the farmers' fault. It is hard for farmers to decide suddenly to move or to change their practice and put that decision into action, especially when they are trying desperately simply to cover the maintenance on their loans.

Farmers are now in the situation where they are in a desperate plight. Even if we want to change agriculture, we need the farmers who have the background and commitment to the industry. We cannot just leave them. They are in a desperate plight and need help now, and the Greens support giving such emergency assistance to at least the extent of the old drought relief programs. We just think it needs to be made clear that it is not drought relief with the implication that it is a remedy for a short-term problem, but should be called something like `climate change emergency relief', so that people know what the score is. Such relief payments should also be used as a basis for determining who may be most at risk from climate change and be used in establishing the target group for rural adjustment work to come.

As a matter of urgency, there needs to be established under the rural adjustment program, or as a separate program, long-term measures to address the problems of rural adjustment to climate change. Strategies need to be developed to cope with the probable range of situations and difficulties facing rural communities. These should be developed with active participation of farmers, pastoralists, rural communities and regional institutions; and that participation should extend to inclusion in formulation of strategies.

While it is important to support CSIRO and other organisations in providing better projections, it is important to realise that defensive adjustment strategies can be developed without exact details. For example, moving from monocultural production to more diverse production will provide a basic defence not only against climate change but against other problems such as economic overdependence on a single crop whose prices may fluctuate.

Development of a more diverse and flexible storage and marketing system would also have other positive benefits. To accomplish these objectives and other objectives under the regional development section of the Working Nation white paper will require a substantial increase in funding to the rural adjustment program or some similar program; and a long-term commitment to such funding.

I thank Senator Coulter and the Australian Democrats for their support on this issue. I am pleased that the government has agreed to support this motion. I remind the government, however, that the environment movement is waiting to see a substantial commitment on this issue in terms of positive policy initiatives. It is disappointing that the opposition has abandoned the farming sector and is not supporting this motion. I trust that it will soon be prepared to acknowledge the realities of climate change and work together with all members of this parliament to find some long-term hope for the farming community and the rest of the population on this planet.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been indicated, the government will be supporting this motion. This morning I do not intend to go into an extensive debate on this motion from the government's perspective, not because it is not an important motion but because an essential component of the motion will be dealt with by the drought package to be considered by the cabinet in the next half hour.

PARA.TAB: To that extent, I agree with the criticism of the opposition about advancing a motion this morning before we have seen that drought package. Undoubtedly, we will have some opportunity to debate the package—whether later today, tomorrow or some other sitting day in the next couple of weeks—and express our views on it. Despite Senator Margetts's best intentions, I doubt that her contribution this morning, given the very narrow time frame between her contribution and the cabinet consideration of the drought package, will influence what is in that package.

Obviously, there are some other elements related to drought. This morning I intend to make some comment on the issue of climatic change, which was specifically referred to in the motion. But I stress that there will undoubtedly be a major debate on the government's drought package that will touch on all the issues that Senator Margetts has discussed this morning—and almost certainly other matters. Minister Collins, other members of the Senate and I will make extensive contributions on these issues at a later date.

The underlying principle of a national drought policy, agreed by the Commonwealth and all the states in July 1992, is that climate variability is a feature of the Australian farming environment. It is a normal feature. But that is not to say that the current drought, particularly in Queensland and New South Wales, is normal. It is anything but that; it is quite extraordinary and, certainly by any measure, is as bad as anything we have seen this century.

Under so-called normal drought conditions, good farm managers should be in a position to draw on accumulated risk management reserves. The exceptional circumstance provisions are intended to assist in those circumstances for which a good manager could not be expected to be prepared.

The current period of rainfall deficiency is associated with the El Nino effect. The El Nino is an accumulation of warm waters in the central and eastern Pacific Ocean off the South American coast and the accumulation of cold waters off northern Australia. This disturbs the air mass circulation over the Pacific Ocean, leading to reduced rainfall over eastern Australia.

An El Nino phase is associated with a sustained period of negative southern oscillation index, known as SOI, values; a relative measure of air pressure between Darwin and Tahiti. The SOI has been essentially negative since mid-1990 because of warmer than normal waters in the eastern and central Pacific. The present period of negative SOI has been exceeded by only one other episode—from 1911 to 1916. I understand that that was a period of major drought as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was 1902, wasn't it?

—I am sure Senator Brownhill is right. There have been other periods of drought in Australia's history, but certainly the current drought and the one experienced during the period of World War I are the two major droughts of this century. The Bureau of Meteorology expects that water temperatures will continue to rise in the eastern and central Pacific over the next few months, maintaining the negative SOI.

PARA.TAB: Queensland and northern New South Wales rainfall shows the highest correlation with the SOI. In the worst affected state, Queensland, 38 per cent of the state is drought declared. It has been experiencing essentially similar conditions for the last three years. In New South Wales, drought declarations now cover 83 per cent of the state.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had indicated that the Labor government will not abandon farmers. The government has certainly been addressing this issue progressively in line with the progressively worsening situation. Evidence of that will be shown on the release of the details of the drought package, after cabinet has finalised its deliberations some time this afternoon. Obviously, that announcement will be made in due course.

The other matter I want to touch on, which is dealt with in subclause (iii) of clause (d) of the motion, relates essentially to greenhouse issues. The government's response to climatic change has been effective in reducing emissions of greenhouse gases. I want to strongly rebut Senator Margetts's contribution in this area. The government has been acting; and those greenhouse gas emissions are well below what otherwise would have been reached.

Australia will bridge 54 per cent of the gap between our 1990 emissions and those projected for the year 2000. This represents a seven per cent decrease in total emissions against the projected business as usual scenario; that is, the without any measures level. This is a good performance and compares favourably with countries such as the US and the United Kingdom. It is harder for Australia to meet the implied 1990 target in the climate change convention because in percentage terms our projected business as usual emissions are higher than most other OECD countries.

The government recognises that there is more that can be done to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. In keeping with the dynamic phased approach of the 1992 national greenhouse response strategy, the government is developing further greenhouse options, including innovative approaches involving the active participation of industry. Current measures adopted by the government to meet Australia's international commitments cover a wide range of areas encompassing energy and agriculture. Moreover, they constitute a responsible and balanced approach that reflects the need to protect our vital economic and trade interests.

Australia's contributions to global efforts on greenhouse are in keeping not only with our commitments but also with Australia's circumstances in which so much of our economic welfare and trade competitiveness are linked to our efficient production of energy, based largely on fossil fuels.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be if we were efficient.

—I do not know what Senator Margetts would suggest. But I have one possible thought—not that I would agree with it: that she would be suggesting as her contribution to the reduction of global greenhouse that we end the export of coal, for example. I do not know whether she is in favour of reductions in coal exports. I would be interested to hear her views. I suspect she does. If she does not, she can interject and disagree with me—but I do not hear any interjection. I am sorry Mr Acting Deputy President, I should not invite interjections. It is unruly of me.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—On this occasion it would be welcomed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's disorderly!

—It is disorderly. I am still waiting to hear. Perhaps in a later contribution the Greens can indicate whether they are opposed to the export of coal, for example. Australia is continuing to work for international approaches that will be globally effective and equitable. This means that all countries will need to share both the effort and the costs if we are to have any lasting effect on climate change.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the package that is being presented to cabinet this morning, I can only reinforce the message delivered by the Prime Minister, by the minister, Senator Collins, and by government members collectively that the government takes very seriously the current critical drought situation in Queensland and New South Wales. It will be a comprehensive package that will appropriately deal with the issue in a measured and targeted way. I will add more to those comments on that issue at the appropriate time when we consider that drought package over the coming weeks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said earlier when we were debating the suspension of standing orders, it is rather premature to be calling on the Senate to be debating an issue such as this at a time when we are waiting for the government to come out with its drought alleviation plan. It is still debating it at the moment, I would imagine, in its cabinet. I would have thought that it would be better to wait and see what is happening, and I think Senator Sherry has said that.

PARA.TAB: It is rather sad to be debating at this stage something that will be scientifically looked at to find out whether or not there is a warming—I do not entirely agree that there is any real proof yet to say there is or there is not—because, basically, people out there are really hurting with this drought. This drought is not about looking at what will happen in 30 years time. First of all, we should be looking at how we can help the people out there who are really hurting at the moment. It is urgent. I think the urgency of the drought is what we should be debating this afternoon after we hear what the government has come down with in its recommendations as to what it will do about the rural adjustment scheme, et cetera.

The government is at long last starting to recognise that there is a drought out there, there is a lot of hurt and hardship going on and that, if it does not do something at the moment to retain our breeding herds and our breeding flocks, there will be a dramatic downturn in revenue from our exports in three years time. I have said that in this place numerous times already since we have been debating the drought. The National Party and the Liberal Party have been talking in this place about drought and the problems associated with it much more than anyone else and trying to make the government aware of the problems out there.

Just recently the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) even made a statement—it was just about the same time as he made the statement that Senator Margetts is talking about in her motion—asking why the National Party is out there shedding crocodile tears about the drought when it is a natural, recurring phenomenon. The fact is that drought does recur. There is no doubt about drought recurring. It recurs in different cycles and at different times. Whether there is any more frequency of drought at the moment, I do not know. Some areas of Australia last year had most probably better seasons than they have ever had. Other areas of Australia have had drought for four years. So I think it is very hard to work out what is happening in relation to the frequency of droughts.

The Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, of which numerous of us in this chamber are members, has been all over Australia looking at the rural adjustment scheme and how it is working to see whether or not it is working adequately, to see what can be done and to see what recommendations it can make. As Senator Burns said earlier today, such recommendations will be coming down in the first week of the December sittings. Hopefully the government will take some notice of those recommendations. It has not always taken notice of some of the recommendations that have been made. For example, we had an inquiry into drought in 1992 and, had the government taken notice of some of the things that were recommended, maybe there would not be such a problem out in the rural areas at the moment.

Drought, as I said, occurs sometimes once every five years. It may be that once every five years farmers lose a crop. It is once every six years in some areas. It varies all over Australia. There are major droughts. Senator Sherry alluded to when those major droughts occurred in Australia and whether or not they related to the southern oscillation index.

I make another point about RAS, which we have been looking at, before I go on to the substantive parts of Senator Margetts's motion. A lot of people have been falling through the cracks in the rural adjustment scheme. I hope we find from the recommendations that the government is bringing down today that it is going to do something about this. Either people have been too viable or they have not been viable enough, or they have been too profitable or they have not been profitable enough, so they have been falling through from one part to another. Obviously, people have been having trouble with Austudy. People have been having trouble educating their kids. I will just quote what somebody said to us at one of the hearings: `If you can't put food on the table, if you can't educate your kids as well as the city people, surely it is time for the government to take notice.'

The government has taken notice. Hopefully in the recommendations that it comes down with today it will give help and assistance to the people out there who have all of the problems associated with the climate and everything else. In fact, the farmers have no meat on their bones at the moment. They have no fat on the meat of their bones. This is all basically because of this government, which in the last 10 years has gutted the rural communities.

Before we start talking about this motion, we have to start looking at why the people in the rural areas are having so many problems and why they are crying out for help at the moment. Considering that the new drought scheme came into place in 1992, there has not been time for people to prepare for this drought. There has been only a short time since the government came down with its changes to the drought policy.

What has the government done in the last 10 years that has really guttered the rural communities? We have to look at this. The government took away the effective IED scheme, the income equalisation deposits scheme. It made it so that people did not in the good years they had during the 1980s put away money in that scheme. There is only $137 million in that scheme at the moment. That is not enough money to carry people through because they were not given enough incentive to put their money in there. So the government gutted that scheme. The government did not take the scheme away entirely, but it changed and gutted it.

What did the government do in the mid-1980s? It foisted the rural communities with interest rates that crippled people. Interest rates went from 12 per cent in some cases to 24 per cent. They doubled. People were giving away a quarter of their income every year in paying the interest on their loans, and remember that people in the rural communities have loans. Some people say they are net lenders, but a lot of the rural people have overdrafts.

What else did the government do? It took away the floor price of wool. I am not arguing whether it was good or bad, but the government took away the floor price after having said it would not take it away. It really pulled the rug from under a lot of woolgrowers.

TALK.START.PARA: —What's the price of wool now?

—Albeit the price of wool has now gone up again, which is good. But I am just saying that the floor price was taken away even though the minister at the time said that the government would not take it way. Then overnight he took it away, and that really knocked the guts out of people.

PARA.TAB: We had commodity downturns, which I cannot blame the government for, in the rural sector during the 1980s. What did the government do? It thought that it had better foist a fringe benefits tax onto the rural communities. It was quite interesting when we were at hearings in the Northern Territory the other day to hear evidence from people that they are paying $40 a week on fringe benefits tax because they are supplying food to the ringers out in the mustering camps. Basically, I do not know what the alternative restaurants would be out in the centre of the Northern Territory. Are they under the gum trees? Anyway, the employers are getting slogged something like $40 a week.

The government changed the capital gains tax and put in de facto death duties. This all applies to people in the rural communities. Kicked them in the guts, this government has; this government has kicked the rural communities in the guts over the last 10 years. I think the government should stand condemned for that.

The government changed the depreciation allowances and took away completely the investment allowances. The government should have had that in place—it would have known that if it had looked at the recommendations of our drought committee—to make sure that people put up silos, sheds and other sorts of things to put fodder away, and put money away into the income equalisation deposits scheme so that people could have prepared for this drought.

The government took drought out of the natural disaster area. Personally, it does not matter whether it is or is not in the natural disaster area; what really matters is whether government takes note of something that gets beyond the individual's ability to cope with. Obviously, government then has to do something. Having done all the things expected of them, when things get beyond rural people the government should at least recognise that they have to be given some help or assistance.

What did the government do with fuel excise? Does this government not realise that people who live out in country areas use a lot more fuel than people who live in the cities? The government slammed up the fuel excise from about 6c to nearly 30c a litre. People in the bush do not get any alleviation from this excise when they travel by road. They are being slugged by this government again. The excise put up the cost of the freight into and out of their properties.

What did the government do with wholesale taxes? When the Labor Party came to power, wholesale taxes amounted to something like $3 billion. Now, under this government, something like $13 billion is being collected in wholesale taxes. Much of this tax applies to the transport industry and it is another slug on the carriage of goods in and out of farmers' properties. I have already mentioned the assets test for Austudy. Also, the Australian dollar is at an artificially high level to protect the bad budget policies of this government.

In order to set the scene for where we are at the moment, I have outlined what the government has done to rural communities. I hope that we will be able to say that the policy initiatives to be announced today by the government will alleviate some of those problems.
In her motion, Senator Margetts quotes a few things that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said on 4RK Rockhampton. Her motion states that, in the context of drought relief, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that drought is not an intermittent disaster but is probably a manifestation of climate change effects and is becoming a permanent feature of the Australian landscape . . .

The Prime Minister was condemned all over Australia by every person in the rural community for saying that drought is a natural recurring phenomenon. As I said earlier, droughts, little dry times or whatever occur about every five or six years. Maybe they occur every 10 years in some areas. Maybe in Victoria they never occur. People can cope with little droughts or little dry times. But every now and again there is a scorcher. The drought at the moment is a scorcher.

PARA.TAB: People in Queensland who have missed out on four years of cropping—which is eight separate crops over the last four years—are now concerned about whether they will have the money to resow when the drought breaks. I wonder whether the government will have anything in its policy initiatives to be released today about resowing funding for people in those areas who will not be able to afford to resow unless they get some form of assistance.

I wonder whether the government will announce today some sort of fodder scheme that will help people keep their breeding herd and their breeding flock alive. There is an animal welfare aspect to this because people in a lot of places are letting their stock die. I hope the minister is taking a little notice of this problem and that we will hear something today about that as well. If we let our flocks and herds die, what will happen to our meat exports and our wool exports in the next few years? Government senators are all smiling because wool prices are up at the moment. If we do not have any sheep to shear in a few years time, we will not have much wool to export. That is something that has to be looked at.
Part (b) of Senator Margetts's motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . recognises the importance of agricultural exports to our economy—
we have just been talking about them—
and the impact of climate disruption on the security of that sector . . .

I can assure the Senate that floods are a disruption, droughts are a disruption, high winds are a disruption and terrible runs of frost are a disruption. This year some places had 30-odd scorching frosts in a row, which really knocked out the back end of what little grass there was. A series of very cold nights and heavy frosts knock the heck out of stock, too. Part (c) of her motion states:
. . . supports the call for the development of a policy to effectively assist farmers to adjust to changing climatic conditions . . .

I do not disagree with that. But I do disagree with the claim by the Prime Minister in the first part of her motion that drought `is probably a manifestation of climate change effects and is becoming a permanent feature of the Australian landscape'. I do not think there is any real proof at this stage, and I will refer in a minute to some of the evidence we had in 1992 on this matter. The fact is that there is no real proof at the moment to show that what the Prime Minister said—as recorded in the first part of this motion—is correct.

PARA.TAB: Senator Margetts then calls for `a major commitment of funding to address the longer term structural problems of an agriculture sector facing massive climatic disruption'. I agree with that because this government has gutted this sector in the past, and it stands condemned for doing so. The government now wants to get into farmers' pockets. Instead of getting into their pockets, the government should get into its own pockets. It gives plenty to ANL. It gives plenty to its mates. If its old union mates need a bit of dough, it gives it to them. What about the poor old farmers? Why do the poor old farmers not get a bit?

Part (d)(i) of the motion talks about the agricultural sector `facing massive climatic disruption'. Yes, there is climatic disruption at the moment. This very big climatic disruption has caused a big drought. Part (d)(ii) states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . provision of assistance to farmers at least equivalent to drought relief to ameliorate the personal impact of climatic change on these farmers, as well as assistance in adjusting to new climatic conditions . . .
I do not quite understand what that means and I have reservations about these parts of the motion. Part (d)(iii) states:

. . . a strong policy designed to limit the source of the pollutants that lead to climatic change domestically and support for a strong international protocol to ensure the reduction of pollutants that may worsen the climate instability.

Maybe Senator Chamarette has explained that to us. With the reservations I have outlined, I can support this motion; I can go along with it. But I do not agree with all the points or assumptions she has made.
