PARA.TAB: I will quote what the final report of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs in July 1992 had to say about the national drought policy. It is interesting because the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry), who is at the table, earlier talked about what was happening as a result of El Nino. It is quite interesting to note that research—which was basically what Senator Margetts was on about—is being done into different things. The report stated:
Mr Hunt gave the Committee detailed information on climate research undertaken by CSIRO and the difficulties in attracting funds for this research.

SPEECH.PARA: So be it. I think a motion concerning the CSIRO will be brought on this afternoon. The CSIRO is another thing that this government has gutted and it stands condemned for that as well.

PARA.TAB: The government does not stand condemned for the fact that it has not rained. I do not blame the government for that; but I blame it for all the things that it has done that have hurt so many people and which have meant that they cannot cope with the drought. The government absolutely stands condemned for that and it stands condemned for gutting the CSIRO. The report went on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: He emphasised that this research is not only important to Australia but also has worldwide application. Mr Hunt noted that drought research is not accorded the priority that more topical research projects receive. He elaborated:

PARA.TAB: Greenhouse actually has been the saviour of the drought research program because it has brought a considerable influx of scientists and money into the Division which has enabled us to go ahead with our model development which we would not have been able to do otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, poor old CSIRO has been gutted by this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —They obviously see the connection between drought and greenhouse.

—It has not substantiated it because it does not have the money; nor has it done the research to say that it is causing a warming or that it is not causing a warming, that there is a problem or that there is not a problem. The CSIRO has just said that that brought extra money into its research.

PARA.TAB: Dr Gauntlett talked about El Nino. The report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the El Nino southern oscillation phenomenon `only explains about 40 per cent of the natural rainfall variability'. He listed a number of other processes, such as variability of ocean circulation patterns and Antarctic sea ice, which may also be influences on Australia's rainfall patterns. Given the complexity of the relationships between the various climatic influences, complex and sophisticated numerical simulation techniques will need to be pursued. The results of this research would not be immediate, Dr Gauntlett noted. He further commented on the time scale for development of improved predictive capability:

With further research and the right sort of resource support, progress will be made there as well. But it is going to be a long haul thing. There is no easy answer. I would be thinking more in terms of the 10-year time scale, rather than the next couple of years.

We are talking about things that might be 10 or 20 years down the track. At the moment we have people who are crying out for help. These people have had their noses rubbed in the dust by this government because of its policies over the last 12 years or so. These people are on their hands and knees saying, `Please give us a little bit of help and support.' I do not think they are saying, `Please have a look at greenhouse. Please tell us whether there is a climatic change or not.' Those people who are absolutely crying out for help are not looking for that; they are looking for real hard help. The report continues:
Mr Barry Hunt made the following observation:
We have had a decade of cutbacks in the CSIRO. We got rid of the fat and we are now starting to cut into the bone and muscle.

This government stands condemned for the fact that it has cut all those bits of aid and help in the scientific approach to drought and other things that it ought to have done something about. I will come back to the motion that has been moved by Senator Margetts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well done, David.

—I think my remarks have been relevant to the motion—very relevant. Those opposite did not quote any of those things about the drought. That is the problem with this government. Those opposite have never read this damn book. If they have seen this book—the national drought policy—they have not read it. If they have read it, they have not absorbed it. They do not have the ability to put it into their damn heads, otherwise they would have done something for the rural community. There is the report, for God's sake. Why did they not do something about it so that the people would not have as big a problem as they have now?

PARA.TAB: I do not accept the points that Senator Margetts made about climate change because I do not believe that that has been proved. If it was proved, I would agree. Apart from that, we would agree with this motion, but only on the proviso that the government does something decent today for the farming community by way of its policy statement. Otherwise, we will be back here this afternoon and tomorrow debating what the government has done to ameliorate the problems associated with this drought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me begin by pointing out that Senator Margetts's original motion was substantially amended by the President on the grounds that it contained very significant extracts of statements which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had made. My own view is that, in doing that, the President substantially changed the motion. I am being kind to the opposition here, but perhaps that is one of the reasons why the opposition has not picked up the central theme which was well developed by Senator Margetts, that is, that the emphasis is on climate change rather than drought.

PARA.TAB: I agree with Senator Brownhill that quite clearly those farmers in New South Wales and Queensland, in particular, who have suffered from drought for four years and who have had up to eight failures of crops are not, at this stage, thinking about climate change. What those farmers want is immediate relief.

However, it is the responsibility of this government and this parliament to take a longer term view, and therefore it is absolutely appropriate that Senator Margetts draw attention to the fact that this may well be not an extreme event in a normal cycle, but rather an extreme event which would be expected under a greenhouse scenario. Therefore, it is absolutely appropriate for this parliament and this government to be looking at that aspect in addition to the immediate relief which farmers are clearly seeking.

There is a principle which has been clearly enunciated by the ecologically sustainable development working groups, and it has been enunciated more broadly in a number of publications, including the Brundtland report. That principle broadly says that, if one is in a situation where one cannot be absolutely certain of the consequences but some of those consequences are going to be potentially quite disastrous, then a wise and prudent person would take precautions to ensure that those worst consequences were put off for as long as possible until one had better knowledge.

One is absolutely surprised to hear the opposition say, `But we don't have proof yet that we are in a greenhouse situation.' My God, how long do we wait? Do we wait until we are hanging right over the edge of the cliff, about to drop into the abyss, knowing full well that by that stage, if we are suffering a climate change, the consequences will be so disastrous that there is no going back? Alternatively, do we intelligently recognise that the levels of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere are increasing; that the rate of increase is accelerating; that all the climate models in the world indicate that that will bring about climate change; and that scientists have made reasonable predictions in relation to those expected climate changes? Looking at that, do we then take the precautionary approach and seek to slow down those changes as far as we can until we have a better fix on it?

I suggest to Senator Brownhill and to members of the opposition—I will deal with the government later—that a wise person would take that precautionary view, and a wise person would therefore be factoring in the possible consequences of these greenhouse changes.

What we do know is that the levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere have increased very substantially since the start of the industrial age: they have gone from roughly 270 parts per million to about 350 parts per million. As I indicated a moment ago, they are still increasing. I stress again: a wise person, looking at that global change and recognising that this is the only habitable piece of rock in our corner of the universe, would say, `My God, we should slow that down until we get a better handle on exactly what the consequences of that change are.'

We cannot go anywhere else. If those changes prove to be disastrous and if Australia's agriculture collapses—as Senator Margetts indicates may well happen under a significant greenhouse climate change—we have nowhere else to go. We are animals. We require food. We require water. We require our sustenance from the environment. If that is taken away—

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not animals.

—I will develop that again, Senator Boswell. We are animals with physiological requirements which I will get onto in a moment because that bears very much on how we address this question. We have also observed that there have been significant increases in methane in the global atmosphere. We know about the CFCs. Fewer people recognise that the HCFCs, which we are using to substitute for the CFCs, are also greenhouse gases, and they are increasing very substantially in the atmosphere at the moment. We should be concerned about that. Nitrogen, oxides and a variety of other agents are also greenhouse gases, and they are increasing in concentration in the atmosphere.

PARA.TAB: The model predicts that there will be a rise in global temperature. What do we find when we look at the record? We find that there is a rise in global temperature. No competent scientist is prepared to say at this stage that that rise is due to the greenhouse effect, but every one of them is prepared to say that the rise is consistent with it and if we were suffering from a greenhouse effect, this is what one would see. Moreover, as Senator Margetts has pointed out, the models predict that the frequency of extreme events is expected to increase. The area under the tails of the distribution curve will increase very substantially with quite modest changes in mean temperature.

What do we find when we look specifically at this drought? We find that we have had a four-year drought. The prediction is that it will go on into at least March of next year. When looking over the record—and I stand to be corrected on this—I understood that the drought to which Senator Sherry referred was from 1911 to 1914, and there was also one from 1939 to 1942. The drought that we are suffering from at the moment is an extreme event since white settlement by any measure.

No competent scientist is prepared to say that this drought is due to the greenhouse effect, but I am sure that most of them would say that this is the sort of thing that we would expect if we were suffering from the greenhouse effect. I come back to the point that a prudent person—evidently we do not have prudent people among the opposition—would attempt to slow down that rate of change in the global atmosphere until one had a better handle on the exact consequences and would not simply let the thing go until it was too late.

The most recent predictions one has seen coming from the CSIRO are that, even with the most vigorous attention given to greenhouse gases, as of 1994 we will almost certainly double the concentration of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere as compared with what that they were prior to the onset of the industrial age before we can cause them to level off at some point.

As to predictions relating to the greenhouse effect, the very first paper that I have in my file is dated 1972. It is a very comprehensive and well-referenced document. I am reminded of the Swedish chemist Arrhenius who, at the end of the last century, pointed to the increase in the use of fossil fuel and the danger which that would pose to the world in relation to increasing the level of CO(2) and, therefore, that would have an effect on the global atmosphere with the sort of consequences that are now being more widely talked about. The

SPEECH.PARA: notion that this is something new that we do not know about is simply not true. Scientists have been concerned about this effect for a long time.

PARA.TAB: When we look at the cost benefit analysis—Senator Margetts has drawn our attention to this as well—we find that a number of people in industry and a number of right wing think-tanks in this country are saying, `It is far too expensive to address the greenhouse problem because Australia is dependent on fossil fuel.' However, taking into account the precautionary principle, the realistic way to do this cost benefit analysis would allow that this drought may well be due to the greenhouse effect. That would be put on the cost side of the equation and put against the fact that we are a major exporter of coal.

We were asked by way of an interjection earlier what we would do about coal exports. I have frequently been on the record in this place saying that the coal industry is a dying industry and, recognising the greenhouse consequences, we should be progressively phasing it out. We should not have spent 90 per cent of our energy research dollars on coal research, as this government has done since it came to office in 1983. The government should have been spending that money in other directions, developing energy efficient alternatives and renewable energy systems—and there are many of both of these. If we had gone down that road, we would certainly be further advanced in relation to being able to tackle this problem. Australia is a very profligate user of fossil fuel. We cannot excuse ourselves on the grounds that we are dependent upon that fossil fuel and, therefore, we have to continue on in that way into the future.

The next point that I want to dwell on is the government's lack of action in this area. I contest Senator Sherry's claim that there has been an action on the part of the government which has reduced the greenhouse gas emissions compared with what they would have been under a business-as-usual scenario. I do not know of one action which this government can point to and say, `That action by this government has reduced our greenhouse gas emissions by this amount.' Certainly, during the years of the recession, greenhouse gas emissions have declined compared with where they would have been had we had the gung-ho economic growth of the earlier 1980s. In a peculiar way, I suppose the government was responsible for this with the recession, if that is what it is claiming.

However, I do not think for one moment that the government can point to any action that it has taken which has effectively reduced the greenhouse gas emissions in the long term in this country. I would certainly like the minister to point to any specific measures if he can. On the contrary, what one finds in this government is that throughout all of the portfolios—with the exception of the environment portfolio through the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), who seems to be looking at the greenhouse problem—all of the actions that are going forward are taking no account whatsoever of the problem of the greenhouse effect.

I will mention just one example which was on the news this morning. The Prime Minister of Australia met with the Irish Prime Minister and he talked about the desirability of tourism between our two countries. I was recently in southern Africa and I happened to do a few calculations on the energy costs of tourism. When one does these calculations, one finds—I was not surprised by this, I more or less expected it—that international tourism is an absolute no-no if it is based on air travel in a greenhouse world. If Australia is going to meet its greenhouse target as set by the IPCC of a 60 to 80 per cent reduction and be fair to the rest of the world—and I point out that Australia is a very profligate user of greenhouse gases—we would need to reduce the level by a great deal more than that unless we intended to retain for ourselves a larger proportion of the energy which the world uses.

If we cut down our greenhouse gas emissions by 75 per cent, we would have 50 gigajoules available to each person in Australia each year. Every tourist coming from Ireland to Australia and going back again or every tourist going from Australia to Ireland would use twice that amount in the period of their two- to three-week trip. I use this example to point out that the government goes ahead with the idea of tourism and totally ignores the consequences which that will have in the greenhouse area. Therefore, it totally ignores the consequences which that activity would have on agriculture in Australia through climate change.

TALK.START.PARA: —The cattle industry will be gone next.

—Yes, I will pick-up on food production. There is a long history of studies on the energy costs of Western agriculture. I will come back to the point that human beings are, after all, animals which require a certain intake of calories or megajoules each day for their sustenance. Like all animals, we are approximately 10 per cent efficient in energy terms. In other words, we require 10 units of energy taken in each day to put out one energy of useful work. In gatherer-hunter societies, obviously, we were very efficient. We took in a great deal more than 10 units of energy for one unit of output because gatherer-hunter societies were actually able to spend a lot of their time in creative activities away from actual food gathering and production. What does one find in so-called modern agricultural systems?

PARA.TAB: I point out some work done by Perelman many years ago, which has been repeated by a number of other people, which shows that for every unit of energy which appears on the table, say in Australia, five units of energy go into that production. So in energy terms our agricultural systems are very inefficient. If we were to do our sums in energy terms rather than in dollar terms, we would recognise that we have very significant changes to make. We have a GATT agreement. We have a government which is committed to the idea of increasing international trade and transport. One of the major energy costs of putting food on the table is the transport cost and that has been referred to. But rather than reduce the costs, one has to reduce the energy inputs and, in seriously addressing the problem of greenhouse, that is the way we need to go.

There is another example which brings it right home. We would personally use in our air travelling to and from Canberra from our home bases twice the amount of energy that we would have available to us in a greenhouse world. Are we going to selfishly retain to ourselves a larger slice of the energy available to Australia, or are we going to seriously look at the fact that we need to restructure not only the way we produce, transport and process our food but also the way in which we organise our society?

Government has not even begun to think about these sorts of issues because it has not really grasped the problem of greenhouse, which is a major problem. It is a problem that really underpins everything else that we need to address in every possible portfolio in every aspect of our social life and our economy if we are seriously to come to grips with this problem. The consequences if we do not, as Senator Margetts's motion points out, are that we may well suffer these sorts of droughts far more frequently and we may see a major change in the whole structure of agriculture in Australia.

I will emphasise another point that Senator Margetts made in her speech and that is that because we have one drought we do not change our agricultural practices. The uncertainty means that it is very difficult to change our agricultural practices. It takes a long time. We will have to have long and repeated droughts before we recognise that this is a permanent condition. In a greenhouse world the past will not be a predictor of the future. We need to think in different ways. We need to recognise the uncertainty which makes it extremely difficult for farmers and pastoralists to reorganise their practices on the land. It is not just the costs of the equipment and retooling that Senator Margetts was talking about; it is the uncertainty to which Senator Brownhill has already drawn attention.

I will conclude by pointing out that in other areas the government is also pursuing quite the wrong course. We have recently seen processes put in place in relation to the national grid system, which is primarily aimed to make electricity cheaper. It will, almost certainly, drive the electricity system into generating electricity from brown coal in Victoria and from black coal in New South Wales, rather than natural gas in South Australia—a fuel which emits in its burning far less greenhouse gas.

The government—driven by this economic rationalism and driven by reports from the Industry Commission and bodies such as that—is simply not looking at the greenhouse consequences of its actions. It is true that we will not get increased energy efficiency if we strive to make energy as cheap as possible and totally ignore the greenhouse externalities. We need to write those externalities in. We need to recognise that the cost of this drought may well be due to greenhouse. Writing those costs in will drive us towards the alternatives that we need to develop and there are many of these.

In the domestic energy area—one that I have drawn attention to repeatedly—the government has put a paltry sum of $6 million towards a solar domestic hot water system, but it is totally inadequate. What one finds in my home state of South Australia is that the Electricity Trust of South Australia is still strongly promoting the use of electricity for domestic water heating—something which is very inefficient and which results in enormous releases of greenhouse gas. Yet we have probably one of the best developed solar hot water systems in the world.

We have some of the best technology here. It is a technology which we are already exporting to a number of nearby countries and which could be increased very substantially. The costs, again, could be reduced if our domestic industry were producing more units, so the unit cost would actually come down. We have a number of manufacturers in Australia. They employ a large number of people. Very significant reductions in the domestic use of electricity, a very inefficient form of energy, could be made through that measure.

We have put in place a proposal for ethanol for transport. There are exciting possibilities here in relation to a renewable fuel based on cellulose from waste paper, timber wastes and so on to provide fuel and enormous regional and country employment. There is a very good proposal in South Australia to use low value grain to produce ethanol for on farm use which, I hope, at least in the next year, will attract the bounty scheme and get under way. It will provide farmers with not just a cheaper fuel but a fuel over which they have some control and a fuel which they produce locally themselves. There are enormous opportunities. We are turning our backs on so many things that we could do. That would certainly not meet the IPC's targets; I do not think there is any technology we have at the moment that would allow us to get down to that sort of level, but at least we can make a start. We can certainly exceed the 20 per cent target which the government and other governments had set by the year 2005. In going down that road, via a suitable iterative approach and looking at where we are, at new technologies and at the change in institutional and social structures that would need to be put in place in relation to transport and a whole range of other human activities, we can make further changes as we go.

Unless we do that, we will find that Senator Margetts's motion is absolutely spot on. We will almost certainly see an increased frequency of these extreme events. We will need to pay enormous costs, which eventually will probably far and away outweigh any temporary benefit that we get from remaining wedded to fossil fuel exports. It really is not intelligent for us not to take the precautionary approach. It would be far more intelligent for us to recognise the real possibility that we are indeed going towards the abyss. We do not want to be hanging by our fingernails over the edge before we recognise where we are. We therefore need to put in place those measures which we already know about, which will substantially reduce our greenhouse gas emissions. We will therefore, in that process, give some longer term hope to farmers that these sorts of conditions will not be visited on them more frequently in the future.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, my comments today will be fairly brief because I envisage that we will be debating the real thing in another couple of hours.
—The real thing?
—The real thing is the package that the government will be putting before us. That is what is of utmost importance. That is the main game for rural Australia today.

PARA.TAB: Every farmer will be listening to the news today to find out what the government has produced. Farmers will want to know if there is some hope for them being able to stay on the land—whether they will be able to get Austudy for their children, JSA, farm household support. The whole focus of our farming industry today will be on the package that the government will be bringing down. That is why I say that is the main game today. Nevertheless, Senator Margetts raised some important issues which I found interesting from an academic point of view.

Senator Coulter also raised some issues that need to be debated. But during his contribution today he hardly touched on the drought. He went off on a frolic of his own, getting on one of his hobbyhorses. Of course, that is his right; he believes in the importance of those issues.

The fact is that this drought has been going on for four years. I first raised it as an issue on 21 November 1992. It was bad then and it is worse now. But the drought is only the third leg of the trifecta. The first was low commodity prices, caused by a collapse in the wool industry and the firm commitment of the government to stand by the floor prices. That commitment was supposed to be irrefutable, rock solid, set in cement and never to be changed.

On 13 occasions Mr Kerin went out and told the woolgrowers that they could rely on a floor price. The woolgrowers made their adjustments and planned their budgets on the basis of that agreement. Their financial commitments were based on the fact that Mr Kerin had said that the floor price would not disappear. When it did disappear that was the first hit.

The second hit—I think this is even worse than the drought—was the high interest rates that just sucked the equity out of their properties. They had planned on interest rates holding at 15 per cent but they went to 18 to 23 to 24 per cent, and that took the equity out of their farms.

As I said, the third part of the trifecta is the drought. On 19 July the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made some comments on the radio. Those comments have been incorporated in the motion moved by Senator Margetts and I do not want to repeat them. But the fact is that this government had to be dragged kicking and screaming into this drought debate.

On 19 July it was just another drought that had occurred on top of all the other droughts that are always occurring in Australia. If it had not been for Channel 9 and the media generally dragging this government into this debate it would not have entered into it. A Current Affair presented programs depicting, among other things, young farm children who could not get Austudy. That was one of the stories that led to the establishment of the Farm Hand appeal. But it is not the media's job to run a social welfare package for farmers, as welcome as it may be; that is the government's job. The role of the media is to report the events; the government is there to solve the problems.

On 21 November 1992 the drought was already bad. People were in trouble—they were being thrown off their farms and were losing equity in their properties. It is now September 1994—nearly two years later—and the government is only now about to bring down a package. Meanwhile, people have been thrown off their properties, looking for work off the farm, cashing in their insurance policies and selling their wedding presents and jewellery to keep their children at school. Finally, because of the pressure brought by Channel 9, by the Australian, by the press gallery and by the media generally, the government was forced to act. It had nowhere else to go. It was dragged into this debate and today we will finally see a package after two years of hurt.

I have here four or five pages of the benefits that were accrued over a number of years by the Anthony-Fraser government—by the National Party and the Liberal Party—and that have been stripped away from rural Australia by the Labor government. Now, belatedly, that government has come up with a package.

Many farmers have told me that had they had access to the money they had paid in taxes in 1987, 1988 and 1989 when the wool prices were fair and reasonable—even good at some stages—they could have withstood the drought, the high interest rates and even the commodity collapses. But, as Senator Brownhill said, the IED scheme was gutted. The farmers had to pay huge tax bills when wool prices were high but had no fall-back position when commodity prices collapsed, interest rates went up and the drought came.

I hope that this package today will be good because this government has a lot to make up for. Whatever the package is, it will be too late for some but I hope that it will be good enough to sustain all the people left out on the farms because they are the backbone of this nation's wool, grain and cattle industries. They are the efficient ones. They are the ones who have hung on, the fighters who are not going to let go. They must be saved at all costs. I hope this package will do the job for those people. I look forward to it with anticipation and in hope.

I will be examining this package as soon as it comes down. That is when we should suspend standing orders and go into a full-blown debate over whether the package is good or bad. This issue means so much to Australia that, irrespective of what we think of the package, we should bring it forward and then go into a debate on the issue of what primary industry means to Australia and how we can sustain it.

I would welcome the support of the Greens on this issue because it is a matter that must be debated in full by the Senate and the House of Representatives. I look forward to debating that package today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleagues Senator Margetts and Senator Coulter have put forward some careful arguments and I know that Senator Margetts will deal with others in her closing remarks. I wish to touch on two aspects that are relevant and need to be raised. I refer to forest management practices and the impact of land clearing. The new report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change confirmed that the world's climate is at serious risk. This should add pressure on the government to stop logging our old-growth forests. Poor forest management by both state and federal governments definitely adds to Australia's inability to meet targets for greenhouse gas reductions.

PARA.TAB: As well as having inherent value and great importance as a species habitat, the forests play an important role in absorbing carbon dioxide. The uniquely Australian issue of the contribution of carbon dioxide from the use of fire as a land management tool is also a matter of great concern, contributing—and here I speak of my own state of Western Australia—to carbon dioxide emissions by the logging of our old-growth forests. But as well as destroying plants and animal habitats, excessive prescribed burning increases an already unacceptable level of carbon dioxide emission. The Conservation and Land Management Department of Western Australia is further contributing by allowing a large bark dump near the Diamond chip mill to burn non-stop since 1976.

Our forests in the south-west and in other parts of Australia have been under threat for some time. Logging and burning have resulted in the loss of our natural heritage and the extinction of species. Now we see that these practices are also threatening the `lungs of the earth'. If greenhouse gas reduction targets are to be met and forests protected, there needs to be a real shift in political will so that environmental protection becomes central to government decision making and action rather than secondary to it.

For this to be achieved the government needs to stop logging native forests immediately and move to plantations. It should change tax and land policies to provide incentives for retaining and planting bush. It needs to seriously examine the use of fire in forest and land management and to implement its own policies for buying recycled paper products. The contribution of agricultural policies to greenhouse emissions should not be overlooked. The government's approach to supporting farmers should not only relate to immediate concerns and the impact of drought, but look to the long-term future of the entire agricultural sector.

The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change confirmed that emissions of greenhouse gases are the main reason that the atmosphere's ability to absorb and emit energy is changing. When the environment minister, Senator Faulkner, released the greenhouse gas inventory he admitted that Australia would not reach reduction targets for greenhouse gases if only existing measures were followed. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The contribution of land clearing to greenhouse gases is unexpected and of serious concern.

According to the inventory, the energy sector is the single largest contributor to greenhouse gas emissions, and emissions from land clearing contribute about half as much carbon dioxide as the energy sector. This was unexpected, but it should not have been. We need to consider the increasing amount of information that tells us that the impact of stocking and of land clearance on our agricultural sector has been disastrous in its economic consequences. Now we can see that it has global implications and that Australia has a strong responsibility in this regard because we have the scientific and technological information to address the problems.

PARA.TAB: We also have the alternative strategies that simply need encouragement to be put in place. What we lack is political will. Unless we take a multifaceted approach to this problem, then Australia will suffer serious ecological, social and economic consequences. As well as developing strategies in regard to the energy and other industries, we also need to restructure the wood products industry so that alternative sources of wood and pulp for paper are further developed and used. Further, we need to develop agricultural policies whereby farmers are subsidised and given incentives for ecologically sustainable agriculture. The government should change tax and land policies to remove the present disincentives to retaining and planting bush. The long-term support for our agricultural sector which is embedded in Senator Margetts's motion is vital.

Senator Boswell has called on us to speak on the government package but said that the package is `too late for many'. The Greens' view is that, unless the package addresses the long-term impact of climate change and ecologically unsound agricultural practices, it will be too late even for those who have immediate benefit or who are left in our agricultural sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join others in this chamber, and certainly people in the community, in expressing concern about the drought that has gripped Australia. I acknowledge the contributions to this debate by my National Party colleagues Senator Brownhill and Senator Boswell. Senator Boswell has been the leader in raising the plight of stricken farmers, particularly those in Queensland. All Queensland farmers know that he is the politician that they can turn to in their desperation. He has been vigorous on these matters, both in this chamber and in the community, and also he has raised the media profile on this issue which has brought the matter to the attention of the government. He has brought home to this parliament that we have a national disaster on our hands.

PARA.TAB: Anybody who knows Senator Brownhill will be aware that he is not a man of fluctuating emotions, but on this issue he has a hair-trigger in relation to the plight of the farmers and towards anyone who underplays the plight of New South Wales farmers. He spoke from the heart today, as he has done on so many other occasions, on the drought. What he and Senator Boswell said encapsulates the emotions throughout Australia. Not just in the parliament or among politicians, who often come in too late on these matters, but across Australia and the community a great deal of emotion is now being expressed for the stricken farmers.

My state of Victoria has had its driest winter since the 1982 droughts, which in themselves were savage. This spring is not promising for farmers. Victoria's north-west, the mallee area, is bone dry, and crops across Victoria have failed. The weather bureau fears that the drought that has gripped eastern Australia will continue south into Victoria. We already know that 83 per cent of New South Wales is drought declared and over one-third of Queensland is in that category.

The drought has taken on the largeness of a national disaster. It now has the almighty reputation of being the worst drought ever. In our sunburnt country of sweeping plains that truly is a mighty claim, especially when we think back to the times of heartbreak faced by our pioneering ancestors. Those were times when much of our culture was shaped, and when our traditional bush songs, poetry and stories emerged. Yet today things are worse than in those earlier times. It is the same harsh realities faced by past and present Australians that have allowed the never-say-die quality to be passed on through the generations to this moment.

Of late there has been a great deal of emotion generated and captured throughout the rural communities. The finest report to date has been the Channel 9 drought report by Paul Ransley. In every way that story captured the plight of the rural communities and surely would have moved every city person watching this early morning Sunday program from the comfort of his or her lounge room.

One particular aspect that emerged from the story was the great strength displayed by the rural women. On each occasion that the farmer and his wife were interviewed, the man referred to his wife and, when he unashamedly broke down and could not continue with the interview, the wife took up the reins. I think Henry Lawson's poems The Drover's Wife and Brighten's Sister-in-Law still hold true today for those rural women.

Equally, the stirring of our city cousins, who so often borrow from our bush ethics, has been greatly and deeply appreciated. The high profile farmhand appeal, raising millions of dollars, and so many other charities and church groups that have chipped in, have helped the rural community in trouble with that unique Australian quality, that fine spirit of mateship. Why that spirit of mateship is one of Australia's best characteristics I cannot say, but it truly is and there is evidence of it today.

The economic losses of the drought will not be confined to the rural and regional areas. Rather, the impact will be felt throughout the whole economy. How can it not be when this country so heavily relies upon our primary industries? Its major exports of wool, wheat, beef and horticulture total some 20 per cent of exports. The effect of the drought upon the whole economy cannot be underestimated, yet I fear it is being underestimated. The roll-on effects are only now starting to be realised by the government and the economic writers. Already the failed winter crop has wiped out over $1.5 billion from export income, and Australian consumers will soon be feeling the impact of the escalating grain prices throughout the retail outlets.

The government forecasts of the losses from the drought seem to be underplayed when it says that the loss will be about $2 billion, or a 0.5 per cent shave off the GDP. I think those forecasts are looking rather underestimated. The National Farmers Federation has estimated the drought will cost the farm households alone over $1 billion directly in lost income. It is obvious that this lost income will have a roll-on effect on thousands of small businesses and industries that supply the farm sector.

The longer this national disaster continues, the greater the likelihood that this country will slip back into a recession in 1995-96. The drought is guaranteed to have an inflationary effect upon all points of the economy, an economy that is already facing an upswing in interest rates. That is a recipe for a renewed recession.

History will show that the greatest effect of this drought and the following wave of economic downturn will be yet another exodus of the family farmer. The family farm is the most efficient and social economic unit in society, yet there has been a growing assault on its economic structure and, indeed, its social structure. Over the past decade there has been the catchcry `small is no longer beautiful.' The great deregulation and privatisation debates have gained bull-at-a-gate support from all sections of the political leadership, without too much regard for the social and economic effects upon rural communities.

As is the general case with small business, family farms are the dynamo of private enterprise. Family farms represent Australian ownership of our natural resources. Such private access is rapidly being denied in other sectors of the economy due to the concentration of ownership in fewer and fewer hands. The link between ownership and work is a powerful stimulus to private enterprise.

Perhaps the blow-out in social welfare expenditure and the consequent government debt could have been avoided if such social and economic integration had been supported in metropolitan Australia before this time, especially if we are to meet the daunting economic challenges that face us post-drought. It is therefore incumbent upon the government not only to claim our breeding herds and crops as national assets worthy to be supported and preserved, but also to believe that the family farm is worth preserving and understand that farms do not always work as big organised corporations.

If ever the Australian public needed evidence that governments in Canberra become isolated from the happenings of the rest of Australia, it is sorely provided by this government's reaction to the four-year-long drought. Australian farmers and rural communities were reduced to a fourth year of severe drought and accepting packages from charity organisations before this government made a worthwhile contribution to this national disaster. Even then it was probably due to the very high media profile given to the farmhand fundraising effort, which subsequently created an enormous public interest across Australia, that politicians in Canberra, who hold the power and in government can do so much, really sat up and took notice. Prior to this, any effort to bring the drought to the attention of the government and, in particular, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) were met with those immortal words:

SPEECH.PARA: I notice the National Party running around saying I should be standing in a paddock in some drought affected area.
Drought is around now in Australia all the time so we have said let's try and cover this as a normal recurrence of rural life.

As for the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), he defended the government's record by relying upon the rural adjustment scheme as the cornerstone of government drought policy, even though he was aware that access to RAS was log jammed in red tape, and so great were its inefficiencies that it was subject at that very time he was defending it to a major Senate inquiry.

PARA.TAB: To rub salt into the wounds, the latest settlement in the waterfront strike must have confirmed where this government's ultimate loyalties lie. The absurd waterfront strike in defence of the bankrupt ANL shipping line cost the nation $55 million, yet it created a sense of urgency for settlement in Canberra, an urgency never given to the four-year-long drought which ravages parts of this country. While it has been only in the last month or so that the federal government has given the drought recognition, it took only 24 hours for the federal government to concede a remarkable tax-free concession to maritime workers. Australia's economy stands to lose billions of dollars from the drought and yet another blow is dealt to the Australian family farmer.

Mercifully, the government will today announce a welcome drought relief package and we will have time later on to scrutinise that package. It will go some of the way towards relieving the plight of our devastated farmers and rural communities and, in turn, will support the economy in general from collapsing. However, if we are to save our farmers and the rural communities, the focus must equally be upon the banking sector. In reality, the banking sector holds more power to the survival of the farmers than the government itself. Yet, unlike the government, it has yet to be brought to proper account and has been deafening in its silence regarding bank drought policy.

I will acknowledge the National Australia Bank as it has been a major player in the farmhand appeal. I trust this reflects a policy of understanding and leniency towards the hard-hit farming families and the rural communities. But the heat must go on the other banks to force a stated policy. It is not good enough for the Prime Minister, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy or the National Farmers Federation simply to appeal to the reasonableness of the banks. The banking sector is very well versed in offering measured public relations responses to such appeals, and these appeals will carry little weight with recession hardened financial institutions.

Stronger action is required. Farmers and small business need post-drought hope to fight present adversity. Hopelessness will set in with those fighting the drought if bank foreclosures haunt post-drought recovery. The banks' reputation in rural Australia is not good. What cut deepest during the recession of rural Australia was turning on the 6 o'clock news to the scene of a farmer and his family being dragged off their land following a dawn raid by sheriffs and banking officers. The tales of the banks' carpetbaggers have become as firm in legend in rural Australia as they were in the Deep South following the American Civil War carpetbaggers.

Even the National Farmers Federation has warned against the honesty of the banks by suggesting that they would prey upon the charity money raised for the farmers. If that sounds like an exaggeration, I refer the Senate to the comments of the National Farmers Federation in the Australian on 14 September 1994. The government has the authority to force a policy statement from the Australian Bankers Association and to monitor the tenets of that policy through the parliamentary banking, finance and public administration committee.

In conclusion, this time the bush is fighting for its life. It has faced over the past 11 years the crippling effect of high and sustained interest rates; a ruthless bank sector; uncaring and callous governments; depressed commodity prices; unmerciful and corrupt trading partners; and now the final blow—mother nature herself.

It is doubtful that any other country in the world, particularly any country that relied so much on its primary industry, would abandon its rural sector to abject poverty as this country has done. This should not be taken as the usual rural or bush cry. Unless this government and the Australian community wish to see forever a fundamental change in our rural landscape, every effort without exception must be made to sustain our farming community through these hard times. If not, we face a barren land beyond the metropolitan and coastal regions. The government's regional policy will amount to nil, and Australia as a nation would have thrown away its heritage and its wealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening to only part of what has been said this morning, as I was involved in another meeting. What has been said so far this morning about the drought, from what I can ascertain, has pertained to the eastern states—that is, Queensland, New South Wales and, I believe, part of Victoria—and, I suppose, rightly so. But that does not mean that my state of Western Australia is totally free of drought.

PARA.TAB: I did a round of what I thought may be the drought areas about three weeks ago, and since that time there has been no great amount of rainfall. There is a place in the south-east of Western Australia—incidentally, it includes the area in which Senator Winston Crane farms and stretches from Gnowangerup in the west to Condingup in the east, and from Salmon Gums in the north to Esperance in the south, a diamond shaped area—that has been badly affected by drought this year. The rainfall for Esperance, for instance, is 60 per cent below its lowest ever recording. Esperance is a town which normally receives 27 inches of rainfall, so it is normally regarded as a rather safe area. So it is a totally disastrous situation.

The drought has caused crop losses in quite a few cases. In most cases, in Esperance it rained so late that there was very little crop sown, which is probably an advantage because at least the inputs did not go in. Stock were removed very early in the piece—fortunately, while prices were still all right.

The drought has caused other problems as well. It has caused a shortage of water on farms. The Jerramungup shire—and there is another town, the name of which I cannot think of at the moment, but I will come to it later—has had to start carting water to its own town and to towns such as Ongerup. When I was visiting that town there was only about 10 to 12 days supply of water in the town dams. They would have had to start carting water initially from about 100 kilometres away, but that dam would have lasted only about a week, and then from 250 kilometres, either coming from Lake Grace or from Esperance at the other end. Esperance, of course, is reasonably short of water itself.

I do not know whether anyone spoke from your side, Mr Deputy President—and you are a Western Australian senator—but what I am telling you is that Western Australia is not totally devoid of drought, but fortunately is not in the same situation as the eastern states.

I might add that three-quarters of the wheat belt of Western Australia is affected and would have had below average rainfall. We can expect below average seasons, but I put on record that Western Australia is not having the season that a few people may think. With three-quarters of the wheat belt in the state affected, I believe that even Western Australia's wheat production will be down quite a bit this year compared to the average, let alone last year's figure. I will put on record also that, although a quarter of the wheat belt—that part towards the west coast—is having quite a good season, it will not make up for the three-quarters of the state that is not.

I believe that the government's package this afternoon, especially for the eastern states, has to be a good one. I believe that the Fraser government, in the final analysis, allocated some $360 million for the 1982 drought. This government so far, to my knowledge, has committed only $14 million, and I believe that what will be announced this afternoon will take that up to $100 million, which is far short of that $360 million that was allocated by the Fraser government.

We do not know when this drought is going to break. That is the big question. Taking the experience of 1982, it broke towards the end of March in the eastern states. But it does not mean that, when the drought breaks, the income starts coming in. It is generally when the next crop is planted, some seven or eight months later. So this government would have to be well ready to provide assistance up to the figure provided by the Fraser government in 1982. The Fraser government, having supplied that assistance, saw the benefit down the track. Farmers were still on their farms when the good years came and the people were able to remain in the country, not necessarily on the farms but in allied service industries, and receive the benefit.

If the government does a good job of this package this afternoon, then it can look forward to the benefits of it when the seasons turn around. The seasons will turn around. A good season generally follows a drought, or at least a better season. That is a self-evident fact. But if the government does the right thing and provides a good package, then it will get the benefit in time.

May I also compare the figure that has been allocated for drought to date with the amount given to ANL the other day—$50 million was not too hard to find. I hope the government is just as generous with the very hard situation caused by the drought in the eastern states.

I make a special appeal to the government on behalf of young people from the country who are doing university courses or other courses—that the assistance to be given in the package will assist them to at least finish their courses.

Statistics that I have read indicate that 80 per cent of those who break their attendance at a course never go back to finish it. They are astonishing figures; but they are correct—at least they were two years ago. Senator Crowley looks at me in amazement. I would like to know whether she has different figures. Mine indicate that of students who take a year or more off, 80 per cent do not complete their course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not true, Senator.

—That is not right? Senator Crowley may be able to give me some different figures but they are the ones I have. There is also the problem of destitute families in the country which have to be looked after so they can even put bread on the table. I support everything my colleagues have said, and look forward to the announcement of the package this afternoon.

—I will not take up too much of the chamber's time. I certainly support the previous speakers on the coalition side in their approach to this motion moved by the Western Australian Greens. I also think that it would have been better to have had this debate after the government's package had been announced rather than at this premature time, particularly on the effects of climate change as it affects the drought.

PARA.TAB: There have been many speeches so far on the effects of the drought on our nation. It is important to recognise that the whole of regional Australia is in that situation. It will suffer increasingly from the effects of the drought—not only the farmers, who are the hardest and most directly hit, but all those other people in rural and regional communities who rely on the incomes that farmers generate in the good times. Any package from the government, of necessity, must include consideration for small businessmen in rural and regional areas and for workers and others thrown out of their jobs because of the effects of the drought.

In many instances, farmers and small businessmen are simply no longer able to continue the employment of their employees, many of whom have worked with particular farmers or small businessmen all of their lives. They suffer the emotional tragedy of having to say to those people who have worked loyally in their business—a farm business or a town business—all of their lives, `Sorry, we just can't continue your employment.'

The effects of the drought are so widespread in regional communities. Some of my colleagues have mentioned the very real fear that whole towns and communities in regional Australia will simply have to shut down because once the farm income stops, the small businessmen cannot continue to operate; once the small businessmen are not there, their employees do not have jobs; and once farmers and small businessmen are not paying rates, councils find it very difficult to continue. Even though councils try to mop up some of the unemployed in rural and regional towns, their resources are very limited and they are not able to continue to do that. It is a real tragedy.

My colleagues, very appropriately, have mentioned the enormous effect on farmers and farm families. I simply wish to emphasise that the effects of the drought are more widespread—there are effects on small businesses in rural communities and towns, on workers and councils. In fact everyone has a very difficult time in an extreme drought.

As a Queensland senator, I have travelled in a lot of drought areas. The Liberal Party is very concerned. I know that Mr Taylor, the member for Groom, whose electorate is one of the worst hit, has a real concern for the ongoing viability and livelihood of many of the communities in the Darling Downs area. As I travel around Western Queensland, particularly in the Rockhampton area, I can see that the effects of the drought are horrific, not only in an economic sense but also in a personal and emotional way.

So I wish to associate myself with the comments made by my colleagues in relation to this matter. I will perhaps elaborate further on that point when the matter is discussed upon the announcement of the government's package for drought relief. On the motion before the chamber at the moment, I concur with my colleagues in thinking that it is perhaps premature. We will be dealing with it in the manner that my colleagues have indicated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I have the task now to comment on some of the arguments that have been made during this debate. I believe the discussion today has been very useful. Senator Sherry made some rather sideways comments with relation to the coal industry because of the impact that coal and the output of coal have on greenhouse gas emissions and climate change.

PARA.TAB: It is very important to get things a little in perspective. There has been quite a lot of discussion from the Greens and the Australian Democrats about the need to adjust such industries to the changing situation in the world, the need to have the economic smarts to realise the changes that are necessary and the need to realise also that industries that may be big in some senses may not be bringing Australia a great many benefits at the same time as they are imposing a great many environmental costs now and for the future. The reality is that Australia is being played as a pawn in a game by coal multinationals. Most of those companies are owned and controlled overseas. Very little of their profits are going into Australia. In terms of employment, it is not a big industry—and it is one we can afford to restructure.

I do not see people jumping up and down about the many more thousands of people who are losing their jobs as a result of such things as tariff reductions through GATT or the lead-up to GATT in industries such as the footwear, clothing and textile industries. I think that for credibility we would have to see equal concern for the many more people losing their jobs in other industries than are currently likely to have their jobs at risk in an industry like coal which does need readjustment for us to be able to meet our future commitments. We have also had quite a lot of discussion on the nature of proof. What proof do we have and what proof do we not have? What has come out a lot in this discussion is that there seems to be a lack of understanding about the nature of proof in the field of climatology. It is acknowledged in climatology that there is never any total proof. It is not like something we can put in a test tube and say, `Yes, that has happened on a certain number of occasions; therefore we can comfortably predict that it will happen given certain conditions.'

There is the problem that if we wait until we have absolute proof, it may well be too late. Very recently from the CSIRO we received information that the kinds of changes we are talking about involve a change of two to four per cent over a hundred years, when the world would normally be expected to move towards an ice age over a minimum of 10,000 to 15,000 years—perhaps up to 100,000 years.

Senator Brownhill talked about little dry periods. We are talking about some massive changes and the possibility of a very significant change that, as I said before, could be up to 15 per cent in areas with the most ice in the world. That would mean we would have massive increases in sea levels. That has not really come up in today's debate. We should think of the impact of those kinds of changes.

We are not talking about statements that are coming from a scattered number of scientists. The outcome of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has been mentioned on a number of occasions today. I would like to mention a couple of points from its statements. Its statement of 5 September is entitled `While Sceptics and Alarmists Square Off, the IPCC Forges Consensus'. This is the acknowledgment:
Geneva, September 1994—The climate change debate as it takes place through the media and other public fora is not always based on sound science.

SPEECH.PARA: The statement talks about the possibility for alarmists and sceptics, and it is very right to do so. But it also mentions:

PARA.TAB: The IPCC is an intergovernmental scientific and technical body consisting of a very small secretariat and a world wide network of 2,500 scientists and experts who are leaders in their fields.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not talking about a handful of people. To get this kind of consensus in this kind of scientific discussion is phenomenal. The statement also mentions:
Because carbon dioxide—
I include other greenhouse gases in this—
remains in the atmosphere for a long time, the IPCC had earlier concluded that, even if global emissions could be stabilised, atmospheric concentrations would continue to rise for at least 200 years.

This is not alarmist stuff, as I said. It is trying to get into contact with reality. We have also had a number of other statements today. Senator Brownhill mentioned, and he was right, that people are suffering now. But he also said that we cannot worry about what will happen 30 years down the track.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the moment we can't; we've got to look at things right at the moment.

—We do need to look at things right at the moment, and there is certainly agreement on that from the Greens and the Democrats. That has been well mentioned today. What we are saying is that, if we do not put this also in the context of the fundamental causes of climatic change, whatever happens today will serve only as a bandaid and we will not really be giving any long-term benefits to those people whom we are seeking to assist.
—I also quoted the cutbacks to CSIRO too.

—Exactly. Senator Coulter mentioned that a great deal of greenhouse gas is produced by intercountry air travel. It is true that any change in policies which means we have the ability to use less sea travel certainly will impact on the level of global greenhouse gases. Although some may be thinking of using aircraft for freight instead of using shipping, which is much better in terms of greenhouse gas production, in reality we may not even need to worry about this in the long-term because, according to global predictions, in 20 years time we will have basically run out of aviation gas. We seem to be forgetting that, too. Petroleum as a resource also has a finite period. So there are many reasons why we have to change the way we do business. We do not have to stop producing for our needs. What we emphasise and what the Democrats are emphasising today is that we need to do things smarter and differently in order to meet our needs.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to highlight that the whole drought question has wider physical implications than just those for agriculture. Scientists are currently working, especially in the Americas, on the consequences in terms of biological diversity; and that has been mentioned a few times today. With such a rapid change of climate, many species will become unsuited to their habitat. Plants cannot walk away and find better habitats, and natural movement is slow—far slower than climate change. As a consequence, a lot of plants may become extinct and there may be serious implications for forests, wetlands and other biomes.

In North America, it is thought, whole forests may simply die. Animals can walk, but there are real problems for animals that need a certain habitat. There are problems where animals exist in parks and biological islands with no corridors to possible new habitats. Many animal species may also be endangered. This would have all sorts of implications, including economic ones, especially for forestry.

I would like to say strongly that all of this—the emergency relief and the adjustment programs—is a consequence of human created climate change, or it would be seem that it is in line with what we are expecting from that. There are proposals to do something to stop such change. The government has shown little commitment to do anything about slowing or stopping the effects of greenhouse by addressing sources. It has not taken any conservative measures; it is talking about going and claiming economic disadvantage.

Part of the problem is that in reports on greenhouse such as the CRA report, the Industry Commission report and the ecologically sustainable development report there was never any value placed on the damage the greenhouse effect might cause. It was said that this was not quantifiable and, therefore, no value could be assigned—where there are no costs assigned to climate change, there are no benefits from stopping such change. This has been a fundamental distortion in the Australian calculations of the costs and benefits of greenhouse gas reduction, although even things that clearly had no cost implications anyway we could have examined; and they were not implemented.

I would like to note that we can at least begin to calculate a cost. So far this year the cost is likely to be about $3 billion, not including the cost of relief, the cost of fires resulting from drought conditions, the cost of possible loss of forests and other biological resources, the cost of land degradation due to farming under poor conditions, and the cost of adjustment and relief. All up, this year it may cost something closer to $5 billion or $6 billion. People should put that in their calculations.

People will argue that we are small producers on a global scale. True, but we are major producers of greenhouse gas on a per capita basis. We are somewhere in the top four. Two of the top five global producers of greenhouse emissions are our neighbours India and China. They use a small fraction per capita of the energy we do, and most of their emissions come from animals and swamps. If we want them to take any action, how can we think of going back to the convention and asking for an exemption because we think it would cost us something? People will laugh in our face; and if they do not take greenhouse seriously, we are well and truly down the tubes economically.

As a matter of urgency and rational action, we must do something for farmers if we want to have an agricultural industry left in 30 years time. We will need to do this regardless, because we have already been changing our climate. We do not want this problem to get worse and worse until we pass the stage where we have the ability to cope. We need to do something about stopping emissions globally. We need to get serious and do it soon.

We have just put in our national communication as required under the convention. It shows that we have done little and will not meet our targets. I say it is time for the government to come to terms with this issue and it must do so by February next year. It should be pushing for the convention to be shifted to a strong protocol at the framework convention meeting at that time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Crowley) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Migration Act 1958 and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Crowley) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum relating to the bill, and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to ensure that Australia's onshore refugee determination system is not open to the abuse of forum shopping by asylum seekers who have been denied refugee status by or who have access to protection in another country.

The bill will ensure that non-citizens covered by the Comprehensive Plan of Action for Indo-chinese refugees (CPA) or in relation to whom there is a safe third country, should not be able to apply for a protection visa and, in some cases, any other visa. An immediate example is that of people for whom there is a safe third country who have been assessed by a refugee determination process which is accepted by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR). Under this bill such people will not be entitled to opt for another assessment under Australian processes.

These amendments to the Migration Act are being introduced following the arrival in Australia of 17 Vietnamese people on a boat codenamed "Vagabond" from a refugee holding centre in Galang, Indonesia. These people, who had been rejected as refugees in Indonesia by a refugee determination process approved by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, sought to have another assessment of their cases conducted by Australia. They have, in effect, forum-shopped in the expectation of obtaining the outcome they were seeking through the refugee determination process in Australia.

Under current domestic law there is no option but to allow such arrivals access to Australia's refugee determination process, which we operate as a party to the 1951 UN Convention and the 1967 Protocol relating to the status of refugees. Consequently, this access was granted, despite requests from the UNHCR and the Indonesian Government not to process the applicants but to return them immediately to Galang. The UNHCR undertook to examine any fresh claims or evidence put forward by the Vagabond arrivals following their return to Indonesia. If the legislation introduced today had existed at the time that the Vagabond landed we would have been able to comply with these requests.

In the event, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, after examining all claims, decided not to grant refugee status to 14 of the 17 Vagabond arrivals. Three were found to be refugees on the basis of new information. Had this information been available to the UNHCR the further refugee claims of these three people would have been examined by them.

In view of the prejudice to our international relations that would have arisen from any change in the decisions refusing the 14 Vagabond applicants refugee status, the Minister issued conclusive certificates denying them access to the Refugee Review Tribunal.

It is worth reviewing the history of this issue in the region, which provides context for the bill. Until 1989, the international response to the problem of Indo-Chinese asylum seekers had been a combination of temporary asylum in countries in the region, and international resettlement. Increasingly, the reasons given by those fleeing related to poverty, rather than persecution. In 1989, the UNHCR-sponsored CPA, in which Australia has been a major participant, constituted a new framework to safeguard the protection of refugees. Under the CPA, those screened in as refugees are offered third country resettlement. Those screened out are required to return to Vietnam under arrangements monitored by the UNHCR. The CPA also provides a framework for orderly migration from Vietnam.

A crucial part of the CPA has been the establishment of refugee status determination procedures in countries of first asylum such as Indonesia. These processes are conducted in association with the UNHCR and according to the UN Convention definition of "refugee". They include both primary and secondary levels of assessment. The 17 Vietnamese boat people who arrived in Broome on 7 July, 1994 had been assessed under these UNHCR sponsored processes in Indonesia and had been found not to be refugees.

From July 1989 to July 1994, Australia has resettled 17,600 Vietnamese and Laotian refugees under the CPA, with about 1,400 expected to arrive during 1994-95. Our effort has been, and continues to be exemplary.

A continuation of the present Australian law, where anyone who can get into a boat in Galang or other camps in South East Asia and sail to Australia is entitled to another assessment of their refugee status would severely undermine the whole CPA process and weaken the credibility of all such comprehensive international approaches. If there is to be no difference in the way genuine refugees and those assessed to be economic migrants are treated, protection for those in real need will be seriously weakened, and the genuine refugee pushed aside by the forum shopper.

In July, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs stated the Government's firm intention to act urgently when Parliament resumed to ensure that Australia's policies and refugee procedures are brought into line with UNHCR's concerns. This bill puts this resolve into effect. The seriousness of the potential undermining of the CPA is highlighted by the arrival in Australia of a second boat of Vietnamese people from Galang on 9 September and the recent interception of a third boat by Indonesian authorities which was heading from Galang to Australia. As foreshadowed by the Minister on 29 August, the bill will cover the period from 1 September onwards, and so, in effect will deny the second, and any subsequent boats, the chance to contribute further to the breakdown of the CPA.

While initiated because of events relating to the CPA, the bill also enables Australia to identify safe third countries which will allow for the return to those countries of any asylum seekers who could have availed themselves or did avail themselves of an equitable refugee assessment process or protection in those countries, or for whom effective protection is available in those countries.

In accordance with our obligations under international law, countries with whom we enter into safe third country agreements would need to observe the principle of non-refoulement of refugees and internationally accepted minimum standards of human rights. The bill requires the Minister to make a statement to the Parliament after a particular safe country is prescribed by the regulations, about the country's compliance with relevant international law concerning the protection of persons seeking asylum and relevant human rights standards. Furthermore the formal mechanism for designating Safe Third Countries by way of Regulations will afford the Parliament the opportunity to scrutinise that designation.

Persons who have the necessary connection with a safe third country will not be permitted to apply for a protection visa in Australia. Further, those persons who have not been immigration cleared will not be permitted to apply for any other form of visa: they will be detained and removed from Australia. To ensure there are not harsh or unintended results the bill contains two key safeguards. The first is to exempt coverage of persons by the legislation through the making of a regulation, for example where conditions in the country of origin have changed to the extent that temporary asylum in Australia is the most appropriate form of response to their situation. And secondly in relation to individuals, the bill provides a non-compellable power for the Minister to set aside the operation of the safe third country provisions to allow an application to be made.

The bill requires the mandatory removal of people covered by the amendment who have not been immigration cleared, and of people who, having been immigration cleared, are in detention and have not made a valid application for any other visa that can be granted in the migration zone.

Australia is a staunch supporter of UNHCR's massive efforts throughout the world to assist genuine refugees, and the imaginative and enlightened adoption by countries in our region of the comprehensive solution of the CPA. It is because of this that the Government regards this legislation as a crucial defence of proper, equitable and humane processes. To do less undermines the CPA in what is its most difficult period, following the screening of all in the camps and the requirement to return those found not to be refugees, which now constitutes almost all of the population of the camps. Not to make the changes would also undermine the integrity of, and public support for, Australia's own refugee determination system.

In an era when on-shore refugee determination systems in most asylum countries are being modified to refocus attention on convention refugees and to limit the impact of irregular migration upon the ability to offer protection to those who genuinely need it, Australia can not afford to be left behind. It is essential that our determination system keep pace with developments in other asylum countries and continue to enable Australia to honour its international obligations to refugees.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the bill.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Panizza) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 1093, standing in my name and relating to the establishment of a select committee on ABC management and operations, be taken as formal.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the contingent notice of motion standing in my name, I move:
