PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chamarette moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 1093 standing in the name of Senator Chamarette for this day, relating to the establishment of a select committee on ABC management and operations.

SPEECH.PARA: I will be very brief and I will not go into the content of the motion. The reason why I am seeking to suspend standing orders is that I do not see any reason to wait and to defer this to a later time for two reasons. Firstly, the government has indicated that it will not give formality to the motion. Secondly, the government traditionally does not support formal motions that relate to the formation of Senate select committees. That is all I will say because I do not wish to delay the Senate and I would like to go on to the substantive matters in the motion. I believe there is support for suspending the standing orders and proceeding to the substantive matter of the referral to a Senate select committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —We welcome the initiative. We think it is important to canvass all of those issues that have been specified. We start from the proposition that we are very much in favour of a strong, fearlessly independent, quality alternative to the commercial broadcasting sector. We want to see the ABC given a clear sense of direction, and not left to wonder in which direction it really ought to be going—with the government constantly backgrounding the media about its levels of dissatisfaction but not being prepared to debate the matters in public. In those circumstances, this will do a great deal to clear the air and the ABC will emerge much stronger, much better focused and much better supported by the Australian public.

—The government opposes this motion for the suspension of standing orders so that we can move right along into the substance of an equally ill-timed and unnecessary debate. Senator Chamarette says things such as, `The government always opposes motions being formal if they're about establishing Senate select committees.' I do not have the numbers here, but that is a dreadful claim and she knows it. It is absolutely no justification for the suspension of standing orders at all. It is an interesting distraction, but absolutely no justification for anything. Even if it were true, what justification would that be to suspend standing orders? None at all.

PARA.TAB: If she is arguing about the suspension of standing orders, at least she might have given us some arguments about why they should be suspended and why this debate effectively has to be brought on today and not tomorrow, as I understand was the fairly large corridor agreement. The state of urgency around this places comes and goes like a draught or a banging door. Again, I find that good reason for why there is absolutely no justification for the suspension of standing orders in this place today. The substantive argument that Senator Chamarette wants to debate is the formation of a committee, as Senator Alston alluded to, to trawl across territory that has been already trampled across.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—Of course Senator Alston is going to say no, shake his head in earnest disbelief and all of those sorts of things—and no smiling, because he could give away the serious manner in which he approaches this debate. He knows full well that these issues have been more than extensively canvassed. He knows that there is already an inquiry established within the ABC. There is absolutely no justification for this inquiry and there is absolutely no justification for the suspension of standing orders to proceed to argue the position and set about establishing it.

PARA.TAB: I know how the numbers fall in this place. I could take quite a few more minutes of the Senate's time in arguing against the motion and filling in time—although there has been a fair amount of filler today—but all I will say for the record is that Senator Chamarette has not advanced one reasonable argument about why there should be a suspension of standing orders. She knows she has the numbers and so she said, `I don't have to waste the Senate's time.' I believe that discredits this Senate.

If she ever wants to go through the motions, even when she has the numbers stitched up, she should at least do the Senate the honour of giving us some real reasons for why we should suspend standing orders. It is a pathetic performance by Senator Chamarette and no justification could possibly be argued on what she has proposed. We all know that Senator Alston is going through the motions too. Again, there was no argument for the suspension of standing orders. If either Senator Chamarette or Senator Alston ever talk to me about having more respect for the Senate, I will remind them of this very puerile performance today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Chamarette) agreed to:

That General Business notice of motion No. 1093 standing in the name of Senator Chamarette for this day, relating to the establishment of a select committee on ABC management and operations, may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: (1)That, in light of:

TAB.TAB: (a)the failure of Australian Television International to penetrate its target markets in Asia, with a resultant waste of scarce funds otherwise earmarked for maintenance of quality national broadcasting;
(b)controversial proposals to abolish regional Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) TV News, advocated with great vigour by ABC Management, and rejected by the ABC Board;
(c)recent evidence that ABC program sponsorship rules may have been significantly and deliberately breached in a number of ABC co-productions that have gone to air;
(d)the continuing high level of resignations and departures from the ABC of senior, experienced broadcasting managers and program makers;

(e)the controversy surrounding appointments to the Board of the ABC, including concerns that individual merit and potential contribution to the policy direction, public standing and the political independence of the ABC are no longer the sole criteria for such appointments; and
(f)continuing public concern about the nature and extent of the ABC's involvement in commercial activities;

PARA.TAB: a select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on ABC Management and Operations, be appointed to inquire into and report, on or before 1 March 1995, on the following matters with respect to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation:

TAB.TAB: (i)whether the matters referred to in paragraphs 1(a) to (f) are symptoms of a deep-seated problem within the board, management and organisation of the ABC, and, if so,
(ii)whether this problem arises from dysfunction or conflict between:

PARA.TAB: (A)the current operational goals and direction of the ABC, and the corporation's legislative charter and the board's duties, and

(B)the composition of the board, or part of it, and the management, or part of it, in implementing the charter or discharging the duties to achieve and reflect appropriate policy direction, public standing and political independence.
(2)That the committee consist of seven senators, as follows:

TAB.TAB: (a)two nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b)three nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(c)one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats; and
(d)one nominated by the Greens (WA) or Senator Harradine.

PARA.TAB: (3)That the committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4)That:

TAB.TAB: (a)the chair of the committee be elected by the members of the committee from the members nominated by the Leader of the Opposition;
(b)in the absence of agreement on the selection of a chair, duly notified to the President, the allocation of the chair be determined by the Senate;
(c)the deputy chair of the committee be appointed by the chair from the members of the committee immediately after the election of the chair;
(d)the deputy chair act as chair when there is no chair or the chair is not present at a meeting; and
(e)in the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chair, or the deputy chair when acting as chair, have a casting vote.

PARA.TAB: (5)That the quorum of the committee be four members.

(6)That the committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place and to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

(7)That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the Senators appointed to the subcommittee.

(8)That, without limiting its power to pass procedural or other resolutions that are not inconsistent with this paragraph or these terms of reference, the committee observe the following procedures, namely, that:
Submissions and calling of witnesses

TAB.TAB: (a)as a general principle, evidence be invited in the first instance in the form of written submissions and following examination of submissions, the committee decide which witnesses are to be called for examination;

(b)subject to any contrary order in relation to a particular submission, the submission to the committee by a person of a statement relating to the inquiry be deemed to be the giving of evidence before the committee by that person in accordance with that statement;

PARA.TAB: Evidence

TAB.TAB: (c)evidence be heard in public session except in instances where the committee or a subcommittee resolves to hear evidence in camera;

PARA.TAB: Statements to the media

TAB.TAB: (d)the chair be authorised to make statements to the media on behalf of the committee concerning its activities;

PARA.TAB: Broadcasts and re-broadcasts of public proceedings

TAB.TAB: (e)the recording, broadcasting and re-broadcasting of public proceedings is authorised in accordance with the rules contained in the order of the Senate of 23 August 1990, as varied by the Senate from time to time, concerning the broadcasting of committee proceedings;

PARA.TAB: Release of evidence and documents

TAB.TAB: (f)the secretary is authorised to supply for correction, copies of proof reports of both public and in camera proceedings to the witnesses whose evidence appears in those reports;
(g)subject to any contrary order in relation to a particular submission, each document submitted to the committee be published; and

PARA.TAB: Adverse Evidence

TAB.TAB: (h)subject to any contrary order, evidence which adversely reflects on a person be forwarded to that person inviting their response.

PARA.TAB: (9)That:

TAB.TAB: (a)the terms of reference of the inquiry be appropriately advertised in the media; and
(b)written submissions be sought and examined by the committee and oral evidence be heard, including oral evidence from the authors of the most important submissions.

PARA.TAB: (10)That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee, with the approval of the President.
(11)That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(12)That the committee may report from time to time its proceedings and evidence taken or any interim conclusions or recommendations arising from its inquiry, and may make regular reports on the progress of its proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say at the outset that I, the Greens (WA) and the Greens in general are strong supporters of the ABC. We very much value the institution of a national public broadcaster and we see this reference as in no way an attack on the ABC or on the institution of a national public broadcaster.

PARA.TAB: However, there has been a growing number of instances over the past year where concern has been expressed about, firstly, the way in which the ABC has been managed; secondly, whether some of its activities exceed its charter—and I refer to the ATV Asian and regional focus rather than the national focus as one example; and, thirdly, how management reaches its decisions.

If I were asked about the many subclauses in this motion relating to this reference, then I would like to say that none of paragraphs (a) to (f) is intended, in our view, to be singled out. We do not want to overemphasise any particular area. We are just listing the numerous concerns that have been gradually mounting regarding the ABC. The first concern is about Australian Television International, its penetration of target markets in Asia and the usage of its funding that may well be disadvantaging the maintenance of quality national broadcasting.

There has been grave concern in the community—particularly in Western Australia and the other regional areas—regarding the proposal to abolish regional TV news programs and the increasing centralisation of the process on a national basis. The most recent indicator was the evidence that ABC program sponsorship rules may have been significantly and deliberately breached in a number of ABC co-productions that have gone to air.

I believe that the inclusion of this matter in a rationale for an inquiry does not pre-empt the Palmer inquiry, but is complementary to it. If this committee is set up and has to report back on 1 March 1995, there is no difficulty in delaying hearings in relation to that particular matter referred to in section (1)(c) of my motion. Those hearings could be deferred until the completion of the Palmer inquiry. We could draw any valuable reflections and results from that inquiry into the final consideration of the committee.

There has been a continuing high level of resignations and departures by senior experienced broadcasting managers and program makers from the ABC. Whilst I would not want any particular facet to be overemphasised, that matter has contributed substantially to the Greens' concern which has brought us to this point. The chamber may well remember that in June I proposed a select committee on possible political influence in personnel matters in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. I took that action as a result of being contacted by the Queensland Greens, who were concerned that there was a need for a serious investigation of some matters occurring in that state.

I believe that my involvement in the whistleblowers committee also assisted me in that regard. When we had committee hearings in Queensland it was quite apparent that there were serious problems in relation to allegations, at the very least, regarding the media and the state government. It is in the public interest that those concerns be raised under the auspices of a parliamentary committee. I believe that any serious allegations of political influence in our national public broadcaster deserve careful examination. They are as important as any other matters that have been raised in this chamber.

There were concerns that dismissals and resignations of journalists and program management staff in Queensland may have been as a result of government or other pressure, or have been caused by staff discontent with perceptions of such pressure. It is vital for freedom of expression in Australia that the national broadcaster not only be free of such pressures and allegations, but is seen to be free of them. Evidence of such pressures and influences is notoriously difficult to uncover without access to information and without the power of an independent and formal inquiry. For that reason, I believe that those who have expressed concern but who may have been in fear of the consequences of their speaking out will have one of the most beneficial aspects of the Senate process—a Senate committee—to assist them. They will be able to appear in-confidence or on the public record with information that may be of vital importance.

Controversies have been raised surrounding appointments to the ABC board. There have been concerns that individual merit and potential contribution to the policy direction, public standing and political independence of the ABC were no longer the sole criteria for appointments. That concern deserves to be addressed. There is increasing and continuing public concern about the nature and extent of the ABC's involvement in commercial activities.

Whilst any one of these concerns may have merited an inquiry in its own right, each of them could have been accused of being some sort of witch-hunt. However, I believe that we are doing it in a constructive and positive way by adopting this method. We are not overemphasising any of these matters. We are not engaged in a trawling exercise, as the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) implied in her comments. We see it as a positive step to clear the air regarding the ABC—and the air waves, I might add—and to ensure that the great institution of the ABC will continue into the next century.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I continue my series of speeches on the advent in Australia of the information superhighway. I have spoken in a number of other matters of public interest speeches about my recent trip to the United States and the information superhighway coming, ready or not. The metaphor is that the information superhighway is a complex web of network communications connections. We have developing in America—and, indeed, starting to develop in Australia—an optic fibre superhighway which is coming to link telephone, television and computers, and to provide a whole range of broadband services. The implication for Australian industry, and in particular for Australian society, is massive. The advent of this superhighway will impact upon the home, education, the workplace and health care delivery.

PARA.TAB: Today I want to focus on the implications for this parliament and this federal government, and on the regulatory regime that is needed to focus and shape the development of this new information age. Around the world, governments are acting to do this, but unfortunately this government is very slow to act on this matter. It has a major inquiry going on at this time, and that is fine; but in my experience overseas I saw many examples of governments, particularly those of different states in the United States, not just having inquiries but acting and putting plans into place, and having systems developed.

In the case of North Carolina, as they build up their public infrastructure network, by the year 2000 every home will be within one hour's drive of one of these major nodes of the information superhighway. In Japan there is the Japanese Telecommunications Council, which in a recent report to the government entitled Reforms towards the intellectually creative society of 21st century recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: that the regulatory regime will need reform to accommodate the convergence of telecommunications and broadcasting.

So the Japanese are heading well down the track. The government needs to respond very quickly in Australia, because the technology and the services are evolving so rapidly. We have some businesses taking advantage of this information superhighway already, but if the government does not get its regulatory framework right there are problems and dangers with the way this is developing.

PARA.TAB: We have mega-corporations emerging to take advantage of this new era. We have the Packer-Murdoch-Optus-Continental Cable consortium—PMOC, as it is called. As these companies converge, and as the technologies converge, they will create enormous economic power in the hands of a few. On the other side of this duopoly is Telecom, which is also linking in with a number of companies. These companies have had a little bit of a hiccup with some of their developments, but I am sure they will get back on track again.

What we have evolving in this country—unfortunately, like many other industries—is a massive duopoly that not only controls the means of communication but also has enormous control over the products that travel on that communications network. With the concerns with monopoly power and duopoly power that we have always had in this country, a new era is developing, and the government is just sitting on its hands and letting it develop. It does not have a regulatory framework for this and, indeed, it does not really have a policy to counter this.

To show honourable senators where we are going as these mega-corporations develop, I quote from the corporation president of US Bell Atlantic, James Cullen. He was involved in putting together one of these mega-corporations initially. It involved Bell Atlantic and it involved some of the big databases, particularly the communications companies and the movie studios. That particular one was set up and then fell apart, but a whole range of others have developed since. He had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . within five years telecommunication industry distinctions will blur and we'll just have a series of companies using a variety of technologies.

When I was in America, I discovered that Washington is trying to struggle with the issues that have been raised and that it is trying to move along as quickly as possible a suitable regulatory framework for this. The leader in this issue is Al Gore, the US Vice-President. He has been talking about it for 10 years. He quite frequently appears on national television to talk about his plan for the information superhighway. He has put out a challenge to US industry to connect all of the public institutions in America—all schools, universities, major business houses and perhaps government departments—by the year 2000. Given that it is variable across the states, some of the states have taken up this challenge with a vengeance. In fact, North Carolina plans to do that by the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: The piece of legislation that the US government is working with is the communications act of—wait for it—1934. That act is a little behind the current state of technology but that is the act that is in place. Members of both the US Senate and the Congress are working hard to bring together an act that will basically deregulate the industry and allow companies to carry the services and also provide services. The US is coming up with a framework and it is really getting into things in this area. However, the Australian government is being very slow on this.

One thing that the government has to look at, apart from the companies that are going to provide a lot of the services, is what is happening in the layout of the information superhighway. There are 1.8 million kilometres of optic fibre cable both in and between Sydney and Melbourne, and that is growing. Telstra will be putting broadband fibre optic and coaxial cable past 1.1 million houses by 1996. Optus and Continental Cablevision are rolling out their network to reach two million homes within four years.

Their network is being rolled out in some very imaginative ways: rather than digging trenches in the ground, in some parts of Sydney their cable will run along the electricity network. This cable can be run along with electricity wires—there are no rights of way, poles do not have to be built or anything like that. The network that is there is what is used. The Americans are also doing this. It is certainly a very imaginative way of rolling out this information superhighway at a very rapid rate. Not only will this network link Australia, and link businesses in Australia, but it will also very effectively link us to the rest of the world.

The Internet system, which is a series of databases—30,000, in fact—has been increasingly linking up across America and the rest of the world. That system is growing at a rate of eight per cent annually. In Australia we are well placed with the Aarnet system, which goes across the universities and research institutes. There are a whole lot of groups linking up to our version of the Internet system. The traffic in Australia is growing rapidly. We are now the fourth largest users of Internet worldwide. So the capacity and the usage is starting to develop here, but what is not developing here is this government's policies to properly regulate and develop this particular area.

Early in 1994 there were signs of a whole range of new developments that could increase access to the information superhighway and the products on it. New software being released will enable teleconferencing and videoconferencing from ordinary desktop PC workstations. Once this is widely known, it will be rapidly taken up. Public debate in this country is lagging on the issues that I have raised.

The thing that struck me when I was in America was that when I turned on the TV or the radio I frequently heard people debating these issues. Issues such as how this new information age was going to change the total industrial structure of the country over the next 50 years, what the government should be doing and how businesses could take better advantage of what was developing were discussed. I find very little evidence of that sort of discussion occurring in Australia.

We hear in the academic bodies some debate; we hear in the government some debate; but out there, in the broader public consciousness, this issue is not being debated. There are huge ramifications for every individual in Australia because this will affect the whole way their lives develop—in terms of entertainment, in terms of work and in terms of the way they live. The government's main think-tank on it is the Broadband Services Expert Group and that group is developing the main policy response to the government at this time. So in this bit of a limbo land, other countries have theirs up and running; we are still thinking about it.

The group was set up on 8 December 1993 and has to report at the end of this year. It is chaired by the Australian Broadcasting Authority Chair, Brian Johns. The interim report was released in July and it does lay down some fundamental conditions for regulatory action and legislation by the parliament. So there is a start. Page 19 of the interim report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Broadband Services Expert Group believes the benefits of a broadband network will be maximised if non discriminatory access is available to all service provider companies.

With what I have just said about the development of duopolies and mega-corporations, it is absolutely crucial in the government's policy that it allows smaller companies easier access onto this information superhighway. What we do not want is two mega-companies controlling access onto the information superhighway, having a lot of the products and then cutting out other groups. It must be open access and that is one of the major principles.

PARA.TAB: But where is the government's policy on this? The Minister for Communications and the Arts, Mr Lee, seems to be sitting on his hands and he is not tackling the really big issues that the development of the information superhighway throws up. If he does not do this quickly, Australians will be the losers. We could lose services potentially worth billions of dollars because, although the information superhighway opens up the opportunity for a whole range of new products, they may not be necessarily Australian products. They could be overseas products in a big way. If we do not get our own products, if the overseas products come on, the people overseas are going to be making the money, not Australians. That will have massive implications for our overseas debt as we import more down the information superhighway.

The way in which the government is actually reacting on this was best summed up by Barry Jones in his book Sleepers, Wake! in 1983. The sleepers are still fast asleep on this issue despite the efforts of Barry Jones. On the ABC, on 12 July this year, he summed up the way the government reacted when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We tend to react to things; we tend to stumble into things . . . we say: Oh really, we ought to have a policy response to that. But we don't anticipate the changes, we react to them.

That is exactly what is happening in this area at the moment. Our media and telecommunications laws need urgent reform. A single industry law for TV, radio, computers and telephones is urgently needed. We have the development of these consortiums that I mentioned earlier, making the industrial structure of Australia even more concentrated. Not only economic power is being concentrated; political power is also being concentrated. Overseas governments have shown they are concerned with this problem and they are prepared to act. We call, for the sake of Australian industry and the future of this communications industry, for the government to act now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I rise to pay tribute to Libby Slater who died on 2 September at the young age of 37. The announcement of her untimely death from pneumonia, following a flu virus, came as a profound shock to everyone who knew her. Libby Slater was a greatly respected lawyer, teacher and author, not only in Australia but also in the international realm of law. Without a doubt, she was one of Australia's leading superannuation experts. Libby was also a leading expert in tax law. I believe that her enormous professional achievements, in such a short lifetime, must be admired, respected and acknowledged by the Senate.

PARA.TAB: She was a partner with the law firm Mallesons Stephen Jaques in Sydney where she had worked since 1983. She wrote numerous authoritative articles and was a member of the editorial board of Butterworth's Superannuation Bulletin. As an author, Libby Slater wrote a definitive and landmark text on surplus problems for superannuation funds. This text has been extensively used since its publication as an authority on the issues of surplus. In fact, the book raised for the first time issues relating to surplus distribution when adventurous things were being done with surpluses in relation to superannuation without regard to the legal issues.

Apart from all these achievements, Libby was a lecturer in superannuation in the Master of Law course at Sydney University. She was a highly articulate and unassuming woman. She was a clear thinker and had a gift for explaining complex issues in a simple way that many others are unable to achieve.

Libby appeared before the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation on numerous occasions as a witness representing the Law Council of New South Wales. Without doubt, she was perhaps the most prized witness the committee had the privilege of hearing. She provided the committee with invaluable assistance, for example, on the SIS legislation and the policy framework for superannuation legislation. In fact, the members of the committee were struck by her frankness, candour and knowledge as a witness.

Aside from her professional life, Libby was a wife and mother of two young children. She carefully balanced her professional life with her family commitments. It was not uncommon for Libby to bring her children to conferences.

Libby will be sadly missed and her passing will leave a void in the superannuation industry. She has had a profound influence on the present and future state of superannuation in Australia and for this legacy we must all be thankful.

To mark her great contribution to superannuation law, the Law Council of Australia will name the prize it gives to its highest achieving student in the legal subject of the superannuation administration diploma conducted by ASFA and the Macquarie University after Libby Slater. I believe this tribute is a sign of the great respect with which she was held by her peers.

Libby is survived by her husband Michael and two children. To them I extend my sincere condolences. Libby's passing is a great loss not only to her family but also to her clients, her colleagues, the superannuation industry and the parliamentary committee system. I thank the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate representing the Attorney-General. I refer to the scathing remarks by Perth District Court Judge Nigel Clark that there was a `strong whiff of corruption' around the conduct of former deputy premier David Parker's acceptance of certain large donations. He went on to say that Parker's thefts took place `when the elders of the ALP espoused the precept that electoral victory was an end to justify the means' and that `the rank and file who devote themselves selflessly to fundraising will be discouraged if the guardians of the monies raised plunder them'. In light of the statement by the Minister for Administrative Services, Frank Walker, yesterday that a payment to a politician which is unrelated to an election is not something that should be included in an electoral return, is not this contemptuous, arrogant government really thumbing its nose at an electoral reform designed to stop this type of fraud?

—I will ignore the political static associated with that particular question and the feigned indignation and synthetic anger that is so characteristic of this otherwise very wimpish character opposite and deal simply with the substantive points in issue. I am advised that the Commonwealth Electoral Act does make a distinction between gifts made to a candidate in a private capacity for personal use and gifts made to a candidate for purposes related to a Commonwealth election.

PARA.TAB: Gifts made to a candidate in a private capacity must be disclosed if used solely or substantially for a political purpose. Gifts below certain thresholds need not be disclosed in any circumstances. The act was amended in 1992, as honourable senators will recall, to require third parties to disclose gifts made to candidates or parties. Where a gift is disclosed by a third party, failure by a candidate or his party to acknowledge or account for that gift will automatically lead to the Australian Electoral Commission investigating the matter.

The matters referred to by Senator Hill in the context of the Parker case in Western Australia have absolutely nothing to do with the federal election. In that context I have absolutely nothing more to say about the particular circumstances of that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When the party pays a candidate's gambling debts or pays for a candidate's holiday post-election, as is apparently the practice of the ALP in Western Australia, is the minister in fact arguing that that is a payment for personal interests of the candidate and not a payment for public interests in the election?
—I am not obliged to give kerbstone legal opinions on this or any other matter, and I do not propose to do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. Is the minister aware of an article in today's Australian Financial Review detailing the impact of growth in manufacturing exports upon the restoration of full employment in Australia? This report is based upon a study undertaken by the Centre for Strategic Economic Studies entitled, `The rebirth of Australian industry'. Is the minister aware that this research study suggests that manufacturing export growth rates could be sustained at five per cent per annum which would have a substantial impact on job growth? What action will the government take to ensure that growth rates for the manufacturing export sector are increased?

—I thank Senator Carr for his question, and certainly note that he has had a long-term interest in industry development in Australia. The report that he refers to was officially released today here in Canberra. The government is very pleased with the outcome of this report which, as Senator Carr said, is entitled, `The rebirth of Australian industry' by the Victorian-based Centre for Strategic Economic Studies.

PARA.TAB: The report, which I commend to all senators, tells a very good news story for Australian manufacturing. The research focuses on our performance in producing and exporting elaborately transformed manufactures, the so-called ETMs. ETMs include products like motor vehicles, ships, pharmaceuticals, sophisticated machinery and computer and communications equipment. Since 1985 growth in Australian exports of ETMs has averaged 14.5 per cent per annum after the previous decade or more showed almost no growth at all.

The most recent statistics from the ABS show that in the past few years growth has been closer to 20 per cent than to 14 per cent. This compares with the average annual growth rate of less than two per cent in the first half of the 1980s. But, more importantly, the story is also good news when we compare ourselves with the performance of our competitors. While there has been an acceleration of growth in world exports of ETMs, Australian exports of ETMs have grown faster; that is, the pie is getting bigger and we are gaining a bigger share of the bigger pie.

These outcomes did not happen by accident. The report recognises the success of this government's industry policies. Again I commend the report, particularly to senators opposite, so they may see how the government's policies over the past decade have contributed to the growth of ETMs. I want to say that we are now building on that, and particularly on the policies announced in the Working Nation statement of May this year which provided a number of initiatives that encourage innovation and management; provided incentives to increase the uptake of technology; ensured that firms, particularly small- and medium-sized firms, have access to finance to underpin their growth; and stimulate strategic partnerships with industry through enterprise networking. While these are specific policies in the industry statement Working Nation, we will certainly aim, through the trade policies that Senator McMullan is in charge of, to ensure that we continue to look at increasing opportunities opening up for Australian industry in overseas markets.

The author of the report suggests that the continued improvement in ETM exports could accelerate the fall of unemployment in Australia before the year 2001. It will do so by boosting the growth of GDP to the order of five per cent per year through to the end of the decade. The most important quote from the report says that at the moment we have an ETM export-import ratio of 30 per cent. If that grows, as it is believed it will, to 50 per cent by the year 2001, then, to quote from the report, it `would imply a rate of growth permitted under the balance of payments constraint of 1.5 to two percentage points per annum higher than if the present ratio was maintained. This implies that Australia could achieve economic growth in the order of five per cent per annum over this period'. The achievement of a growth rate of five per cent per annum over the period until 2001 would require successful policies in the areas outlined in the Working Nation statement. This report shows that this government has got it right for the last decade in establishing ETMs. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister inform the Senate whether there is any evidence of any more general industry and community recognition of the factors behind these very significant results released in the report today?

—Yes. In the report itself, as I have already said, there is plenty of evidence to show that the government's policies in the elaborately transformed manufactures area of our industries have been very successful. I also want to draw attention to a poll that appears in today's Australian under the heading `Labor leads on all issues.' The issues are listed as to who would do better on unemployment—

—I take a point of order, Mr President. This poll has nothing whatsoever to do with the minister's administrative functions, and he should be required to answer within the standing orders in the same way as we are all obliged to comply with those orders.

—In the sense that Senator Schacht is the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, most of his answer has certainly been relevant. I think he is digressing a bit now, and I would urge him to get back to the point.

—As I mentioned in the first answer to this question, in every category involved with the balance of payments, taxation, inflation and interest rates—all of those issues that are germane to this report—the Labor Party is seen by the general public as being able to perform better than the opposition. That says it all. We are recognised by the public as being able to perform, while the opposition is not recognised as having any sort of credible policy in any of these areas.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. The minister would be aware that Australian rugby league is fast falling into disrepute following the increasing number of allegations circulating in the community—and confirmed by league hero Benny Elias—which suggest that matches are being fixed and that details of the league's best and fairest player were leaked prior to the formal announcement. Given that half a million dollars will be wagered on this weekend's grand final between the Canberra Raiders and Canterbury, can the minister advise the Senate what action the government has undertaken to alleviate the concern that this national and international sport may not be clean? Will the minister initiate a probing drugs in sport style inquiry into rugby league match fixing?

—I read a report in the newspaper this morning which said that inquiries into the leaking of the name of the rugby league Rothmans Medal winner had found that there was no basis to the allegations that had been made. I am sure that Senator McGauran and other honourable senators would have read that same report in the newspaper. I am also aware that investigations are being undertaken by appropriate authorities, the New South Wales police, into certain allegations—and I stress the word `allegations'—that have been made in relation to match fixing in New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: As I understand it, that is the status of this matter—the allegations have been made and investigations are being undertaken. As the federal minister for sport, I have had no evidence presented to me of any allegations at all in relation to the sport of rugby league in Australia. If evidence was presented, I would take the appropriate course of action. I have no reason to believe that the investigations that are being undertaken by the appropriate authorities into these matters have not been done in the most thorough manner. Unless or until those particular investigations are complete, I believe that it is not appropriate for me to comment further on them publicly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister assure the Senate that the rugby league grand final is not fixed for Canterbury to win this Sunday?

—I do not think it is a humorous thing to bring sports into disrepute in this chamber in this way. I do not think the opposition, in raising this issue in this way, will win any friends in the Australian community. I do not believe that any reasonable or fair-minded Australian believes that the rugby league grand final, or any other sporting event of that status in our community, is fixed. I believe that the question that Senator McGauran has asked is preposterous, and it ought to be treated with the absolute contempt it deserves. Rugby league is a popular sport. It is a well-administered sport in this country, and it is a sport that has the confidence of the Australian people. (Time expired)

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Norway led by the President of the Storting, Mrs Kirsti Grondahl. On behalf of honourable senators, I take great pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and hope that your stay in Australia will be both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite President Grondahl to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

EMPHASIS.TAB: President Grondahl was thereupon seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I might note in prefacing my question that perhaps the Victorian interest in rugby league stems from the Western Australian dominance of the AFL. The minister would be aware that a local government poll in Mandurah, Western Australia, resulted in a strong no vote against a proposed canal development in the internationally important Creery Wetland. What action is the minister able to take to ensure that the decision of the local community is implemented and that this valuable wetland is protected for all time?

—There was a poll conducted by the Mandurah City Council and that poll, in its conduct, jointly involved the council and the developer of the proposed canal estate to determine the level of support in the community for this development proposal. I can report to the Senate that the residents of Mandurah voted overwhelmingly against Cedar Woods Properties Ltd canal estate—a development that would have had a very significant impact on the Creery Wetland in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: The poll result was 64.7 per cent of residents opposed to the development. I take that as a clear signal from the community that it wants to see the Creery Wetland protected. I must say, as federal environment minister, that I warmly welcome that decision.

On the basis of the poll result, I hope that the way is now clear to properly recognise and protect all the important values of the Creery Wetland. Today I will be writing to the Western Australian environment minister proposing that we work cooperatively to recognise the environmental value of that area by preparing the necessary documentation to allow for its addition to the adjoining Peel-Yalgorup system Ramsar site. I look forward to a positive response from the Western Australian environment minister. I think the Creery Wetland has a very high environmental value and that has been clearly recognised by the community.

The Creery Wetland is regularly used by large numbers of waterbirds, including some that are protected under international treaties. Up to 25 per cent of all the birds in the Peel inlet can be found on or adjacent to the land where the proposed development would have been located.

I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the residents of Mandurah, particularly the Creery Wetland support group and local state upper house member John Cowdell and, of course, others who have been involved in this particular struggle for protection of a very important area of very high environmental value in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer the minister to the Peter Valentine report on the impacts of the proposed Port Hinchinbrook development on the World Heritage values of the Hinchinbrook area. I ask: can the minister confirm that the Valentine report contains a catalogue of serious impacts on World Heritage values of the proposed development? Secondly, will the minister assure the Senate that as part of his jurisdiction he will not allow any of the impacts listed in the report to occur? Thirdly, will the minister release the environmental management agreement, as recommended by the department of environment and the Valentine report, prior to his making a decision on the development? Finally, will the minister refer the deed of agreement to Peter Valentine for objective assessment of World Heritage impacts prior to his making a decision on the development?

—My department engaged Dr Peter Valentine of the James Cook University of North Queensland to undertake a study of the World Heritage values of the Hinchinbrook Channel and its environs and also the possible effects on those values of the proposed resort at Oyster Point. I can confirm for Senator Kernot that the report does describe World Heritage values of the Hinchinbrook area and it does discuss possible impacts of the Oyster Point proposal on those values.

PARA.TAB: In response to the second part of Senator Kernot's question, I can give her a categorical assurance that I will do everything within my power as the federal environment minister to protect the World Heritage values of the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage area. The environment management agreement that Senator Kernot has referred to in her question is now called, I believe, a deed of agreement and is a Queensland government document. It is still, I believe, in draft form. I will take Senator Kernot's suggestion up with the Queensland government and the minister there, Ms Robson, in relation to its release. I will give consideration to release of the Valentine report, which, of course, is a report commissioned by my own department.

In relation to referring the deed of agreement to Dr Valentine, I will give consideration to that suggestion. But I would point out to Senator Kernot, as I have suggested before, that the deed of agreement is a Queensland government document and is still in draft form at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer. Are the relevant Queensland ministers and bureaucrats cooperating with the minister and his department, or is this yet another example of the need for a greater role for the federal government in the environmental protection of this nation and its natural resources?

—There certainly has been significant liaison and communication between me and Minister Robson in Queensland, and between the relevant agencies within my department and the Queensland agencies that have a concern with this proposal. Obviously we are currently assessing responses that we have received from the Queensland government.
—Do they make your job more difficult?

—I think there is a proper process in place in relation to this matter. There has been significant communication, and I have indicated to Senator Kernot that I will be taking my responsibilities seriously as they go to protecting the world heritage values of those areas. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Trade. We often hear claims that the Australian information and telecommunications industry is as technologically advanced and competitive as that of any other country in the world. Are these claims true? Are Australian companies taking advantage of export opportunities? Is the government giving them any assistance?

—Senator Schacht gave a very important outline of the exports of highly added manufactures earlier in question time, and the same thing is happening in this area and in related services areas. Exports are growing very quickly and they are increasingly important sources of employment growth in the Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: Information technology and telecommunications products are very important elements of that growth and we should be very proud of the things that are happening. There are a lot of Australians in jobs and offices all around the country in this industry working because of the success of this industry internationally. It is generating jobs in all the cities and many of the major regional centres of Australia.

If I may look at services more broadly and then put this in context, the recent so-called LEK study on intelligent exports and the silent revolution in services said that the increase in services exports is likely to lead to an additional 109,000 new jobs by 1998. In fact, there are some proposals in that report that suggest it might even be earlier. The information technology and telecommunications industry is leading the way. Our exports in this area have grown tenfold over the past decade, from $250 million to $2.5 billion.

One of the problems is that Australians underestimate the extent to which Australia does very well in this area. We still have an old-fashioned view of ourselves. More importantly, our markets tend to have an old-fashioned view and see us as essentially a source of commodities and tourist destinations, both of which are very important and should not be under-estimated. But this new growth area of telecommunications and information technology has exports roughly equivalent to, for example, our annual exports of sugar, dairy, wine and spirits combined. It is almost equivalent to iron ore—$2.5 billion to $2.9 billion is the ratio. It is becoming one of our major sectors of export.

The industry has set itself a very substantial future export growth—a target of $10 billion per year of exports by the year 2000. We are working very closely with the industry to achieve this laudable goal, and I think the extent of that cooperation will be a key issue in determining whether we succeed.

Recently I had the chance to be associated with the very appropriate decision and cooperative arrangement between the Australian Information Industry Association and Austrade, as a result of which an AIIA export manager will be based within Austrade to help the industry and to coordinate. We are also working very closely with the telecommunications export task force which brings together industry and government representatives. Obviously, the more orthodox bilateral route of governments assisting with business missions, with Australian companies going overseas and seeking to make high level contacts, is valuable because there is a big government role in this area and the countries of our region. We recently had good experience in that regard in Thailand and in China, and previously in Latin America.

We are getting some international recognition of this and that is why Australia will be the partner country at CeBIT `95 in Germany. Allied with what the government is doing through Senator Cook's portfolio on industry development in this sector—for example, through partnerships in development—those areas are coming together very successfully to mean an industry growing strongly at home. This is beginning to get effective recognition overseas and will eventually be reflected in jobs in Australia. That is exactly what the driving force behind it should be. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and it also relates to the Port Hinchinbrook Development. Can the minister reconcile the two reports on the Port Hinchinbrook development: namely, on the one hand the Valentine report, paid for by the federal taxpayer, which said that there were 15 distinct World Heritage impacts which would destroy the World Heritage values of the area; and on the other hand, the respected Loder and Bayly Consulting Group report which said there were nine possible areas of impact and of those only one had a moderate risk of direct impact, four were of low risk of direct impact, three were of minimal direct impact and one would have no impact at all? Can the minister explain how two so-called professional consultants can come to such contradictory and conflicting conclusions on the impact of the proposed development on the environmental values of the area?

—One of the advantages in the process that has been undertaken by my department and by me as environment minister is to ensure that the material that has been available to me, the report that my department commissioned and was undertaken by Dr Valentine, has been made available to the Queensland authorities. They have had an opportunity to look at the report even in draft form in detail and at any consequences that flow from it. I have also made available to Mrs Robson, the Queensland environment minister, and officers of her department and the office of the Queensland department of the coordinator-general, the final Valentine report.

PARA.TAB: I appreciate the fact that Queensland authorities have also made available to agencies of my department information and details about any work that they have commissioned. So I believe that there has been a transparency in those processes. Clearly, if there has been conflicting advice contained within any of that documentation, there is an opportunity for officers of departments of both governments to be able to look at those issues in some detail.

The process that has been undertaken by me as minister, which obviously has involved significant work by my department and agencies of the department, has not yet drawn to a conclusion. Some of the recent advice that we have had and documents that have been provided by the Queensland authorities are currently being subjected to examination by my department. I expect that within a very short time the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories will be advising me on the latest documentation that has been made available by Queensland authorities.

It seems to me that the process that has been undertaken means that there is maximum opportunity for both state and federal governments to look at the complexities of these issues—and the issues are complex. I stress that my role is to ensure that there is no impact on world heritage values. I indicated in response to Senator Kernot's question that that is a responsibility I take very seriously. I believe it is proper that the sort of work that has been undertaken at both levels of government is treated in the serious and thorough way that it has been.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is obvious that the minister has read neither report and has really no idea at all about the issue. I asked the minister to reconcile two entirely conflicting environmental reports. Is it not a fact that the minister is having a factional brawl with the Queensland government; that he goes out to get an environmental report that is different from the one the Queensland Labor government has; and that he will keep going until he gets a report that suits his factional position? Is the minister also aware that the developer has said that, because of the minister's procrastination, he is going to proceed with the development on the original plans for which he already has approval, which is a far less desirable form of development than the one he is trying to get approval for now? Unless the minister stops using this issue to have a fight with the right wing of the Labor Party in Queensland, this absolute farce will simply go on and a much needed development for North Queensland, which will create hundreds of jobs and a lot of export dollars, will simply go by the board. (Time expired)

—I love a factional brawl—and even, perhaps in Senator Macdonald's words, a factional ball. But I can assure the honourable senator that I am not having either at the expense of any of my colleagues in the Labor Party in Queensland. What is occurring is a very proper process between government ministers, departments and agencies of the Commonwealth government and the Queensland government. I stress that the federal minister's responsibilities go to protecting the World Heritage values of those areas. I will take that responsibility seriously—I have. In answer to the other part of the question: yes, I have read the reports and, hence, I have communicated in the way that I have with the Queensland authorities.

—My question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs relates to the peace process on Bougainville. Has a decision been made yet about the nature and extent of Australian support for the Bougainville peace process, and in particular for the proposed South Pacific peacekeeping contingent? Has the government arrived at a determination as to the practical level of assistance?

—I am pleased to be able to advise the Senate that cabinet this morning approved Australian training and logistic support for the proposed South Pacific peacekeeping contingent to be deployed to Bougainville next month. Our commitment follows last week's visit to Canberra by Papua New Guinea Prime Minister, Sir Julius Chan, during which he formally requested Australia's assistance in support of the peacekeeping operation.

PARA.TAB: Since his visit a series of meetings involving the Papua New Guinea government and the proposed contingent participants—that is to say, Fiji, Tonga and Vanuatu—together with the Australian and New Zealand governments, have defined key aspects of the contingent's composition, structure, funding, task and command. The key operational commands for the contingent, including in particular command on the ground in Bougainville, will be held by Fiji and Tonga. Australia has been requested by PNG and the other participating nations and other players in the peace process to take responsibility for the planning, training and logistic support of the operation.

The deployment of the South Pacific peacekeeping contingent to Bougainville is provided for under the `Honiara Commitment to Peace on Bougainville' that was signed on 3 September between Sir Julius and the BRA leader, Sam Kauona. Its main task will be to secure the venue for the Bougainville peace conference to be held in Arawa in October. The contingent is proposed to be deployed for some 14 days presently anticipated to be between 3 and 17 October.

Our support for the peacekeeping operation will consist of the preparatory training of the 400-strong contingent in Townsville followed by transport of it to Bougainville in early October. We will also have a role in providing support for the contingent during its stay on Bougainville, and supplying logistic and technical assistance throughout the operation, including rations, medical support and communications. The cost of our contribution is estimated to be some $5.2 million.

Might I say that it is fitting that Australia make a significant contribution in support of a peaceful resolution of the Bougainville conflict, consistent with our commitment to do everything we possibly could to facilitate a peaceful resolution of that conflict, bearing in mind the obvious constraints that we labour under. At the same time, it should be fully understood that Australia in no way assumes responsibility for the success or failure of the peace conference. We are simply facilitating and supporting arrangements reached by the PNG government and the BRA themselves, and our role is premised on their agreeing to it.

I want to applaud the efforts made by Sir Julius Chan in pursuing a peaceful negotiated settlement of the Bougainville conflict. I very much welcome the renunciation by rebel groups of the use of arms as contained in the cease-fire agreement on Bougainville signed on 8 September. The present peace process has undoubtedly given Bougainville its best chance of returning to normalcy in the six years since the conflict commenced. In that context, I also want to have a word of praise for my colleague Senator Loosley and those in the parliamentary delegation that he led there a few months ago because I think it was the process that was mapped in that particular committee's report that has now seen itself crystallised in this fashion.

I also want to acknowledge very publicly the very constructive role played over recent weeks and months by the government of the Solomon Islands in bringing together the parties to the Bougainville conflict and fostering a process of dialogue among them, a process which has led now directly to the decision to deploy a peacekeeping contingent to Bougainville.

I say finally that we do not see the peacekeeping operation as an end in itself. Its objective is and always has been to facilitate the holding of the peace conference. The onus will be on all the parties themselves to continue to act in a responsible, cooperative and peaceful manner in the search for a lasting solution.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. I remind the minister that over the past seven years the Australian science olympiads have entered teams of outstanding young scholars in the international physics, chemistry and, more recently, biology olympiads. Participation by teams from Australia will cease if funding cannot be raised by the end of this year for 1995. Will the minister acknowledge that recognition of academic values is very important if Australia is to be significant in the Asia region? Will the government demonstrate commitment and restore the opportunity for Australia's young scientists to participate in these important international competitions? Why has government support been withdrawn?

—This question was addressed to me as the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. I am not sure whether the question relates to this area or to the area of industry, science and technology. Whatever area it relates to, I do not have information available to me about the specific details Senator Reid has raised. However, I want to put on the record that this government values academic achievement and it values learning amongst our young people. I will raise this matter with my colleagues and come back to Senator Reid with a report as soon as I can.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. The minister opened a construction skills centre in Adelaide on Friday. What particular skills will the centre offer and how will the training be integrated with work practices? What federal government moneys were contributed to the centre? What moves are being made in competency based training?

—I thank Senator Foreman for his question. I was representing both my own portfolio and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Crean, last Friday at the opening of Australia's first industry owned construction skills centre at Wingfield in the north-western area of Adelaide.
—Which electorate is that in?

—This facility is a great example of what can be achieved in partnership between government and industry. Senator Watson asked what seat that centre is in. I understand that it is in the Port Adelaide electorate, which is very well represented by Mr Sawford, who was at the opening representing his constituents. The centre was built in this area—it had nothing to do with a particular electorate—because the industry identified this as the most appropriate place to build it.

PARA.TAB: The federal government provided $700,000 towards the construction of the skills centre, with industry contributing $279,000 and with a further $136,000 to come from the construction industry training fund. The land was provided by the South Australian government. The centre was jointly opened by myself and Minister Such from the state government. The state government provided assistance for the land and for a rehabilitation agreement.

The facility offers a large range of accredited training to meet the needs of earthmoving and civil construction industries and in providing industry-relevant training to new and existing workers in a range of occupations. It will integrate learning with real work industry practice. The government's training reform agenda is a long-term process of change. It is a process which will progressively move existing inflexible, time based training systems into flexible, industry responsive, competency based training. In fact, the National Training Board has endorsed the national competency standards for almost 60 per cent of Australia's work force. The push is now on to ensure that we have training courses and programs that meet industry standards.

For the first time we have seen all states and territories agree to move towards a competency based training system, and this is a major step forward for training in Australia. This has resulted in a massive effort across industry to define work standards and to use these benchmarks for designing industry-specific training courses. I certainly want to pay tribute to the earthmoving and construction industry for its contribution, foresight and vision in driving the program forward to establish this skill centre.

I also want to say, as the federal minister responsible for the MFP, that part of the opening ceremony was drowned out by the sounds of bulldozers and earthmoving equipment immediately behind us, as the first stage of the MFP was getting under way in establishing the environmental wetlands at Barker Inlet. All of those present, including Mr Such and the Liberal Party representatives, were also very pleased, as I was, to acknowledge that development, for the MFP has assisted in the establishment of this skills centre.

In conclusion, this is another very good example of the federal government's commitment to supporting industry in its drive towards greater efficiency. We look forward to further cooperation across all industries to get a competency based skills system operating.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Evans. Let me first compliment him on that wonderfully elitist pen for such an egalitarian person to have. Nonetheless, since this government has widely taken up the cost of justice issue so tirelessly—and may I say pursued by this chamber's Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, ably chaired by Senator Cooney—and given that the COAG working party on reform of the legal profession clearly felt that competition would be enhanced and prices therefore kept in check if the title of Queen's Counsel were no longer given currency, why does not the minister lead the way and firm up his commitment to Australians by discarding what he would see as remnants of a colonial empire? Why does he not give up his commission as Queen's Counsel, or at least stop using it since in his case it might be regarded as an affectation?

—Unlike one's whole presence in this chamber, which is equally an affectation in Senator Vanstone's case. Mr President, I do not think that that has very much to do with my present ministerial responsibilities; it did have something to do with my ministerial responsibilities some 10 years ago. The title Queen's Counsel is not one that I drop around—
—It is better than a magistrates court job.
—I have been in hearings before the High Court more often than has Senator Hill.
—Only when you appointed yourself.

—On the contrary. Let us just get that straight for the record. I was appointed by the Victorian Chief Justice—on application, yes, but by the Victorian Chief Justice. At least my career has not been spent not making impressions on soft cushions, which is the most I can say for Senator Hill.

PARA.TAB: If this indicates that Senator Vanstone is moving progressively down the republican path in her approach to these residual elements of the monarchical system, that is a contribution and a progress wholly to be applauded. I am glad to see that, having made the grotesque mistake she obviously now acknowledges she did in moving to support Alexander Downer, she is now in this particular fashion starting gradually to wean herself off some of the policy positions that she is going to be tagged with if she keeps up that particular support. I do not think that particular title has anything to do with anything very much. It is one that I have been very proud to carry over the years, and I will continue to do so so long as it exists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I think Senator Evans misunderstood my question. My question to him was in his capacity as Leader of the Government in the Senate, not in his ministerial capacity. In that capacity he does have a role to show a lead, and his government has widely taken up the costs of justice agenda. It is argued by many people that the prices will go down if we do not have such elitist things. Senator Evans is the one who is on the republican path. The question to the minister is: will he put his money where his mouth is and discard the title of Queen's Counsel? If he does not want all the trappings of the empire, why is he clinging onto them for himself?
—One of the Queen's men.
—One of the Queen's men. The question I ask is: why does Senator Evans not show a lead as Leader of the Government in the Senate?

—Mr President, I am one of the Queen's men and I am very proud to wear that particular title for so long as it remains appropriate in this country. As a good democrat as well as a Queen's man, I am happy to await the verdict of the Australian community on this particular question before seeking to pre-empt it in any way. There is a much better chance of our making an impact on the Australian community in that respect and in many others than Senator Vanstone, particularly if she continues to ask inane questions like that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Given that the Prime Minister said on a recent trip to North Queensland that the current drought was related to climate change effects, I ask: firstly, has the government carried out a cost benefit analysis in accordance with the precautionary principle of failing to address the greenhouse issue in its drought relief program; secondly, what are the total costs of the current drought; thirdly, what specific measures has the government put in place to address greenhouse; and, fourthly, how much has been spent on these measures, and by how much—that is quantitatively—has each of these measures been effective?

—To begin with, I think I should point out to Senator Coulter that the Prime Minister did not say that the current drought was due to climate change effects. He did say that drought was a recurring issue in Australia and that it is coming quite regularly with climate change effects.

PARA.TAB: Climate change research demonstrates that climatic conditions are dynamic; they represent a complex interaction of meteorological and hydrological phenomena involving the atmosphere, the oceans and continental land masses. It is clear that rapidly increasing gas emissions will contribute to the variability and unpredictability of our climate.

In relation to the specific questions asked, I am not aware of any cost benefit analysis of the type that Senator Coulter referred to in his question. In answer to the second part of the question, I do not have any comprehensive figures to provide to the honourable senator; but I can say that the drought is forecast to reduce the net value of agricultural production by around $1.3 billion, stalling what would have been a strong recovery in the rural sector. Overall, the net value of agricultural production is expected to fall by almost $1 billion between 1993-94 and 1994-95. This follows three years in which the net value of agricultural production increased slowly from the low base of the early 1990s.

The honourable senator asked me to detail measures put in place to address climate greenhouse and their effectiveness and cost. I have been on the public record several times over the past few weeks addressing those very issues. I have clearly stated that the first set of measures in the national greenhouse response strategy will not achieve the national and international targets that Australia is aiming to meet. I have also clearly stated that more will need to be done in terms of greenhouse measures and that cabinet will be considering additional policy options in December of this year to, I hope, move us closer to meeting our targets.

In relation to the honourable senator's request for more specific details on the government's actions across the range of obligations we have nationally and under the climate change convention, I refer him to the very soon to be released national report under the climate change convention, which has been endorsed by cabinet. I will certainly make available to the honourable senator a copy of that report as soon as it is available, which will be within the next few days.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. The minister will be aware of the controversy surrounding the $41 million of losses accumulated by ANL over the past three financial years. He will also be aware of losses made by the Department of Administrative Services businesses—specifically, Australian Construction Services, which has accumulated losses and other subsidies in excess of $90 million over the past four years, and DAS Distribution, which has accumulated losses and other subsidies of $23.2 million. The minister will also be aware of the $80 million that was lost on the disastrous development of the Casselden Place building in Melbourne. Will the minister immediately appoint an independent board of inquiry into these failed government business dealings that have cost taxpayers in excess of $200 million in the last three years?

—We have here selective indignation because there was no reference to those profit-making businesses in DAS, or to the fact that since 1987-88 there has been a turnaround in the performance of the businesses under the Department of Administrative Services of several hundred million dollars—a significant improvement in the way in which the taxpayers' money is dealt with—and that there are significant programs of reform in ACS and DAS Distribution, the two businesses to which Senator Campbell referred. They both have programs—certainly this was the case with regard to DAS Distribution when I last looked at it—which show significant capacity to return to a profitable operation.

PARA.TAB: ACS, of course, is operating in the depressed construction sector as a result of the oversupply of the 1980s and is suffering, as most of the other companies in that area are. It has been the subject of very rigorous review in the budget and, of course, rigorous scrutiny by this parliament in estimates committees and in other ways. Yes, I am aware of those cases. The Casselden Place figure is just one of those little fictions of Senator Campbell's imagination.

Overall, those business are doing well. In fact, there is an advisory board within the department with significant and senior private sector representation on it. I do not know its current membership—it is some time since I was involved—but there is senior private sector representation on that board which advises the secretary to the department, the minister and the government about the management of those enterprises.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I will take the opportunity to mention a couple that did make profits. Dasfleet is a very profitable operation because it has a monopoly on supplying 15,000 vehicles to public servants, politicians and other people. It also uses that profit to supply cars, at a cost to the taxpayer of about $1 million, to the government's Transport Workers Union mates at cut rates. But these businesses have lost in excess of $200 million. According to the answer given at estimates committee, the loss on the Casselden Place building is in excess of $70 million, plus other costs.
