The minister can call that a fiction but, if it is a fiction, then his department is misleading the Senate. That is the figure referred to in the estimates process. My question is this: the government has provided income tax relief to employees of ANL to help out its Maritime Union mates. Will it now make, as part of its package to salvage these failed government dealings in these other businesses, income tax exemption to the employees of these DAS business units?
—I am delighted that Senator Campbell has joined Mr Sharp in advocating this policy. Mr Sharp advocated it for ANL; now he has advocated it for people in the—
—I am not advocating it; I am saying you are going to do it.

—You asked me if I would do it. I understand Senator Campbell's enthusiasm to sell these projects because he probably has some mates who would like to profit from it. Nevertheless, it is not our intention to go down that route.
—I take a point of order, Mr President. I am reluctant to rise on points of order, but Senator McMullan implied and impugned an improper motive.
—What about all the stuff in his question?
—I have no intention of interrupting my point of order to debate with Senator Collins, but it was impugning a motive to Senator Campbell in the answer to the question. I ask that it be withdrawn.
—I agree that it might have been impugning, but so were a lot of other comments being made in the question. But I would ask you to withdraw, Senator McMullan.
—I will, Mr President, if you wish.

—On the point of order, Mr President, I ask you to consider this: if any question—in this case, Senator Campbell's—contains imputations, I ask you to bear in mind that the person answering it can deliver the facts which clear that point. In this case it is the reverse situation, whereby someone answering a question can make the imputations and the other person does not have the opportunity to respond.
—He has already withdrawn.
—I realise it has been withdrawn. I am asking you, Mr President, to consider this. I am asking you to consider that in future rulings.
—Your point is taken. I have already asked him to withdraw; he has withdrawn.

—Some people can give it out but cannot take it. The fact is that these companies have been operating on the basis of a very significant initiative taken by Stewart West and Nick Bolkus, as my predecessors, and by me—and now by Frank Walker—and they have been substantially turned around, not without great difficulty. Overall, the businesses operating under the Department of Administrative Services have turned into significant pluses for the Australian taxpayer. They provide important services while providing a return to the budget. I know that he thinks that all the profitable ones should be sold and all the unprofitable ones should be closed, but I have to say the arithmetic of that does not add up, either.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services, Senator Rosemary Crowley. Can the minister inform the Senate what the federal government is doing to protect Australian women and men from false claims by cosmetics manufacturers?

—I suppose a lot of other senators, besides me, saw in today's Melbourne Age an article claiming that the Therapeutic Goods Administration is cracking down on extravagant advertising claims by cosmetic manufacturers. In fact, the TGA has been working on this issue for quite a while. I share a large concern about some of the more extravagant claims made by cosmetic companies. It concerns me that these companies are preying on the insecurities of both men and women about staying young forever, about the perfect body or the perfect face or, if we read today's Sydney Morning Herald, the perfect penis.
—There are a few of those on the other side.
—Certainly not.
—Order!

—Some of the claims made by these cosmetic companies are quite remarkable and must clearly have tested the imagination of copy writers. Most of us can cope with `improving biological performance', `re-energising skin', `decongesting skin' or `accelerating cell renewal'. But I think that suggestions of `rebuilding the innermost structure of the epidermis' or, even better still, `biostimulation of tissue oxygenation'—and I am still not sure what it means—are the sorts of things that can lead to confusion and anxiety, at least, amongst the consuming public. It is a matter of considerable concern that we do get the distinction between cosmetic claims and therapeutic claims right.

PARA.TAB: The laws of this land under the Therapeutic Goods Authority require that if manufacturers make any sort of therapeutic claim at all then they must have the product concerned registered and tested for both the validity of the claim and any chemical or serious content in that product. We need to have that because we know of a number of times when—and this is perhaps of less concern—a claim is made that cannot be verified or, more importantly, when people use or consume products which cause serious illness.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would close down the whole of the cosmetic industry.

—Senator Hill should wait to hear what I have to say. He has got it all wrong. If people are providing products that are not properly tested, these can lead to illness or even death if the regulations are not clear. Senator Hill seems anxious to confuse the issue. We are very concerned about making a clear distinction between cosmetic claims and therapeutic claims so that people in the cosmetic industry and the therapeutic industry can be clear and not stray from one into the other and therefore put people at risk or industry at risk.

PARA.TAB: For that reason we have established some draft guidelines, and I make it clear that they are draft guidelines. They are being worked through with the Cosmetic Toiletry and Fragrance Association of Australia and with the TGA so as to establish clearly this distinction between therapeutic and cosmetic and to protect both the consumer and proper industries that are supplying these products. If people make therapeutic claims it is not good enough that such claims should go untested. It is even worse if products that have a therapeutic claim attached to them contain chemicals or products that could—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have to go on?
—Why is this upsetting Senator Vanstone?
—The government is therapeutic; the opposition is cosmetic.
—The minister's time has expired.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—I follow up a question from Senator Panizza yesterday, as I promised to do, relating to the Price Surveillance Authority and the impact of the drought, with the following answer. Bread is not a product presently declared for surveillance under the Prices Surveillance Act. Some wheat products are declared, such as Arnott's biscuits and breakfast cereals, but this is because of the structure of those markets. Bread is a very competitive market and those who seek to raise prices excessively, based on spurious claims about the drought, are likely to lose market share to their competitors.

PARA.TAB: I understand that the chairman of the PSA is aware, nonetheless, that some prices have increased as a result of the drought and he has cautioned firms not to use it as an excuse to raise prices. Some price rices are inevitable as a result of the drought. This is one means, after all, by which its effect on rural producers is cushioned and the burden shared throughout the general community. If evidence were to emerge of excessive pricing increases in markets where drought affected inputs to production are important, the government would consider requesting that the PSA provide advice on those price movements.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, earlier in question time today Senator Reid asked me a question about funding for the Australian Science Olympiad. In relation to that question I have been provided with certain information from the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Mr Free.

PARA.TAB: The information is as follows. The government is surprised by the claim that we are withdrawing funding from the maths and science olympiads in 1994; the maths and science olympiads will receive $335,000 in 1994 for their activities; the Commonwealth is providing $300,000 for the hosting of the Physics Olympiad in 1995 and has undertaken to provide $300,000 for the hosting of the Chemistry Olympiad in 1998, if Australia's bid is successful. Professor Fred Smith, chairman of the Australian Science Olympiad committee, has written confirmation of these arrangements—

TALK.START.PARA: —When did you decide it—yesterday?
—He got written confirmation. I have just been provided with this information.
—They had been told previously they would get nothing.

—I ask the honourable senator to please let me finish. In 1990 the Commonwealth agreed to provide seed funding for these activities from 1990 to 1994 to encourage wider participation in maths and science. The organisers have always been aware of the funding period and undertook to obtain alternate recurrent support for their activities.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth's aim in schooling is to improve education outcomes across the full spectrum of student achievement. Seed support for the olympiads is only a small part of this. The states, which have the primary responsibility for schooling across Australia, have not provided any financial assistance for the maths and science olympiads.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a short response on behalf of Senator Collins, representing the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton), to the notice of motion given yesterday by Senator Gibson for the laying on the table of information relating to ANL.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I am advised by Senator Collins, representing the Minister for Transport, that it is not possible at this time to table the documents that are listed in Senator Gibson's notice of motion given yesterday, which motion has not yet formally passed the Senate. The documents listed are being categorised against security classifications, including whether the documents contain cabinet-in-confidence and/ or commercial-in-confidence material. In addition, ANL has to be given an opportunity to comment on whether these documents should be released. When these steps are completed Senator Collins will advise the Senate.

PARA.TAB: On behalf of the Minister for Transport, I might add that the task involved in compiling the list of documents that was tabled on 19 September, in accordance with the notice of motion agreed to by the Senate on 31 August 1994 relating to the ANL, was an enormous one. In particular, the exercise to locate and identify all the documents requested under parts (c) and (d) of the motion was considerable. It involved searching some 600 files and, thus far, over 270 documents have been listed for the information of the Senate.

Five officers have been involved full time and a number on a less than full-time basis in identifying relevant documents. The government in good faith made the results of that search available to the Senate as soon as possible and in accordance with the Senate's wishes. Some hundreds of person hours have so far been expended on the task and officers have been seconded from other important projects to fulfil the request of the Senate within a reasonable time.

Recognising that some documents have been inadvertently omitted from the list, the Maritime Policy Division of the Department of Transport is currently crosschecking its records with those of ANL and other areas of the department. In preparing the initial list it was not possible to crosscheck references against information held by ANL Ltd. That information has been progressively made available by the company only since yesterday evening. Once crosschecking has been completed, the search will have been as exhaustive as possible and the supplementary list will be made available to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In Senator Gibson's absence—I hope he will be able to come to the chamber—I would like to thank the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) for his statement on behalf of the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton). Could the minister advise the Senate as to how long the government proposes to delay responding to the Senate's return to order motion, which, I understand, was passed formally this morning—and, therefore, with the concurrence of the government—that the material is to be produced by 3 p.m. tomorrow?
—It has not been dealt with.
—I am advised it has not been passed.

—I correct my understanding on that. But my other understanding is that the government advised the Senate that it was going to agree to the motion. Can the minister advise us how long a delay is being proposed?

PARA.TAB: The minister also referred to the fact that there were inadvertent omissions from the list of documents that were tabled yesterday. We certainly understand that that has been a lengthy and difficult process, but you may recall, Mr Deputy President, that yesterday, when I raised in question time the fact that I was aware of at least one omission from that statement, Senator Collins, representing the Minister for Transport, got on a very high horse and said that, of course, it was a complete list. Now we hear that the omission that I referred to yesterday is not the only one and that there are others.

Does Senator Evans have any details of the extent of those omissions, which are highly misleading, given that the list that was tabled yesterday purported to be a complete list? And, as I say, the ire of the government was raised when I questioned that. If he does not yet know how many documents have been omitted from the list submitted yesterday, will he give the Senate a guarantee that he will, in eventually advising the Senate—I hope that is as soon as possible—of the full list of omissions, tell us why those omissions occurred in the first place and why the government yesterday misled the Senate in not only the presentation of the list but also the subsequent explanation of it?

They are both very serious matters. ANL is a very serious matter. I do not think that I have ever seen any area of government where policy and administration of a matter have been so disgracefully handled as the ANL one. It is a matter of very considerable public importance and it is obligatory, in my view, on behalf of the Australian community, that the government prepare and present to the Senate the material as has been requested and as is foreshadowed in the notice of motion that Senator Gibson gave today.

Senator Gibson is now here and he will undoubtedly have some words to add. I want to express my concern at this foreshadowed delay and I want some assurance from the government as to the time scale that it is now proposing in relation to the presentation of the material.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I would like to make a request of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans). He is a person of boundless courtesy and charity. Regrettably, Senator Gibson was out of the chamber when Senator Evans made his statement. With the great economy of words that the Leader of the Government has, could he repeat the burden of his argument in two sentences so that Senator Gibson could be apprised of the issue?

—by leave—I will do better than that; I will pass the text of it across the chamber. The essence of it is that it has not been possible in the time available to respond to Senator Gibson's motion for reasons that are there set out in terms of the enormous workload that is involved and also the necessity to crosscheck against records from the ANL side some of the information that was given in response to the original motion because there have been one or two—or some, as the text there says—omissions that have shown up since this was put down.

PARA.TAB: I am not in a position to give any further information on this. What the Senate heard is what I know about this. Senator Collins would be in the chamber except for the fact that he is just finishing off the preparation of his drought relief statement and about to do a press conference, and he asked me to fill in on his behalf.

I think the best thing to do in all the circumstances, since this motion of Senator Gibson's has not yet been formally passed, would be by agreement to change the time on this to 3 o'clock tomorrow, 22 September. I will ask the department to make best endeavours to meet that particular deadline. If there is some compelling reason why that cannot be met tomorrow after question time, then Senator Collins will give Senator Gibson a further and better explanation of what the problems are. I think that is the best we can do under all the circumstances. Nobody is trying to be in any way unhelpful—well, not particularly unhelpful.

It is a matter of recognising the enormous complexity of this sort of exercise. As I said earlier on, some 600 or 700 files have had to be gone through to produce this information and it has involved literally hundreds of person-hours of effort already and we must expect some difficulty of this kind in a matter of this complexity. If Senator Gibson is prepared to amend his notice of motion accordingly, we can perhaps handle it on that basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I hear what Senator Evans has to say and I understand the complexities of double checking the total list, but my notice of motion No. 1084, which, as Senator Evans says, is still to be passed by the Senate, is really only asking for copies of about 30 documents. We are not talking about a huge amount of work. I am happy to set a later time today.

—As it says there, confidentiality criteria have got to be tested, ANL's reaction has got to be tested and commercial-in-confidence orders. We simply cannot expect to get that sort of response that quickly. I am suggesting that Senator Gibson will get a further and better response tomorrow on what the art of the possible is.
—Could we compromise on a time of, say, 12 noon tomorrow, so that we have some time to look at the matters? That is a reasonable request.

—You have probably got the numbers to roll us over at any time you like. I am just trying to be realistic about it. I do not think it is likely that you will get a response tomorrow in the terms that you would require, but you may be able to get a response to some of the issues that Senator Short has raised, with the omissions filled in.

—I think that the omissions are a secondary issue. From our point of view, we would sooner see the documents tabled that I have listed as first priority. I am happy to suggest that that be done by, say, midday tomorrow.

—At the risk of interrupting a stimulating debate in which I am not a participant, this is a matter for formal business later in the day. Senator Gibson might like to take a position at the time of his motion coming before the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), to a question without notice asked by Senator Ian Macdonald this day, relating to the Port Hinchinbrook development project.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer in particular to my request to Senator Faulkner to reconcile the two environmental reports into the Hinchinbrook development, both of which are quite contradictory. At the outset, can I say that it comes as no surprise to me that the Australian Democrats are supporting Senator Faulkner in the delay and procrastination on this particular development. It is interesting to note that the only people on the other side who have ever spoken on this or raised the matter have been Senator Faulkner, who is well known as a kneecapper from the left—he has tried his kneecapping on Mr Goss in the Queensland Right and it has not worked—Senator Reynolds, who, lovely person that she is, of course, is from the Left of the Labor Party, and Senator Bryant Burns, also from the Left of the Labor Party. Of course, we have the Greens and the Australian Democrats, who are really the ultra-left wing of the Labor Party, coming on-side.

TALK.START.PARA: —Better than being in the Liberal Party at the moment.

—Senator Kernot has been running around Queensland trying to pretend, mischievously, that she is a member of the Liberal Party. I assure her that we would never have her in the Liberal Party because she and her party are anti-business, anti-rural people, anti-regional Australia and, really, anti any form of sensible government whatsoever in our country. So we would never have her in the Liberal Party in spite of her going around Queensland trying to pretend she is a member of the Liberal Party.

PARA.TAB: We do not want her—again, nice person as she is. Her political philosophies are so far removed from ours that even the Labor Party intervenes between the Democrats and us. They are to the very left of the Labor Party. Her colleagues understand that. That is why they are getting a bit concerned about her continuing fall in the polls and the fact that the Democrats simply support the Labor Party on every conceivable major issue. It comes as no surprise to me that the Democrats are doing that.

Port Hinchinbrook is a tourist development. We heard an amazing contribution from Senator Coulter earlier today in which he criticised international tourism into Australia because he said it meant that we could not reach our greenhouse targets for the end of the century. As I understand Senator Coulter, he is bagging international tourism and saying we should be cutting it out. He says we should be reducing international tourism into Australia because of its greenhouse effect. I find that breathtaking. It is no wonder that with that general philosophy of the Democrats about stopping international tourism into Australia—one of Australia's major industries, I might say—they are trying their best to stop this development.

As I have always said, this development must go ahead—subject to the most stringent environmental conditions. But the Queensland government, time and again, has looked at this matter. It has been on the drawing board for some years now. The Queensland government has gone into it properly. It has had the Loder and Bayly Consulting Group report on the matter at hand. That report has said that there are only nine possible—not definite—areas of impact that this development might have on environmental matters. It said that of those nine possible areas, one had a moderate risk of direct impact; four were of low risk direct impact; three were of minimal direct impact; and one had no direct impact at all.

Contrasted with that is the report that Senator Faulkner has got for himself from Dr Peter Valentine, who says there are 15 distinct World Heritage impacts, any one of which would destroy the World Heritage values of the area. I ask: how can two respected consulting groups give entirely conflicting and contradictory reports on this development? It really shows the farce of it all.

The Labor Party has to sort out its factional brawl. It has to let the proper processes go and, if it is appropriate for this development to go ahead, it should go ahead. I have warned the minister that the developer has said that he can now go ahead on his old permits if he wants to do so. The Labor Party has to get its act together and work out which faction is going to have a say and, for heaven's sake, get the development on the way in an environmentally sensitive manner—and create jobs. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us get the politics out of the way first. I say to Senator Ian Macdonald that people have asked me to be the leader of the Liberal Party. I have told them that, unlike Alexander Downer, I know what I believe in—and it is not what that arch-conservative corps, masquerading as liberals, believes in. I have no difficulty telling them that I am not interested. Senator Macdonald always obfuscates on such matters. Let us get on to the issue.

PARA.TAB: The big issue Senator Macdonald left out in his taking note was the way in which the Queensland government uses consultants. Senator Macdonald asked how the minister for environment could reconcile a federal report and a state government report. There is one fundamental problem: the Queensland Labor government lines up consultants and uses them in such a way in order to get the right answer that the consultants know what they have to tell the Queensland government to get the next tender.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Valentine report?

—I believe that the Valentine report does not suffer from that deficiency. I want to spend a couple of minutes looking at what the Valentine report says in relation to its World Heritage values description of the Hinchinbrook area. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The World Heritage values of special significance in the Hinchinbrook area were identified as the following:

PARA.TAB: . Geological and geomorphological processes and features of Hinchinbrook Island and Channel—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know what that is?
—I wonder whether Senator Parer knows about these things. It continues:

PARA.TAB: . the high diversity of Brook Islands coral reefs and their outstanding scenic properties;
. the visual splendour—

SPEECH.PARA: I say to Senator Macdonald that we do not actually attach a tangible dollar to that, but it happens to be a World Heritage principle—
and outstanding diversity of the mangrove communities of Hinchinbrook Island and channel;

PARA.TAB: . the extremely high floristic diversity of Hinchinbrook Island lowlands;
. the spectacular scenery of Hinchinbrook Island and Channel and especially its wilderness values;
. the critical habitat of seagrasses and associated threatened marine animals.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the impacts of Oyster Point on these World Heritage values, the Valentine report states:
. impacts of dredging on seagrasses;
. impacts of seagrass loss on dugongs and sea turtles;
. impacts of increased boating activity on dugongs and sea turtles;
. impacts of rock training wall on tidal dynamics and sediment movement;
. impacts on Stony and One Mile Creek and ecological consequences;
. impacts on mangroves;
. impacts on marine ecological processes;
. other sources of increased turbidity;
. impacts on landscape;
. water pollution;
. impacts from acid sulphate soils;
. effects from insect management;
. impacts on adjacent Marine and National Parks;
. effects of increased recreational fishing in the Channel on the marine ecology;
. additional spill-over effects on World Heritage areas.

We just cannot ignore such an important catalogue of impacts and try to make it into some political issue about who we will believe—the Queensland government's consultants or the federal government's consultants.

PARA.TAB: I want to read to the Senate what I thought was a particularly appropriate letter that appeared in the Australian on 29 July 1994 from Frank Talbot, who is the Director of the United States Museum of National History, Smithsonian Institution, Washington DC, USA—

TALK.START.PARA: —What would he know about it?
—I say to Senator Parer, before he goes ahead disparagingly, that Frank Talbot is a former professor of environmental studies at Macquarie University. He says, and I agree with him:

PARA.TAB: I believe we should share this superb World Heritage area with others . . .

SPEECH.PARA: This is not about no tourist development; this is about totally inappropriate tourist development. This is about foisting and imposing another Hamilton Island on the Hinchinbrook Channel. He says:

I believe we should share this . . . tourist development as also an economic necessity. But the resort needs to be a mile or two away . . . National parks in the US, like California's Yosemite, struggle to cope with powerful developments entrenched in their parks through decisions made in the last century.

PARA.TAB: This "Port Hinchinbrook" resort and marina . . . has had no environmental impact study.

SPEECH.PARA: The point about all of this is that we have learnt what we have done to the Great Barrier Reef. We have learnt about inappropriate, mega-type Keith Williams developments. They are not suitable for the rest of this century or next century. That is why we should make sure that we get this decision right. It is not good enough to say it is simply a political matter of what the Queensland consultants will say. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ian Macdonald asks how we can reconcile the differences between federal and state government and attempts to indicate that political issues are at stake. Clearly, if people are familiar with World Heritage values, if they are familiar with federal government responsibilities under World Heritage legislation, they know there is clearly a federal government role to be played here.

PARA.TAB: Even though I do say it about the Queensland government, it is unfortunate that the Coordinator General's Department went ahead with this development before it even knew about World Heritage values. That is because the Coordinator General's Department is about development and making quick dollars; it is not an expert in environmental issues, and that is unfortunate. To the department's credit, it then commissioned the report by Loder and Bayly that Senator Ian MacDonald mentioned. But, again, with every respect to those consultants, I do not believe that they have the degree of expertise of Peter Valentine.
Opposition senators—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition senators may laugh but, frankly, their reputation and credibility on environmental issues scarcely warrant taking their laughter very seriously. Let me read from Peter Valentine's curriculum vitae and then perhaps those opposite can tell me whether they believe that Loder and Bayly can match this not only national but international reputation. Peter Valentine, the consultant that the minister chose for very good reason, is a senior lecturer in tropical environmental studies and geography at James Cook University. He is also a faculty member of the Executive Development Institute of Tourism at the University of Hawaii, teaching environment and tourism.

PARA.TAB: He has also held the position of former fellow consultant for the Environment and Policy Institute at the East-West Centre in Honolulu. He is currently a member and consultant at the International Union for the Conservation of Nature Commission on National Parks and Protected Areas; a member of the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage Consultative Committee; the chair of the North Queensland natural environment evaluation panel of the Australian Heritage Commission; and a founding member of the Ecotourism Association of Australia. He also has a great deal of experience—listed on four pages—of research into ecotourism, particularly looking at World Heritage values.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you think he might vote?

—Senator Macdonald and some of his colleagues dismiss Peter Valentine as somebody the minister thought it would be a good idea to appoint. Peter Valentine is an expert. That is why the minister chose him. The minister did not just call in some local consultant from Brisbane. Loder and Bayly probably has great expertise in other areas, but I challenge Senator Macdonald to indicate that it can match the international reputation of Peter Valentine. For example, he is regularly speaking at international conferences—including, in the last couple of years, Venezuela, Micronesia, Honolulu, Fiji and the United States. He is not a person who has come into this debate in the last few months because the Coordinator General's Department needs an evaluation.

PARA.TAB: The federal government has prime responsibility. Obviously we want to work with the state government, but we have prime responsibility. We will choose the best possible expert to advise us because we have the responsibility to maintain World Heritage values. If we do not maintain World Heritage values, what will happen to North Queensland's tourist industry? What will happen if, for example, the values of World Heritage listing were in any way denigrated? If we lost that World Heritage listing, what would happen to North Queensland's tourist industry? These are issues that the federal minister has to consider. He will consult with the state government, but the state government does not necessarily have the expertise. I do not believe that it can anywhere near match the work of Peter Valentine. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also would like to comment on the response given by Senator Faulkner to the question asked by Senator Ian Macdonald. Prior to that question being asked, a dorothy dix question was asked of the minister in respect of a poll taken by the Mandurah City Council in relation to a canal development which involved wetlands. The minister welcomed the fact that 67 per cent of the population did not want the canal estate development; that, therefore, encouraged him to go ahead and do what he was going to do to prevent the development happening.

PARA.TAB: If the minister knew that, he would also be aware of the fact that the Port Hinchinbrook development is in Cardwell. Cardwell has a population of some 1,300 people. Over 1,000 people attended a public meeting—the only time in the history of this little town where something like 1,000 people met together. Ninety-five per cent of those 1,000 people supported the project.

What we heard from Senator Kernot was a litany of reasons—very typical of the Democrats—as to why there should be no development. This area is between Cairns and Townsville. Development in Far North Queensland, particularly around Cairns, has by-passed Cardwell. The people of Cardwell are very interested in this development proceeding because of the benefits it will offer.

We have heard Senator Reynolds from the Left and Senator Kernot. They have said that lots of things count, but what does not count with them is Australian people. The people of Cardwell have a consuming interest in being able to participate in the tourist development which has so far by-passed them. I believe that the Cardwell Chamber of Commerce wrote to every senator. Did I hear Senator Kernot talk about this? Have I heard any of the Australian Democrats talk about this? No! All we have heard from the Democrats is why the project should not go ahead.

We have also had a quite disgraceful bucketing of the person behind this project, Mr Keith Williams, who has a record second to none in the sort of developments he has undertaken in Queensland—particularly Sea World.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look what he did to Hamilton Island.

—The Democrats and Senator Reynolds of the left wing of the Labor Party are laughing. Keith Williams developed a tourist project at Sea World which attracts hundreds of thousands of foreign visitors to Queensland and Australia. Senator Reynolds and the Democrats do not care about that; they do not care about jobs; they do not care about the fact that people who live there have no future unless this development goes ahead.

PARA.TAB: The Chamber of Commerce made the point that it carefully considered the benefits and the disadvantages before deciding to support the Oyster Point marina resort project. In May 1994, 1,260 out of 1,300 people in the town signed a petition in support of the project. After 14 months the project is still delayed, awaiting permit approvals.

This government has been responsible for the highest level of unemployment in our history. This has been going on and on with very little improvement. Tourism is one of the areas that have the potential to improve that disgraceful figure. The Minister for Tourism, Mr Lee, is going around saying warm-hearted things to the industry about how supportive the government is, and putting out glossy brochures; but when we get to a situation which is so vital to the town of Cardwell, to the people of Queensland, and to the people of Australia, every reason in the world is given as to why it should not occur.

I have before me a letter from a young man in Cardwell, Michael Kangas. Mr Kangas has never met Mr Williams. He told Mr Williams that he discussed this matter with one of the minorities, Margaret Thorsborne, and listened to her complaints. He wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: I have come to the conclusion that her claims are so insignificant when compared to the overwhelming advantages of your development that the so-called `Friends of Hinchinbrook' should not be taken any notice of.

This is a letter from a 17-year-old who says that he has no place to go but is hoping to get into a tertiary institution next year. He is very concerned about where his friends go and what happens to him when he has completed his degree. This is a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem is that a number of questions about this whole issue are not being answered. They include: why did the Queensland government find it necessary to ask for an environmental report instead of a proper environmental impact assessment? It had the framework in which it could have produced a report which would have answered the questions, but it did not use that framework. One needs to ask: was it because the Queensland government did not want a proper assessment but already knew the answer that it wanted its particular consultants to produce? Why was the report done by the Office of the Coordinator-General instead of the Department of Environment and Heritage? Again, one has to wonder whether it was because it knew the Office of the Coordinator-General would produce the answer it wanted. The answers to these questions are fundamental to the issue we are debating. I need to ask the developer, Mr Williams, why he does not want proper environmental controls. Surely, if it is the environment which he will use as the attraction—
—Go and ask him.

—I have asked him. I have asked him these very questions in letters and in telephone conversations with him. The problem is that, when Mr Williams is asked such questions, instead of answering in any reasonable way, he simply threatens. Numbers of people in the Cardwell area and in the Cardwell township have raised objections to this development. Every one of them has been threatened by Mr Williams.

PARA.TAB: Other tourist operators in the area, who also have raised questions about the development, immediately are threatened by Mr Williams. In telephone conversations that I have had with Mr Williams, I have been threatened, as have other people. I find it interesting that certain members of the Liberal Party are prepared to back someone whose main strategy in proceeding with such a development is always to threaten whenever he receives any objections or questions about such development. When it is suggested that there might be a delay to the development to enable a proper environmental assessment, he threatens to go ahead on the old permits which were issued. I wonder whether Mr Williams is a genuine developer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: Senator Woodley comes into this chamber and says that he has been threatened and alleges that Mr Williams has threatened a whole range of other people. I am not aware of Mr Williams; I know nothing about him. But it is a very serious charge for Senator Woodley to make, particularly as a senator for Queensland. That in itself is a very serious breach of privilege. If these sorts of charges and allegations are going to be made, they should be substantiated in some way.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: following up what Senator Kemp said, it is not unusual for Senator Woodley to make these claims—he did it once before; he said that a person had threatened him as a senator. There are avenues for him to do something about that. If he does not do something about that, he should withdraw that remark because it is an imputation against Mr Williams.
—It is not a question of order; it may be a matter of privilege.
—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I can produce the documentation which is required, but at this stage I am dealing with an issue that is before us and that is of more interest.

PARA.TAB: I have written to Mr Williams and offered to meet him to preserve the chance for appropriate development—that is a matter of correspondence between us—to preserve jobs at Cardwell, because that is certainly my concern as well as, I am sure, the concern of Senator Reynolds, and at the same time to preserve the environment. I have visited this particular place for many years, going back to at least 1969 when I was working in the area and I first visited the place. It is a very special place that certainly needs protection.

It needs protection because its environment is the reason why any tourist would want to visit the area—it is such a special place. I am sure that, if Mr Williams was really prepared to understand the questions, it would be possible to have the kind of development which would not only preserve the environment but also provide jobs in that area. The problem is that it is very hard to get a reasonable answer from Mr Williams, either to correspondence or to telephone conversations with him.

The questions which remain are of deep concern to the people of Queensland and are also of deep concern to people around the world. If only the developer and certain members of the Liberal Party were prepared to understand that it is not a competition between the environment and jobs. I reject utterly that assertion. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in this debate in relation to Hinchinbrook, Senator Ian Macdonald claimed that I was attempting to shut down the tourist industry. If Senator Macdonald would put his two neurons in contact, if he can, and listen to the logic, I will explain to him exactly what I said this morning. It comes not from a recommendation from me that tourism be shut down, but is just a logical conclusion to be drawn from no less than 2,500 scientists in the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change who have thrice recommended that we should reduce our greenhouse gas emissions by 60 per cent to 80 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The figures are quite clear: take the consumption of energy in Australia, divide it by the population and then take 75 per cent of that. That comes to 50 gigajoules per year per person if we are going to address the greenhouse problem. That comes incontrovertibly, through quite simple mathematics, out of this recommendation by 2,500 scientists.

With 50 gigajoules per person per year, it is not possible to bring people by air from Japan, Ireland or anywhere else in the world. If Senator Macdonald wants to go ahead with a greenhouse world where the climate changes and everything else, and totally ignore the advice of 2,500 scientists in that respect, he can do so. But he should not claim that I am making claims on my own behalf. I am simply drawing absolutely logical mathematical conclusions from those recommendations.

This bears very much on Hinchinbrook and other major developments, because ultimately they are dependent upon large international tourism. The point I was making this morning was simply that we need to take the greenhouse considerations into account if we are to properly address that problem.

In relation to Hinchinbrook, there is no doubt that this is a totally out-of-scale development in an area which would be dependent upon precisely this sort of tourism; but the local impacts are the things that are of great concern to people up there. Again, I draw attention just to the impacts on the mangrove areas. I actually heard Mr Williams on the 7.30 Report the other night say that the mangrove areas were a `stinking mess'. Yet most biologists, most people who know about mangroves, recognise that they are the most important breeding areas for so many species in the marine environment. Very often they form the base of the food chain of many of the species upon which the recreational activities—fishing and so on—of the tourists would actually depend.

In his report, Peter Valentine drew particular attention to the fact that these are very important seagrass beds. We know that we have dugongs in this area, and dugongs are a threatened species. This is one of the few places in the world where dugongs still exist in reasonable numbers. Yet clearly, in clearing this channel and having lots of boats going out there, the impacts will—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are making it up!

—I am not making it up, Senator Parer; this is in the Valentine report. He is drawing attention to the impacts of the excessive amount of boating, the dredging of the channel out into the Hinchinbrook Channel, and the impact of those large numbers of people and boats and their activities on that very important area which in fact sits between a couple—not just one, but a couple—of World Heritage areas. It is associated with the wet tropics World Heritage area as well as the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage area. In fact, Peter Valentine suggests that it should be included in the wet tropics area. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 168, I move:

PARA.TAB: That the document Senator Coulter quoted from be tabled.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the Valentine report.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—I ask Senator Coulter whether he quoted from the document and whether he has that document in his possession.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have here three pages of the executive summary, which I am quite happy to table. I was reading from those three pages.
—Could I speak to my motion? I thank Senator Coulter for the offer—

—It is not possible to speak to the motion now because the time for that particular debate, on which I have not yet put the question, has expired. Senator Coulter has indicated that he will table the document.
—Could I take a point of order under standing order 168? This has nothing to do with the time limits on the debate we were having; this is an entirely separate motion. The standing order says that:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) A document quoted by a Senator . . . may be ordered to be laid on the table.
And:
(3) An order under paragraph . . . (2) may be made by motion without notice moved immediately on the conclusion—
immediately on the conclusion—
of the speech of the Senator who quoted the document.

Senator Coulter having finished his speech, I felt compelled by standing order 168(3) immediately to move that the document be tabled and that the original business be suspended until we deal with the motion under standing order 168(3).

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that because the time has expired for taking note of that answer, and because this was part of that particular debate, it was within the time limits for that debate. The time for that debate has expired. You are able to move the motion but you are not able to speak to it—that is the advice I have been given.
—I seek leave to make a contribution of about one minute on the motion.
—Is leave granted?
—No.
—Leave is not granted. Senator Coulter, do you wish to seek leave to table the document?
—I seek leave to table the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. Senator Macdonald clearly wants all the documents that are in the chamber which are held by Senator Coulter, not just the three pages he waved around. Can we have an assurance from Senator Coulter that he has only three pages from that report with him in the chamber?
—I think Senator Coulter indicated that. I will ask him to clarify that.
—That is exactly the situation. I have the executive summary which is what I was quoting from, and that is what I have tabled—three pages.

—I take a point of order. I wonder if you could clarify for me, Mr Acting Deputy President, whether Senator Coulter is in a position to table that document in view of the fact that it has not yet been released by the minister. I wonder how Senator Coulter and Senator Kernot have come by that document when it has not been publicly released, and when it is not available to me, of course. Particularly, perhaps, you should rule whether a document illegally come by can in fact be tabled in the Senate.

—I asked the Senate whether leave was granted; the Senate granted leave. I will not proceed with Senator Macdonald's original motion now because the document has been tabled—if that course of action is satisfactory to him.
—I would prefer you to put the motion. It makes no difference but it formalises the record.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), to a question asked by Senator Ian Macdonald this day, relating to the Port Hinchinbrook development.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—The President has received a letter from Senator Ferguson proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

The short sightedness of Labor Government policy leading to the retrenchment of CSIRO scientists at a time when science and research is vitally important to a competitive and successful Australian economy.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to quote to the Senate from an article by Julian Cribb in the Australian on 30 August this year:

SPEECH.PARA: If they gave gold medals for national commitment for science, this country wouldn't even make the semi-finals. It lies 18th in the OECD, and quite a few Asian nations are also zipping past.

Many recent reports such as this have served to highlight the short-sightedness of the federal Labor government in the area of funding for the CSIRO. The government's policy has effectively slashed the CSIRO budget, and this is leading to a significant number of retrenchments. This has had a particularly severe impact on agricultural research.

PARA.TAB: Prior to highlighting some of the reports on this matter, I wish to bring to the Senate's attention a number of statements which have been made by the chief executive of the CSIRO and by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) in recent committee hearings. In Estimates Committee D on 26 May 1994, Dr Stocker said that as a result of a shortfall per annum in the next triennium of $20.5 million:

SPEECH.PARA: We estimate that the consequence of that will be approximately 100 positions in the next financial year and, across the whole triennium, around 200.
At the same estimates committee hearing, responding to a question from my colleague Senator Gibson regarding redundancies, Senator Cook said:

I understand that most of any staff change in CSIRO will occur by natural effluxion of attrition rather than by any particular program of targeted redundancies. I know that in the way in which all this then gets debated the most dramatic and most threatening scenario is put in centre stage as the most likely or probable scenario. In fact, that is not true.
They are Senator Cook's words from the same estimates committee hearing. In Estimates Committee D on 23 June, Dr Stocker stated:

I can give you more accurate figures. The reduction in positions, according to Dr Donald's figures for the Institute of Animal Production and Processing, would be from the present number of 1,554 to 1,416 over the three years, only three of which would be research staff.

I would like to reiterate that at that hearing Dr Stocker stated that the reduction over the three years would include only three research staff. I have received advice in the last week that letters were sent to 200 staff members of CSIRO's division of animal production alone. I am informed that these letters included 30 redundancy notices in this one division, and three research scientists in one state, Western Australia, received these redundancy notices.

PARA.TAB: This raises a legitimate question, and it is a question for which I will be seeking a definitive answer. Does this mean that no other research scientist in the division of animal production located in states other than Western Australia has received a redundancy notice? Further, does it mean that no more research scientists will be made redundant in the next three years, bearing in mind the words of the chief executive in the estimates committee on 23 June?

There can be no doubt that scientific research is vital to the present and future health of the Australian economy, yet this Labor government sees fit to follow a funding policy which causes the retrenchment of CSIRO scientists at this time. We are now seeing the absolute abandonment by this Keating government of Mr Hawke's promise to make Australia the clever country. Those words have never been followed by action, and the government has now gone one step further and chewed those words up and spat them out in the face of the research science community. If there has ever been an area in which Australia has a comparative advantage over our trading partners, it is in the area of scientific research and its application, particularly in the field of agriculture. The government has jeopardised this comparative advantage by further adding to the brain drain in the research science community. In evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on 2 August 1994, a divisional chief said:

SPEECH.PARA: Despite what was said earlier, we are losing excellent scientists. In the last few weeks one of my senior managers took early retirement.
He went on to say:
We are losing people of that calibre, so there is no doubt that we have a significant problem.
An article from the Australian on 30 August this year regarding the resignation of Dr Stocker states:

Close associates of Dr Stocker were yesterday in no doubt his resignation was the result of cumulative frustration from cuts to CSIRO, internal and external recrimination, perpetual indecisive political tinkering and an "aura of constant criticism" made worse by lack of policy direction.
The article goes on to quote the President of the Australian Academy of Science, Sir Gustav Nossal, who said:
His resignation should give the Government cause to look at its commitment to science in this country. The science budget has essentially been flat for 10 years.

This fact was highlighted in evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on 2 August when, in answer to a question that was raised by my colleague Senator Coulter, Dr Stocker stated:
. . . we are well behind the world's best, most effective, rapidly developing nations in terms of world trade in research funding.

As a percentage of gross domestic product, public and private investment in research and development, Australia is at 1.35 per cent of gross domestic product. This is significantly lower than countries such as Japan, at 2.9 per cent; the UK, at 2.1 per cent; and the United States, at 2.7 per cent. In another submission to the Senate standing committee's inquiry, the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research stated:

Evaluations of the research outcomes of ten projects in the product/technology category have recently been completed by CSIRO (Johnson et al 1992). These revealed the remarkable figures of a return of $2.371 billion for an outlay of $161 million, equivalent to a cost:benefit ratio of 1:15 at a 5% discount rate. There is little doubt that the national public-good figures will be even more remarkable. It seems remarkable that CSIRO should be investing less in sectors that give such a great return on an investment of public funds. It would be far more logical for the organisation to maintain and even enhance its investment in this area, while at the same time be pulling out all stops to achieve greater funding overall. Such an increase could then be used to strengthen the research effort in manufacturing, mining and information technology.

That was part of the submission that was put to us by the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. Along with these figures and reports that have been highlighted—particularly in relation to the inquiry that is going on at present, but also in relation to other events that have taken place over time—it would seem that the concern that is being experienced throughout the science community, particularly within CSIRO, is having an effect on the morale of people within the various divisions and is causing a feeling of uncertainty for these research scientists who consider themselves to be a part of the contribution to the clever country of Australia in the future.

PARA.TAB: In all of the evidence that we have heard so far in this inquiry and in the various discussions that have taken place, there has been mention of the uncertainty of research science, particularly within CSIRO which, as the premier research body recognised worldwide for the quality of work and research that is being done, has certainly come under duress. I would like to conclude by again quoting Sir Gustav Nossal. The Bulletin on 30 August reported that, at the national science and industry forum, Sir Gustav said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is through fundamental research that the truly major breakthroughs come, which subsequently fertilise more practical developments.
The federal Labor government stands condemned for its short-sightedness in failing to take this advice and its attitude towards research science in Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —It comes as a surprise that this matter is before the Senate today for two reasons. Firstly, the government does not accept the conclusion and the statement made in this proposal. Secondly, as has been mentioned in the previous contribution, there is an inquiry under way. I understand that Senator Ferguson is the acting chairman of that inquiry, and I express my surprise that he can come to a conclusion by asserting this position in the Senate today before the inquiry is completed, and before the evidence is—
—We have seen enough.

—Senator Panizza says that the opposition has seen enough, but it has not seen all the evidence. How can opposition senators come to a conclusion before seeing all the evidence? Why do we have these Senate committee inquiries, if opposition senators come in here in a half-baked way and assert a position before the inquiry is completed? Why bother to have these inquiries in the first place? I could understand if a debate was initiated after the inquiry had been completed and opposition senators were attempting to assert a position based on all the evidence, but the opposition has not done that. That is the second reason why I express my concern and surprise at the fact that we are debating this matter today.

PARA.TAB: I will move on to the substance of the matter. Senator Ferguson quoted an article by Julian Cribb in the Australian. With due respect to some of my good friends in the gallery, I forewarn Senator Ferguson never to quote a journalist as an authoritative source. I would have thought that in politics that is one of the first lessons learnt. The important thing is to go to source documents and not use the journalist as the source in order to support a case.

Senator Ferguson asserted that funding to the CSIRO had been slashed; that there have been significant reductions in agricultural research, not just by the CSIRO but generally; and that there have been significant redundancies. That is the crux of his assertion and the crux of his matter of public importance before the Senate today. Nothing could be further from the truth. Total support for R&D innovation, including direct support through appropriations and the estimated effects of tax revenue forgone, is expected to be $539 million in 1994-95, a real increase of five per cent and a continuation of the substantial support in this area over the past decade.

The major component of this increase is an estimated increase in the effect on business R&D of revenue forgone through the industrial R&D tax incentive which increased to $395 million from $377 million. The cooperative research centre program is addressing the need for interaction between researchers and industry, government agencies and universities. Funds for specific R&D grants, rural R&D, National Health and Medical Research Council grants, other health R&D and small R&D grant schemes together rise to $300 million, up five per cent in real terms. I could go on and quote the real increases in general research funding and commitments made by this government but there is no need. Across the board there have been real increases under this government.

Australia's aggregate national expenditure on R&D substantially increased in the 1980s, reaching $5,109 million or 1.34 per cent of gross domestic product in 1990-91. That was the highest level on record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you need to sack scientists?

—I will get to the sacking of scientists in a moment. There is no doubt that our current research expenditure levels are the highest on record. This record level of R&D will continue, given the huge increase in business R&D expenditure in the first results reported in the 1992-93 national R&D survey. We might have hoped that R&D would increase at a faster rate—I do not think anyone here would disagree with that—but finding the funding is another thing. Generally, R&D in our economy has continued to grow in real terms.

PARA.TAB: I recall debating the issue of general funding to the CSIRO, at least in the agricultural context, on a previous occasion. Budget support for recurrent CSIRO expenditure has hovered around $400 million in constant dollar terms over the last 15 years. Budget support for CSIRO capital expenditure has varied significantly over that period, reflecting decisions to establish major new facilities. I hope that no-one will assert that the rise and fall of capital expenditure necessarily affects CSIRO program outcomes.

The CSIRO currently earns around $250 million from external sources. Over the past few years the CSIRO has generally allocated the larger share of its appropriation funds—about 40 per cent—to rural research. But I think it is important to emphasise that over the last ten years—the period of the Labor government—the moneys that have gone into CSIRO agricultural research, the area with which Senator Ferguson was primarily concerned in his contribution to this debate, are not the only moneys going to agricultural research. We have to look at all the money spent in the area of agricultural research.

I think the opposition, some sections of the research community and possibly even the broader community believe in the myth that the CSIRO receives the bulk of agricultural research money. That is not so. The government allocates moneys to a wide variety of areas. Over the last decade this government has established a number of rural R&D corporations. A few examples, by no means all of them, are: cotton, dairy, fisheries, grains, grape and wine, horticulture, land and water, meat, pig R&D—a favourite topic of Senator Baume—sugar, wool and the Rural Industry Research and Development Council, which was specifically set up to deal with those areas not covered by other rural research corporations. There are others such as honeybee and tobacco—I could go on. Almost all of those research councils have been set up by this government.

In 1984-85, shortly after we were elected to government, total Commonwealth contributions—this is without industry contributions, which are significant—were $35.72 million a year. What was the contribution in the last financial year? It had grown to $128 million a year. Then there are other areas, such as the cooperative research centres. There is no doubt—it cannot be refuted—that the total financial contribution to agricultural research in this country has increased.

Australian government science agencies are undergoing a cultural shift. They are moving to strengthen collaboration with industry. It is no longer simply science for science's sake. Collaboration is expected to result in more exploitable scientific outcomes to stimulate industry to perform more research.

There has been a specific criticism about CSIRO staff cut-backs. I have with me the latest available figures. In the CSIRO in 1985, the number of equivalent full-time units—a term I hate but which is used to describe full-time positions—was 3,007. Last year the number of equivalent full-time positions was 3,117, so there has been a slight increase.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about last week's figures?

—Yes, I understand that changes within the CSIRO were recently foreshadowed, but that does not mean there has been a reduction in agricultural research across the entire economy or in this government's contribution to agricultural research. If redundancies do occur—and I have not seen any evidence of it yet—that does not mean that those people will not contribute to research in an ongoing way. Given this government's contribution to agricultural research in other areas, and particularly given its very impressive record of expanding the amount of money allocated to research, they are more than likely to be employed in other research projects.

PARA.TAB: I think that is the crux of the government's case. Senator Murphy will be on the inquiry, the outcome of which Senator Ferguson is pre-empting with this matter today and by coming to a conclusion before the inquiry is conducted. Senator Murphy will be making a contribution based not only on the evidence that he has seen but also on other materials that he has before him.

Before I conclude, it would be interesting to look at one aspect of the opposition's policy contribution in this area, as scant as it has been to date. The opposition recently released a document, called `Things that something or other'—I have not heard the title lately—outlining the strategies upon which its policy will be developed. It denies that it is a policy document. Page 21 of that document is devoted to science and technology and is headed `At the cutting edge.' In view of the current shambles in the opposition, I suppose that is an appropriate description of its science and technology policy. In addition to some general platitudes about science and technology, it makes the point that its key role will be to stop the brain drain of scientists from Australia. There has been no brain drain from Australia. Australia has been experiencing a substantial brain gain, not brain drain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not on your side.

—Senator Ferguson should worry about the drain on his side, not on the government's side. We have only to look at the shambles in the opposition over the last few months to worry about the drain on the honourable senator's side.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order on the grounds of relevance. This is a debate on research—it has nothing to do with what any political party may do behind its closed doors. I ask you to tell the parliamentary secretary to get back to the debate.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—I will listen closely, but I do not think the parliamentary secretary has wandered too far off the track. He was responding to an interjection, which equally could have been off the track, too.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for your ruling, Mr Acting Deputy President. Judging from that contribution, there is a serious brain drain in the Senate. Over the last 10 years Australia has experienced a net influx, not a brain drain, of more than 28,000 engineers, scientists and academics. Every year over the last 10 years there has been a net gain of scientists coming into this country.

PARA.TAB: The extent of this inflow can be gauged by a comparison with the output of degree completions from Australian universities. By 1992 the net annual influx amounted to about 18 per cent of all science and engineering degree completions in Australia. Of course, this is not to say that there are no shortages in some specialist fields but, nevertheless, we are clearly experiencing a very considerable gain in overall terms. Yet the opposition dished up this sort of nonsense in a document—it is certainly not a policy document—which the opposition would now prefer to forget and certainly the public has forgotten.

I do not need to speak for my full time in this debate. While we continue to have these sorts of contributions from this shambles of an opposition, which refuses to develop policy and, when it tries to, cannot even get the title right, we do not have to take our full time in debates of this nature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it was Benjamin Disraeli who said there are lies, damn lies and statistics. I rather reject most of the figures which the minister has just mentioned.
—Where are they wrong?

—I will put down a few other figures which are official figures from the government's own sources. Let me begin by quoting what was said last week by a very senior scientist—I cannot quote him word for word because we do not have the Hansard from last week—when giving evidence to an inquiry. What he said went something along these lines: we are losing our intellectual science capital in Australia and, if something is not done, we will totally exhaust our intellectual science capital. Our science capital is not being replaced. With various modifications, those are the expressions of concern which we have heard from scientist after scientist after scientist in CSIRO—that senior people with many years of experience are leaving the organisation.

PARA.TAB: I would like to extend very slightly the wording of the motion. The motion begins with the words, `The shortsightedness of Labor Government policy.' I would like to include the word `science', making it `science policy', because I think that is what the motion relates to. If one conducted an inquiry among the university science faculties, one would find exactly the same thing. If one went into the medical research institutions around Australia, again one would find exactly the same thing. Of course, that is what Sir Gustav Nossal was referring to.

The figures are quite clear. These are the government's figures, and they are not really in dispute. We are, as Senator Ferguson said, spending only 1.35 per cent of GDP on science research and development. That does not compare well with the OECD average. We claim that we are a member of the OECD; we are one of those 24 nations. The OECD average is 1.87 per cent. So we are well below the average. If we compare Australia with other countries we find that the US spends 2.78 per cent, Japan spends 2.85 per cent and Sweden spends 2.54 per cent. I do not think the government will contest those figures; they are from its own document. It indicates that over the whole range of science activity in this country we are performing very poorly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where does the money come from?

—I will pick up Senator Murphy's point: 0.57 per cent of GDP comes from private industry, which, I agree, compares poorly with the OECD average—it is roughly half—of 1.05 per cent. Therein, of course, lies a problem. But the government is saying to industry, `You have to pick up the tab,' and yet evidence after evidence indicates that so many of our major companies in Australia are now foreign owned, that they do their research overseas and that they are not spending the amount of money that they should be spending in Australia. They are spending it elsewhere. Therefore, it behoves the government to relatively increase its expenditure if we are going to meet the sorts of targets that we need to meet.

PARA.TAB: What I am saying also applies to areas other than basic science. I have an editorial from the journal Science of 6 May 1994. John Armstrong, the former IBM vice-president for research, speaks of the costs of research representing only five per cent of the cost of creating a successful product. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: He asserted that world leadership in basic research will confer a competitive advantage only if it is coupled with world-class performance in the extensive set of skills, institutions, and investments that are required for the creation of economic wealth.

We need to spend a great deal more. Given that Australian industry is not spending the money in the R&D area, government must come in and fill that gap or we will simply lose again and again the applications of our basic science overseas.

PARA.TAB: But there are other indications that we are not performing well. I turn again to an official document, the 1993 national report on Australia's higher education sector, which ranked 36 of our universities from all states except Tasmania in the order of the minimum access scores for those commencing undergraduate courses. The ranking is in a range from one to five, with five being the highest.

Medicine scored one in every university; law scored one in all but four universities, in which it scored two; science did not score one in a single university. In other words, we have so degraded the teaching of science in our universities that we do not have a single university in Australia that can attract the highest quality of students. If we average these scores across all institutions, we find that science scored 4.2 on this scale of five, which was only marginally better than the least attractive entrance, which was nursing at 4.5.

It is not surprising that this is happening. The attitude that government is presenting to students who might otherwise go into science is, `Why go into science? There is not much point in going into science; there is no future in science. They are shedding their senior staff and the quality of science is falling. Let us go into something else.'

Looking at it another way and comparing the quartiles going into various faculties, we find that almost 99 per cent of students who went into medicine came from the upper quartile, whereas some 22 per cent of students in that upper quartile went into science; none from the lower quartile went into medicine; and some 26 or 28 per cent from the lowest quartile went into science. Again, on that measure of the attractiveness of science, this government has failed. It has failed not just in respect of CSIRO; it has failed in the universities and it is failing generally.

The third index that I think is quite impossible to refute is the index that comes from the recent work of Professor Bourke at the ANU, where he has looked at the relative science citation index in Australia over the last 10 years. To measure not just the number of publications but the effectiveness of those publications, one looks at the number of times a publication is cited by other people. That is a measure of the value of that research generally to other science workers in the field. The work of Bourke, looking at that relative science citation index over time, indicates that, while it was well maintained up until about 1987-88, from that time onwards it has actually dropped by eight per cent. That is a dramatic increase in only a few short years.

In some areas, for example, the very area that the government is trying to support most intensely—the telecommunications and electronics area—it has dropped by 40 per cent. So the quality of our work is really going down the gurgler. When we put all these things together, it is absolutely irrefutable, I believe, that the perceptions of those scientists who have come before our committee expressing these deep concerns, are well grounded in a very factual base.

There is conflicting evidence before the committee about the cutbacks in CSIRO. The first time Dr Stocker came before the committee, I put to him that he had lobbied before the last budget claiming that CSIRO needed $60 million simply to maintain its expenditure where it would be had expenditure been maintained at the 1983 level, taking into account inflation. He went on to admit that they in fact had been cut by slightly over $20 million. When I put to him that that amounts to $80 million per year each year for the next triennium, he agreed.

It is certainly true, as we have heard from the government, that more recently the government has attempted to cover its tracks and claim that expenditure in the rural areas has been increased. Frankly, the figures do not add up. The initial evidence is clear and I think it indicates that CSIRO has indeed been cut.

To conclude, I think that the state of science in Australia is extremely parlous; the quality of our science is decreasing; the government is not recognising the seriousness of it; it is particularly pulling funds away from fundamental and basic research; and it needs to get back to and more strongly support research. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I commend Senator Ferguson on bringing this important matter to the parliament today, which is put in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The short sightedness of Labor Government policy leading to the retrenchment of CSIRO scientists at a time when science and research is vitally important to a competitive and successful Australian economy.

Secondly, can I say how disappointing it is that the Australian Labor government has failed to recognise the substance of this matter—and that is that science and technology, and the application of science and technology, are so vital to the future of a competitive Australia.

PARA.TAB: It is particularly tragic that this government has cut $60 million from CSIRO's budget over a period of three years. Australia's premier scientific organisation, a body with a strong international reputation, having its funding slashed so enormously demonstrates in very vivid terms the low priority that this government attaches to science. Probably in no other way could the government more vividly demonstrate that low priority.

This matter has been raised today because it coincides with notices being sent out retrenching Australian scientists, putting Australian scientists out of work as a result of this government's deliberate policy. That is why it is important that Senator Ferguson bring this matter to the Senate for debate today.

I have met with some of those scientists as I have travelled around the country visiting CSIRO establishments. I have talked to them about their work, their training, their hopes and their dreams, and their frustration at having those dreams and hopes shortened as a result of this foolish policy. Young scientists, not just old scientists, are losing work in an environment where there is not a lot of other opportunity. The figures show that, unfortunately, the contribution of industry to science in this country is still low.
