If we want both basic research and, in many cases, applied research, we are still reliant on government, and yet government is cutting back this funding to CSIRO and these scientists are being put out of work.

The government responded, although I do not think Senator Sherry was well briefed. If a minister had bothered to attend—I accept that Senator Cook is unwell—he would have no doubt used the argument that it is not so much the scientists that are being retrenched but the technicians and administrative staff. But the technicians are, in many cases, just as important to the success of scientific development as are the more highly academically qualified scientists. They are absolutely critical to the maintenance of the scientific programs and it is, therefore, an inadequate response by the government to say that it is others, rather than the most senior scientists, who are losing their jobs.

The whole position of CSIRO is extremely worrying. The chief executive has just announced that he is not prepared to take an extra term, which was a blow to the organisation. It is not just the frustration of having its funding cut. The difficulties that have come about with the shift of headquarters from Canberra to Melbourne—in fact, the body seems to operate two headquarters at the moment—and the very expensive legal actions that have come out of attempts to commercialise CSIRO without giving the scientists and support staff an adequate administrative or legal background to do so, have also had an effect on reducing morale within that important organisation.

But perhaps what has hit CSIRO more than anything else has been the attitude of this government, the attitude of the previous minister, Senator Schacht and, more recently, his successor, Senator Cook. Perhaps I could do no better than to refer to one of the important publications in this area, `Scitech'—Science Technology is its full name—which, in its current edition of September of this year, stated:

There has . . . been increasingly political interference in CSIRO starting with Senator Schacht who tried to impose his own agenda on the CSIRO Board . . . His successor Senator Cook, although much more low key, has also imposed political pressures by forbidding CSIRO to brief opposition politicians without informing his office and having a member of his staff present.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook, in effect, sought to oppose that agenda. There is nothing wrong with that, but he did so without proper briefing or understanding of the issues. He sought to restructure CSIRO from a basis of being poorly informed. Senator Schacht believed he knew better, did not listen to advice, made an awful mess of the administration of the portfolio and, of course, had to be removed. Senator Cook, who sees political evil around every corner, has had to adopt very much the thought police approach. Although I could say that he seems to have waived it in relation to CSIRO briefings to me, he has not done so in relation to others, and I think that is a matter of great regret.

PARA.TAB: I guess the resignation very recently of Ms Pat Kennedy from CSIRO is just another demonstration of this government's attitude. There is no doubt that, in effect, she was forced out by her active involvement in pursuing the interests of the nation in science, and CSIRO in particular, in the parliamentary process, which was her job. But because her views were in conflict with those of Senator Schacht, in the first instance, and Senator Cook, more recently, the government preferred her to go rather than have her pursue her very worthwhile work. That is a matter of great regret.

It is about time that this government recognised that science and technology is critically important to this country. The government should fund it appropriately, recognise that CSIRO is a body of which we should be proud and which requires proper financial support, and address seriously the issues raised in this matter rather than attempt to dismiss them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say that I am not quite sure why this matter is before the chamber, given that the opposition sought to have an inquiry, I think on a motion by Senator Panizza. We are only part way through it. I think that because things are not quite going the way those opposite thought they might and they are not quite getting the result they thought they might, they have decided to make a public exercise out of it.

PARA.TAB: Regarding what Senator Coulter said before, he seemed to emphasise the government's funding with respect to research in general, particularly as it related to educative university research, and so on. Certainly, in terms of what Commonwealth funding has been provided in the last 10 years, budget data shows that university research funding had reached $1.3 billion by 1993-94, and had grown in real terms by 67 per cent since this government came to office in 1983.

This compares with real increases of 53 per cent in all Commonwealth support for science and innovation over the same period. Again, Australia's output of scientific papers over the 12-year period to 1992 was 2.3 per cent of all world research papers. Per head of population, our output ranks eighth in the world. What has happened in this debate is that people have come in here and quoted very selectively from various things. Senator Ferguson said that we were ranked 18th in terms of public expenditure but that is simply not the case—that is deliberately misleading. The fact is that we are ranked about sixth in terms of public expenditure.

It is very easy to use figures in the broad sense, but as Senator Coulter knows, in some of those other countries he is talking about there is much greater private sector investment in research. That is one problem we have in this country. I will give an example. When we talk about government policy, particularly when it is raised by the opposition, it is always appropriate to have a look at what the opposition's policy is. We have some information called `Creating an Innovative Culture' from the Fightback document of March 1993. I will quote one or two things from it. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The restructuring of the scientific and technological research bureaucracy so that it becomes an operational arm of government policy making a more effective means of coordinating planning linkages between the public research sector and industry groups.
It goes on further to talk about the role of government. It says:

The role of government is therefore, first and foremost, a strategic one; to ensure that policies across the range of portfolio areas are integrated to provide the optimal framework to encourage and facilitate research and development.

We know that the government has implemented a range of things. In particular, we introduced the 150 per cent tax deduction—and we have created the CRCs. The Liberals were going to abolish both of those things. When those opposite want to criticise the government for its policy, it would certainly pay them to look at the old adage that people in glasshouses should not throw stones. I am afraid their house has well and truly shattered on this issue.

PARA.TAB: As I said earlier, we are part way through an inquiry. On Friday, 2 September we took evidence from the senior executive of the CSIRO, John Stocker, and some of the directors of the institutes. I would like to quote from some evidence John Stocker gave. It relates to expenditure by the CSIRO. According to page 930 of the Hansard report he says:

SPEECH.PARA: This then gives a picture across the last triennium which demonstrates that, in appropriation terms and in sponsored research terms, the expenditure that CSIRO has afforded the rural industries has not changed dramatically.

Dr Stocker presented a range of diagrams. Those diagrams showed subsequently that there had generally been about a seven per cent increase in rural research funding. Again we hear claims about scientists being sacked. We can all make spurious claims here about why that might be the case. The opposition, of course, wants to blame the government. But we could look at a whole range of factors. A lot of the evidence that has been received by the committee is more a criticism of the management within the CSIRO than the funding.

PARA.TAB: I asked one of the witnesses from within the CSIRO about funding. I said, `Where do you get the view that the government has cut funding?' He said, `I read it in the newspaper.' The figures presented by the people who should know—that is, the senior executive officer and the directors—clearly demonstrate that that is not the case. Another important factor regarding research in this country is to try to get greater private sector input. The government has succeeded dramatically in that area, increasing the private sector input into research—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who has succeeded? They have to go and get it themselves.

—We have done it because we have been innovative about getting and encouraging. If some of those people on the other side had read the science and technology budget statement, they would not make some of the stupid claims that they do.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill raised a matter relating to Mrs Kennedy and attempted to blame the government for sacking her. As I understand it, the CSIRO wanted Mrs Kennedy to take a different form of employment. Mrs Kennedy chose not to take it. Some people in the CSIRO have a view that Mrs Kennedy may well have created a few problems for them; so they may not have wanted her to continue. The government has nothing to do with it.

This matter of public importance brought by Senator Ferguson is quite ridiculous, given that his colleague Senator Panizza did propose that we have a public inquiry. Those opposite really do not have the sort of evidence they thought they would get. They were totally and utterly politically motivated in their pursuit of this game. The evidence that has been forthcoming to the inquiry has not supported their claims. That was quite clear on Friday, 2 September because the people at the head of the CSIRO refuted them.

Let us take into account some of the circumstances. Senator Ferguson talks about asking questions in estimates committees. I suppose that some of the things that might impact on the CSIRO's capacity to employ people is that money that it has lost as a result of bad commercial decisions. I would think that a more appropriate place for us to conclude this debate is in the inquiry; that is where we should be doing this, not going on with this sort of crap and wasting the time of the Senate.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Senator Murphy, I ask you to withdraw that word.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is unparliamentary, I withdraw.

—At the outset I would like to take up the point raised by Senator Murphy and Senator Sherry that it was too early in the piece to debate a matter of public importance of this sort because a Senate committee inquiry relating to the CSIRO is still being conducted. The fact that an inquiry is being conducted has not stopped the government or the CSIRO board from proceeding with selling off farms, dismissing research scientists or cutting off their funding. So this is a very opportune time to tell the people of Australia what is happening while the inquiry is going on. That is exactly why we brought this matter on today.

PARA.TAB: Senator Murphy, in the limited time he had to speak—and he could not even use that properly—told us that the committee is not getting the sort of evidence that it had expected to get. I do not believe that we go into any inquiry expecting to be given any sort of evidence. We see what the evidence is and take it as it comes. I do not know whether Senator Murphy was at the meeting of the committee in Armidale—I do not believe he was there; if he was, he was there in presence only and not in mind, and he did not take any notice of what was going on. He will get his chance to take notice the week after next at Yallebee and in Western Australia as a whole, so I invite him to hold his comments until then.

The reason we proposed this matter of public importance today was to point out to the people of Australia what is coming out of the inquiry and to ask the CSIRO and the government to stop sacking people until we find out what is really going on. The terms of this matter of public importance is the short-sightedness of the government in its funding of CSIRO. The government has not only been short-sighted in the last 12 months, 18 months, two years or three years; it has been short-sighted on this matter ever since it came to government in 1983. This government will need something more than minor surgery to get it out of this situation. It will need to have a complete eye transplant if it is to see what is going on in CSIRO and what is causing the lack of research in Australia. That is why we asked for the inquiry in the first place.

Senator Murphy also accused me of being politically motivated in calling for this inquiry. He knows as well as I do that this inquiry is being conducted because we are reflecting the concern of CSIRO scientists and CSIRO personnel all around Australia. If he does not want to admit that, he should at least stop telling pork pies or something like that to the Senate.

This government has shown a lack of interest in CSIRO as is evidenced by the fact that in the last 4 1/2 years—Senator Childs, who is the chairman of the Senate committee that is conducting this inquiry and who is doing quite a good job, if I may say so, is laughing at the awkward position that Senator Murphy has got himself into—there have been five ministers in the game. During the time that Dr Stocker has been in charge of the CSIRO, he has had to deal with five different government ministers. No wonder he declined to take up the invitation to renew his contract. It is probably fortunate for him that he took that decision. He will go to a job with better pay anyhow, although he will be a loss to the CSIRO and to science right throughout Australia.

Furthermore, except for Mr Barry Jones from the other place, there has not been a minister in charge of the science portfolio, which takes in the CSIRO, who has had a scientific and technological background or even anything to do with industry. I believe it is essential for science ministers to have that background. Probably the only government minister in the last 10 years who had a grip on industry was former Senator John Button.

The CSIRO is not the only organisation that this government has neglected as far as research is concerned. That neglect goes through to university research, it goes through to medical research and it goes through to defence research. They have all suffered while most of the developing countries, let alone the developed countries, have doubled their research budgets in the last five years.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was your proposal—to reduce it again?

—Senator Murphy thought he read it out, but he should listen to what I have to say. I listened to him in silence—well, I think I did—so I wish he would do the same for me. He should take note of the further evidence that the committee will receive in the next six months before it brings down its report. If he does so, he might learn something about what is going on. I know that Senator Sherry laughs at some of the things that are said by Julian Cribb. Some time ago, Julian Cribb was quoted in the Australian as saying that if they gave gold medals for national commitment to science, this country would not even make the semifinals. I think that is true.

PARA.TAB: Let us consider job losses amongst scientists. Senator Coulter would probably agree that this was one of the concerns that brought about the inquiry. The Australian reported that according to Public Service Union spokesman, Peter O'Donoghue, 200 CSIRO jobs will be lost because of the recent $20 million budget cut. The truth has come out in the last couple of days that at least 100 jobs will be lost from three animal production units alone and another 65 from three of the six plant institute divisions and other parts of the agencies. The government has to get its priorities right.

In the limited time I have left, there are a couple of things I must tell the Senate. In the light of this shortfall, what did the government attempt to do to keep these scientists on? It costs about $190,000 to keep a scientist at the bench doing research. The government decided to sell off the research farms. On the face of it, even I thought that may be a way out, although I do not ever believe in selling off the farm because once one sells off the farm one is never in a position to buy it back within 12 months, even if it were available.

Farms in Yallebee and Armidale—and Senator Childs would be able to back me up on this—were set up for research. The government said, `Sell them off and lease other land.' I would like to know where land can be leased and how it would be set up for research. Those research places have paddocks down to four acres, three acres and one acre. The fencing, the sheds and the research laboratories are virtually worth more than the price of the land. (Time expired)

DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Crowley) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The introduction of this bill continues the historic process that began with the High Court's Mabo decision.
The government moved quickly to respond to that decision.
Last year Parliament passed the Native Title Act, giving legislative effect to the court's rejection of the doctrine of terra nullius, and its recognition of native title to land.

There is enormous symbolic value in the Mabo decision and the subsequent legislation. For the first time in our history, the inherent rights of indigenous Australians have been recognised and given statutory protection. These developments indicate that as a nation we are maturing; we are able to acknowledge the violence and destruction of our history since European occupation and to accept the responsibility we all have to work towards a new relationship. Much has been achieved, but justice has not yet been done.

Justice has not been done because the majority of Australia's indigenous people live on the margins of economic, social and cultural life in this country. We may ask how this can be so, in a country with one of the highest standards of living in the world, a country which prides itself on giving everyone a fair go. It is so, Mr President, because the vast majority of indigenous Australians have been dispossessed, either in whole or part, of that which is most precious to their sense of history and spirituality, that most essential component of their heritage—their land.

Contemporary western culture tends to view land as a commodity, something which can enrich us, not something which we must cherish and nurture, and which will in turn nurture us. It is difficult for non-indigenous Australians to understand what Australia's indigenous people feel about the loss of their land. It is difficult, therefore, to comprehend the extent of their dispossession. Nevertheless, we must try to comprehend it. Unless we understand the importance of land to indigenous peoples, we cannot come to terms with the extent of the loss.

Mr President, it is a great ambition of this government to establish a new relationship between indigenous Australians and the wider community. We established the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation to guide the nation towards greater understanding and justice, greater unity and universal respect for Australia's indigenous heritage. We introduced native title legislation in recognition that indigenous peoples owned the land before colonisation, and to facilitate the formal legal recognition of those native title interests which have never been extinguished.

The process however has just begun. The native title legislation, while of profound symbolic significance, will not benefit all indigenous peoples. Because most have been dispossessed they have been unable to maintain the continued association upon which proof of native title depends. We are now ready for another step; the step represented by this bill, which recognises the injustice flowing from dispossession, and goes some way towards redressing it by providing a means for indigenous communities to acquire, manage and maintain land.
The Land Fund is the first of the social justice measures to be formulated, and represents the major financial element in the government's proposed social justice measures.

There will be further measures on which the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and ATSIC will advise the government later this year. These measures will form part of the social justice package I announced when introducing the native title legislation, and which will be directed towards removing structural and institutional barriers to full participation in Australian economic life by its indigenous peoples, and towards safeguarding and developing indigenous culture.
Mr President, this legislation complements the native title legislation, and like that Act, the bill before the house is the product of wide-ranging consultation.

We sought the views of peak indigenous, farming, environmental, industry and church groups. I have had meetings with Aboriginal representatives and a measure of consensus has been reached on the main features of the bill. I have sought the views of Premiers and Chief Ministers, and of our colleagues on the other side of the house, as well as the Democrat and Green senators.

Our colleagues on the other side have expressed their opposition to the Land Fund, saying there are higher priorities in Aboriginal affairs. There are indeed many other things to be done, but we maintain that land ownership is fundamental to the well-being of the indigenous community, and should be addressed as a matter of priority. The benefits flowing from re-establishing indigenous attachment to the land will not only be cultural and social, but will lead to improved economic well-being. I hope the Opposition will be swayed in the interests of justice and equity, in the cause of righting historical wrongs, in the hope that we can deliver to future generations an Australia without the scars and stigma of the past.

The bill establishes the Land Fund and the Indigenous Land Corporation, with the purpose of enabling indigenous people to acquire land, and to manage and maintain it in a sustainable way to provide economic, social and cultural benefits for future generations. The Indigenous Land Corporation will be a new, independent and commercially oriented statutory body. The government has adopted this structure because such a corporation will ensure a dedicated focus on land matters and will have specialised expertise in land management, land use assessment and environmental issues.

In summary, the Land Fund will receive an allocation from consolidated revenue, pay to the Indigenous Land Corporation a specified amount each year for land acquisition and management, and invest the remainder. After ten years, it is intended that the investments made by the Land Fund will provide sufficient income to cover the allocations to the corporation, and Commonwealth contributions will cease.

The first instalment was allocated in this year's budget—$200 million into the fund, with $25 million to be paid to the corporation, and the remainder to be invested. The Fund will be set up as a Trust Account under the Public Account, and subject to the provisions of part 9 of the Audit Act. To make for a smooth transition, for the first three years, ATSIC will continue with its land acquisition and management programs, and will receive its annual allocation from the Land Fund. After this period, ATSIC's financial allocation will transfer to the Indigenous Land Corporation.

Using the monies paid to it by the Land Fund, the corporation will be responsible for acquiring land, and transferring it to indigenous communities. It may also make grants to indigenous organisations for the purpose of acquiring land.

The government is very much aware of the need for land to be managed in an effective manner. The corporation will therefore carry out an equally important function of promoting and supporting the sustainable management of indigenous-held land. It will do this mainly by entering into agreements with the land holders about the use and management of land; the corporation will have the flexibility to be able to take a direct role in the management of indigenous lands to the extent set down in the agreements. On occasions it may also provide direct grants to land holders for land management purposes. While the government accepts that not all indigenous people will seek to make profits from their ownership of land, we are concerned that they receive sufficient assistance and encouragement to manage their land in a sustainable way.

The operations of the Indigenous Land Corporation will be governed by a number of principles. It is to adopt a strategic approach, and where it operates on a commercial basis it will do so in line with sound business principles. In addition, in carrying out its functions, the corporation must have regard to maximising the employment of indigenous people and utilising indigenous enterprises.

The corporation will be required to prepare national and regional land strategies, covering three to five year periods, and dealing with land acquisition, management and environmental issues. Copies of the documents setting out these strategies will be available on request. Regional bodies including ATSIC Regional Councils will be involved in planning for acquisitions at the local level. The corporation will be able to establish subsidiaries to carry out its functions, allowing for direct participation by local indigenous representatives in land management activities in their area.

This legislation is designed to meet the aspirations of indigenous people and they must therefore have control over decisions made by the corporation. This is reflected in the structure of the board of directors administering the corporation. At least five of the members must be Aboriginal people or Torres Strait Islanders, and the Chairperson of ATSIC will be included as an ex officio member. In recognition of ATSIC's role as a significant vehicle for indigenous self-determination, at least one other member must be an ATSIC Commissioner. All the directors must have experience in land or environmental management, business or financial management, or in indigenous community life.

The corporation has significant powers to conduct its business in the interest of self-determination, including significant commercial functions. The Minister may request and obtain any information about the activities of the corporation. The Minister makes the appointments to the Board of Directors, in consultation with ATSIC and the Minister for Finance.

The Chief Minister of the Northern Territory has expressed reservations about the Land Fund. His concern is that land acquired under Land Fund provisions, and subject to normal title holding rules, will be claimed under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976, and thus lead to an inappropriate increase in land held under inalienable title. This will not result from the legislation before the house today. We have included in the legislation a clause prohibiting claims under the Land Rights Act being made in relation to land acquired by the Indigenous Land Corporation.

The Native Title Act provides for the establishment of the Land Fund, under s201. However, it does not provide enough scope for the establishment and operations of the Indigenous Land Corporation in the way we consider essential for an effective response to the need for land. That is why this bill was necessary.

As an interim measure, the Fund will be set up by regulations under the Native Title Act. We plan that the corporation begin operations on 1 January 1995, when this legislation comes into force, and s201 of the Native Title Act which sets up the Fund will be repealed.
There is a need for the interim arrangement as monies have already been allocated, and will have to be invested pending the establishment of the Indigenous Land Corporation under this bill.
ATSIC, as the body with primary responsibility for indigenous affairs, will from 1 January undertake the day to day administrative arrangements for the Fund.

Mr President, through millennia the indigenous people of this continent have demonstrated extraordinary strength and resilience, and never more so than in the past two hundred years. Since European settlement they have survived the alienation of their land, the destruction of their culture, brutality and disease, the heartbreaking severance of family and community bonds. They have survived, but the losses have been immeasurable and proof of the damage remains all too plainly to be seen. With the native title legislation, Australia took an historic step by finally acknowledging the truth that Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders were the original owners of the continent. In the legislation before the Senate today, we are giving the spirit of that legislation more tangible expression. We are creating the means by which land may be returned to Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders—and with the foundation of their traditions and identity thus partially restored, we trust that they may be able to protect and revitalise their communities, their culture and their heritage.
Mr President, I commend this bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION OF PROVIDERS AND FINANCIAL REGULATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Crowley) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill proposes to amend section 6A of the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act 1991 (the ESOS act) which relates to the operation of notified trust accounts. The bill proposes to amend subsection 6A(5) of the ESOS act to allow Regulations to be made which exempt providers, either in whole or in part, from the requirements concerning notified trust accounts under section 6A of the ESOS act. The amendment will provide more flexible arrangements for the exemption of providers from the requirement to operate a notified trust account.
The amendments are intended to strengthen the protection that the ESOS act offers international students and to ensure the international reputation and growth of this industry.

Section 6A of the ESOS act currently requires providers who are not exempt from the financial Regulations of the ESOS act, to pay into notified trust accounts all pre-paid course money received directly or indirectly from overseas students. The ESOS act also specifies that withdrawals or payments from notified trust accounts may not be made except in accordance with the Regulations under the ESOS act. Subsection 6A(5) of the ESOS act only allows Regulations to be made that exempt providers completely from the requirements to operate a notified trust account. Currently, there is no provision to make Regulations for partial exemption of providers from the requirements to operate a notified trust account. The aim of the bill is to amend the Regulation making power in section 6A so that Regulations can be made that will exempt providers either in whole or in part from the operation of section 6A.
The ESOS act was introduced in 1991 to provide both financial protection and quality assurance for international students in Australian institutions.

In 1993, the ESOS act was amended to enhance the quality and integrity of our educational products and to strengthen the protection the act offers to international students' pre-paid funds. The ESOS Regulations were also amended to include provisions relating to the operation of notified trust accounts and membership of a tuition assurance scheme (TAS)—the primary objective of which was to ensure that international students receive the education and training for which they paid.

The notified trust account and tuition assurance scheme Regulations were subject to a notice of motion of disallowance in the Senate and then referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training for consideration. Following that Committee's hearing, I proposed a package of amendments to the ESOS legislation to address industry concerns about the Regulations. This included amending the trust account Regulations to meet industry's concerns about agents' commissions and enrolment fees, in return for retaining the tuition assurance scheme provisions in a modified form to meet the Government's concern for a safety net.

As part of the package, the tuition assurance scheme Regulations have been amended, without the further need to amend the ESOS act. Representations from major industry associations to my Department indicate their support for these amendments.

Advice from Attorney-General's Department indicated that, in order to amend the trust account Regulations, subsection 6A(5) of the ESOS act would first have to be amended. The bill before Parliament therefore seeks to amend the ESOS act to give effect to my proposals to address industry concerns about the trust account Regulations.

The growth of Australia's international education industry depends on the confidence that students overseas have in the quality of the courses they undertake and the protection of the monies they invest in receiving an Australian education. The confidence of students is fundamental to the credibility and viability of the industry which accounts for over $1 billion in export earnings.
I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Crowley) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 (the act) in accordance with 1994-95 Budget Decisions and other decisions made by the Government in respect of higher education.

The bill's provisions include an amendment to repayment arrangements for certain students under the Higher Education Contribution Scheme—HECS. The measure, which will come into effect on 1 January 1995, will require that people who leave full-time education for the first time have their HECS debt for that financial year calculated on a pro-rata basis in accordance with the proportion of the year spent in the work force.

This provision, which is estimated to bring forward $15 million in HECS revenue in the period 1995-96 to 1997-98 alone, will shorten the repayment period for affected students without increasing the size of the debt for any person. As importantly, it addresses an anomaly in present HECS repayment arrangements by ensuring consistency with the Income Tax Rates Act 1986 which pro-rates the standard tax-free threshold for people who leave full-time education for the first time. It should be noted that as these arrangements only apply to persons leaving full-time education from 1 January 1995, few people will be affected by the changes in the 1994-1995 financial year.

The bill will amend Section 17 to increase the amount of maximum grant available for operating purposes in 1993 as well as transfer funds from the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 for appropriation under the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act 1989. However, the total amount provided by the Commonwealth to institutions for operating purposes has not changed. Although the total amount legislated under Section 17 has increased, this is offset by a corresponding decrease in the amount provided to institutions from the HECS Trust Account. The variation reflects a lower than anticipated Commonwealth contribution required to discharge student liabilities in 1993.

Other amendments to the act put forward in this bill include minor modifications to the Open Learning Deferred Payment Scheme. These amendments will clarify some operational characteristics of the scheme. In particular, it will remove the current restriction on the number of units for which an eligible client may defer payment in the first semester to allow students to defer payment for up to a maximum of 8 study units for any two consecutive semesters. Further the amendments will clarify that the amount of basic charge payable by students under the Open Learning Deferred Payments Scheme for a study unit in the December/March semester is the amount payable for study units in the following semesters.

Finally, the bill seeks to amend the definition of `Overseas Student'. Currently members of certain foreign armed forces enter Australia in the course of their duties and are considered under the act to be HECS liable students. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs treats these members of the armed forces as temporary residents. For consistency, it is more appropriate that these individuals are regarded as full fee-paying students.

The bill includes a range of provisions to correct anomalies in previous amendments to the act which are of a technical nature and should be rectified so that a consolidated version of the act can be printed.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and commend the bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Telecom: Network and Customer Issues and Telephone Affordability

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to Telecom and to move to take note of the statement and two related documents.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will recall that on 24 March of this year my colleague the Minister for Communications and the Arts, the Hon. Michael Lee, provided the House with details of the government's response, to that time, to allegations that Telecom had monitored and recorded telephone conversations of certain customers without their consent. He indicated at that time that he would report back to the parliament on all of these matters. On 29 August Senator Bourne tabled a number of documents in the Senate concerning these and other issues related to Telecom's performance of service.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this statement today is to report progress on Telecom network and customer issues, including those raised by Senator Bourne, and to inform the Senate of government initiatives to expedite the basic goals of ensuring that all Australians have access to a telephone service that is affordable and works to world-class standards and that our telephone carriers conform to the highest standards of ethical behaviour and customer service.

The criminal investigation which the Minister for Communications and the Arts initiated in January into allegations that Telecom had recorded phone calls of certain customers without their consent is still being finalised. The report of the Australian Federal Police investigating team is under examination by the Director of Public Prosecutions. The later allegations by Mr Robert Bray that his telephone conversations were monitored without his consent also remain under investigation, and it is important that nothing is said or done which would in any way attempt to intervene or pre-empt the finding of these investigations. I can, however, assure honourable senators that the government will take whatever action is necessary arising from the completion of these investigations.

Turning to the government's further initiatives, let me first deal with the performance of the telephone network. It is essential that the overall performance of each of Australia's carrier networks be of a high standard and meet consumer expectations. Carrier network performance should be measured independently against appropriate minimum standards that apply to residential and business customers and metropolitan and country residents.

The Minister for Communications and the Arts will ask Austel to accelerate its current development of end-to-end network performance standards with a view to having these in place by early 1995. The Austel network performance standards will be mandatory, and failure to comply with these standards will be a breach of the carriers' licence conditions. Austel will monitor performance against these standards and will also review them to ensure that they reflect the changing telecommunications environment. There has been, and will continue to be, consumer input into this process through Austel's Standards Advisory Committee.
Austel will, in addition, improve the information content of its quarterly quality of service report. This development will focus on

SPEECH.PARA: switched telephone network performance for customers and will seek to provide information on a wider range of services and quality of service measures than presently reported. Austel intends to consult with consumers and major users in this development. Austel will develop a capability independent of the carriers to monitor compliance with these mandatory standards and will be empowered to appoint independent consultants.

PARA.TAB: Another important issue is the ongoing modernisation of telecommunications networks in Australia, including that of Telecom. Telecom has previously developed a major upgrading of its telephone network. To ensure that upgrading proceeds on an equitable basis, the Commonwealth will enter into a formal network development deed with Telecom—broadly comparable to existing network development deeds with Optus and Vodafone. Targets will be set in consultation with Telecom and Austel, with priority being given to digitisation of exchanges and improving services in rural areas.

The starting point for negotiation of the deed will be threefold: Telecom's future mode of operation, FMO, plan—this provides for expenditure of $3.3 billion over the next five years; the recommendations in Austel's April 1994 COT report for network modernisation; and the existing commitments on roll out of calling line identification, CLI, capability.

This network development deed will be commercial-in-confidence, as are the Optus and Vodafone network development deeds. It will, however, include an annex outlining the major developments and this will be tabled in parliament. Clearly there is also room for improvement in Telecom's relations with its customers and a positive, non-adversarial approach is obviously preferable.

The Minister for Communications and the Arts has previously welcomed Telecom's decision to implement the recommendations of Austel's report on the COT cases, particularly those recommendations on customer complaints. Austel has reported that Telecom is instituting new customer complaint handling procedures recommended by the independent Coopers and Lybrand study.

In addition, Telecom will be asked to produce quickly a customer charter detailing in plain English what Telecom's customers are entitled to expect in terms of service. It will include clear information on the position with regard to liability, compensation and customer privacy. Telecom will settle appropriate wording for the charter with Austel, the Trade Practices Commission and the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs.

The charter will be effectively communicated to customers through bill inserts, public advertisements and other means after consultation with consumer groups and relevant government agencies. Of equal importance, internal staff training will emphasise the importance of the charter to Telecom staff, with particular emphasis on representation of liability and customer privacy. The Minister for Communications and the Arts will be encouraging the other carriers to follow Telecom's example and adopt a customer charter.

Honourable senators will recall that the Minister for Communications and the Arts has expressed concern that cost remains a barrier preventing many Australians from having a home telephone service. New measures to deal with affordability are currently being discussed with Telecom, in consultation with consumer and welfare groups, and the minister will be announcing details shortly.

It is important that the telecommunications regulator, Austel, has adequate resources to deal with consumer complaints. To this end, the Minister for Communications and the Arts has requested that Austel establish a special unit, headed by a general manager reporting to a designated Austel member, to manage network performance issues, quality of service and customer complaints about difficult network faults and related privacy issues. The unit will meet with complainants on a regular basis and endeavour to ensure that all matters are dealt with quickly.

Some concern has been expressed about carriers' liability for their actions. Telecom's statutory immunity from suit was removed completely by the Telecommunications Act 1991; that is, it is now in no more nor less favourable a situation than other carriers in Australia or, indeed, other companies. Telecom will be asked to expedite implementation of relevant recommendations in Austel's COT report to ensure that it does not misrepresent the extent of its liability to its customers. This will be done through revised instructions to staff, internal training and appropriate public information, including the proposed customer charter, with Austel overseeing this process through the new unit I have mentioned. Austel will shortly commence a public inquiry into the setting of limits on amounts recoverable in tort in relation to an act done, or an omission made, in relation to the supply of a specified basic carriage service. This will enable all interested parties to make submissions on the practical application of carrier liability.

Protection of customer privacy by telecommunications carriers is an issue of the gravest concern to the government, and we are determined that this will be reflected in the policies and actions of the carriers. Honourable senators will recall that in January the Minister for Communications and the Arts asked the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) to review the Telecommunications (Interception) Act to determine whether amendments were necessary to limit the breadth of the exemption given to carrier employees. The Attorney-General will be introducing amendments to the act to clarify the exemption for carrier employees.

The stringent new privacy guidelines developed by Telecom at the request of the Minister for Communications and the Arts and in consultation with the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman and the Privacy Commissioner have now been adopted by Optus and Vodafone also. Telecom's proposed external audit of its privacy policy will be published as well as tabled in the parliament and made available to Austel for prior scrutiny.

The minister has also asked Telecom to open discussions with the relevant unions to achieve amendments to the necessary awards to allow any internal Telecom disciplinary proceedings involving allegations of privacy breaches, including allegations of voice monitoring and recording, to be required to be chaired by an independent party. In addition, Telecom will be asked to appoint an independent party to review existing disciplinary procedures, including those that should apply to all levels of management.

In relation to the allegations of Mr Bray, the Minister for the Communications and the Arts has asked the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman to review the privacy aspects of those allegations, particularly in relation to Telecom's privacy guidelines. Broader privacy issues will be able to be considered by the Austel Privacy Advisory Committee that the minister announced recently. The Minister for Communications and the Arts has asked that priority be given to disclosure of customer information, particularly silent number information.

The use of the Freedom of Information Act by the COT complainants during the arbitration process disclosed the need for Telecom to review how it dealt with FOI requests. Telecom will be asked to ensure full implementation of the major reforms to its freedom of information procedures that were indicated as a result of that review. Such implementation is already under way, including centralised control to ensure prompt handling of requests, a network of FOI coordinators, standardised handling procedures and improved staff training.

The Minister for Communications and the Arts will be indicating to Telecom that he would expect it would implement any recommendations that the Commonwealth Ombudsman might make with regard to administration of the FOI Act. The minister is advised that the fast-track arbitration procedures—for the first four COT cases—has been settled and the secondary arbitration procedures—for the next 11 COT-type cases—have been substantially settled.

He will ask the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman to report to him, on conclusion of the arbitration, on any findings of general application to the telecommunications industry that he has made as a result of the arbitration process. In establishing if he can make any findings, he will consult with the arbitrator and the other consultants involved in the process.

With regard to the permanent arbitration procedures for settling claims, Telecom will be asked to finalise the rules for these as a matter of priority. Austel's quarterly reports on COT implementation and carrier quality of service will be tabled in the parliament, and I will table Austel's first quarterly COT report and the quality of service report for the March 1994 quarter at the end of my statement. After the receipt of each COT quarterly report, the Minister for Communications and the Arts proposes to request the chairman of Telecom to detail measures to address any concerns which Austel has identified.

The government's recent reforms to government business enterprise reporting and operating arrangements have increased GBE accountability, and the minister is discussing with the Telecom board ways of enhancing their reporting arrangements to government.

I can assure honourable senators that the government is committed to having all of these network and customer issues dealt with in a positive and open manner. We are confident that the arrangements detailed here will ensure this happens, and will provide proper parliamentary scrutiny of Telecom's future actions.

In closing on behalf of the Minister for Communications and the Arts, I would like to thank Senator Bourne for raising her concerns about Telecom's service performance and for assisting the government to respond to the needs and concerns of Telecom's customers. I table the statement, Austel's first quarterly report on the progress of Telecom's implementation of recommendations of Austel's COT cases report, and the Quality of Service bulletin for the March quarter 1994. I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement and the documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats welcome this statement as a very important step towards solving the problems within Telecom that we have been concerned about for a long time. This statement is a result of the documents I tabled on 29 August and my letter to the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) in which I set out our proposals for solving the major problems revealed in those documents.

PARA.TAB: Our subsequent discussions with the minister have left us in no doubt that he takes our concerns seriously. A comparison of his statement with my letter of 29 August shows that he has responded to every one of our proposals. We have reservations that some of the proposed solutions do not go far enough—and I will go into that in detail in a moment—but overall we believe that this response is constructive and thorough, and we thank him for that.

Our concerns about Telecom began more than a year ago when we were approached by the Casualties of Telecom group, a group of business proprietors who complained of chronic phone faults and poor treatment by Telecom. But the matters that I raised in this chamber on 29 August go much wider than the COTs, and so does the minister's response. They go to the performance of Telecom's network—especially in the country—and its responsibility to any customer experiencing difficult network faults.

The Casualties of Telecom deserve a good measure of credit for the changes announced by the minister today. Their perseverance over many years has not simply been in pursuit of self-interest; it has also been a public interest campaign from which all Australians will now benefit. It is our hope that these changes will make the finalisation of Telecom's dispute with the COTs more likely and more imminent, hopefully, and will also minimise the risk that such long-running and damaging disputes will occur again.

As far as the specific measures announced in today's statement are concerned, the Democrats, like all Australians, have been absolutely appalled at recent revelations about possible phone monitoring and recording by Telecom without customer consent. Those matters have been investigated by the Australian Federal Police and are being considered by the Director of Public Prosecutions.

As the minister said in his statement, it is important that these investigations should not be pre-empted. However, we are concerned that, if the Director of Public Prosecutions does not prefer charges, this leaves unanswered an important question: how widespread has the practice of covert monitoring and recording been, and why was it being done? In our view, the public has the right to know the answer. Should the DPP not proceed with prosecutions, we will pursue this matter further.

The Democrats are strong believers in the need to subject telecommunications carriers to rigorous and enforceable network performance standards. Today's commitment is very welcome, and we look forward to Austel's detailed end-to-end network standards with much interest. We also welcome the minister's statement that they will not be based on Telecom's new service verification test, which passes a phone service as adequate if it demonstrates a call success rate of only 90.2 per cent. Australians should be able to expect a much better service guarantee than that.

It is important that network performance standards are kept under constant review to reflect customer expectations, technological developments and trends in international best practice. It is equally important that the performance of all carriers against the standards be audited and that under-performance be quickly corrected. Today's statement makes those commitments.

We are pleased that our concerns about substandard telephone services in country areas are addressed in this statement. The government intends to enter into a network development deed with Telecom—the broad parameters of which will be made public—and to give priority to digitisation of exchanges and improving services in rural areas. In the absence of this commitment, it is far too likely that country areas will get the benefits of digital technology last. As the documents I tabled showed, rural services are already too far behind the city, and the gap must not grow further.

I would ask the minister to ensure that the special needs of people in remote areas are addressed in the network development deed—for example, in relation to the provision of a second phone line for connection to a fax. We have had representations from the Isolated Childrens' and Parents' Association that a fax line is essential for their childrens' education but that some people in New South Wales have been waiting more than nine months for a fax line and still do not have one. I understand that the problem is due to the availability of one particular part but it seems that a delay of that length is far too long and could be avoided.

The commitment that Telecom will develop a customer charter with an accurate and plain English explanation of Telecom's service obligations, including the contentious question of its liability, is very pleasing indeed. We welcome the involvement of Austel, the Trade Practices Commission and the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs in the drafting of the charter, and can only say that this is long overdue. We support the minister's call for the other carriers to follow suit.

The issue of liability is a vexed one. The Democrats accept Telecom's longstanding argument that it should not be held liable for the consequences of the failure of an individual phone call. However, we do believe that carriers should not be immune from liability where a customer receives a substandard phone service for a significant period of time. Not only is it a basic matter of justice, it is also an important motivation for improved carrier performance.

It has been put to us that the network performance standards will set a benchmark which the courts would interpret as, to coin a phrase, the liability line in the sand. We hope that is so but we have no legal advice to that effect. It is a matter we hope will be clarified during Austel's proposed inquiry into an appropriate limit of carrier liability. I suspect that inquiry will hear hotly contested and widely divergent views as to what that limit should be.

Carrier liability also includes the question of the Trade Practices Act, and we have long been concerned that Telecom has breached its obligations under that act not to engage in misleading and deceptive conduct in its dealings with customers with difficult network faults. We have referred our tabled documents to the Trade Practices Commission for investigation, and I understand that the minister has done so too.

We are particularly pleased that a new unit is to be formed within Austel to manage network performance, quality service and customer complaints arising from difficult network faults. There has been a serious communication problem between Austel and the COTs, and we trust that this unit will fix that problem. It should fill the large gap between where Austel's responsibilities end and the Telecommunication Industry Ombudsman's responsibilities begin. We note that the new unit will be headed by a general manager reporting to one of Austel's three members. We hope that the new member will be appointed soon, and that the appointment of a permanent chair will also be made soon to give Austel extra stability and certainty.

The statement includes a number of initiatives in the area of customer privacy, and they are all welcome, particularly the publication of its privacy audit and proposed new disciplinary procedures. But we regard it as essential that Austel be the ultimate auditor and the arbiter of privacy matters for all carriers, and that Telecom's initiatives are complementary to Austel's role and are not seen in any way as a substitute.

Telecom's administration of the Freedom of Information Act has been controversial in relation to the Casualties of Telecom, and we are concerned that the changes now being implemented still may not be adequate. In our opinion, Telecom employees handling FOI applications should do that and that alone. In the case of the COTs, there should be a total separation between FOI administrators and those employees managing the arbitration process. Many of the problems that have arisen to date are the result of Telecom managers trying to encourage the COTs to seek documents through arbitration rather than through FOI, to avoid the risk of public release. This is, of course, completely inappropriate. The FOI act imposes statutory obligations which cannot be avoided in this way.

The fact that the Commonwealth Ombudsman has been dealing with Telecom's FOI administration for so long is a clear indication that something has been badly wrong. We are yet to be convinced that it has been put right but we will defer to the ombudsman's forthcoming report on this matter.

The minister, and indeed everyone else involved in the Casualties of Telecom issue, would like to see the arbitration processes concluded quickly. I believe that there are two important conditions which must be met: the FOI applications of people now under arbitration must be fully delivered; and they must be given technical assistance to help construct their claims. Unlike Telecom, they do not have the expertise or resources to analyse tens of thousands of documents—and that is how many there are—in order to quantify the extent of phone faults on their service. They need help. Once those conditions have been met, I would strongly urge those in arbitration to participate fully in the process.

A question I am sure will be asked—it seems to be asked a lot lately—and which I will therefore answer now is: will we support a Senate inquiry into Telecom? Our aim all along has been to find solutions rather than to explore questions to which we already know the answers. Our reason for tabling the documents was to get action, and we have done that. We have also made it clear that we do not wish to inquire into matters which have already been investigated competently and thoroughly. Our emphasis is to have the results of those investigations made public, not to reinvent the wheel.

I have already raised outstanding concerns about Telecom's handling of freedom of information applications and about the extent to which the Australian Federal Police investigations will be made public should there be no prosecutions arising. We will pursue our FOI concerns with the minister and will be guided on further action by the Commonwealth Ombudsman's report into Telecom's administration of FOI claims.

As I said before, where we take our concerns about the Federal Police report depends on how the Director of Public Prosecutions responds to it. If charges are preferred, then in keeping with convention, we will take no further action while the matter is before the courts. If no charges are preferred, we will seek further information.

We can see no basis at this stage for a Senate inquiry. However, we would reconsider our position if the implementation of the minister's commitments is not expedited or if there are new revelations which require closer investigation. In either event, a Senate inquiry is one possible means to an end, namely, to solve a problem; but it is not an end in itself. What matters is results. That is what we hoped to achieve out of today's statement—an accountable and responsive Telecom, a strong and independent regulator, and a world-class telecommunications system. We believe that a good start has now been made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the report from Minister Lee focusing on the telecommunication network and the issue of services that affect telecommunication customers. The minister's statement sets out the government initiatives to speed up the improvements in the telecommunications sector. He wants to ensure that all Australians have access to a telephone service that is affordable and of a world-class standard. But, as we will see from some of the comments I will reveal later from the technical experts, in country areas in particular we are far from that sort of standard.

PARA.TAB: Through this report the minister will also try to achieve a service where telephone carriers conform to the highest standards of ethical behaviour and customer service. The ministerial statement does set out actions on the Telecom network and customer issues that we support. The report does show a willingness to act on a wide range of identified problems in our telecommunications system—for example, the AFP inquiry into allegations that Telecom recorded phone calls of customers without consent has been finalised. The opposition calls on the government to make sure that this is completed as quickly as possible through the Australian Federal Police and that the investigating teams move to prosecute, if appropriate, as this issue has severely shaken public confidence.

The regulator Austel is to develop an independent capability to monitor the telecommunication carriers' compliance with mandatory performance standards, and that is welcome. The implementation by Telecom of the Austel report on Casualties of Telecom, which was referred to by the last speaker, is positive in the direction in which it is now proceeding. We welcome the report that Telecom will institute new customer complaint handling procedures as recommended by the independent consultants Coopers and Lybrand. The proposed Telecom customer charter in plain English detailing what services people can expect for their money is overdue but needed urgently, and the government's movement in this area is also welcome. The involvement of the Trade Practices Commission in the wording of the charter that the government proposes will certainly help public confidence in this document and in this procedure.

The priority given to internal staff training at Telecom to get staff to own the values of the charter on customer service is essential to prevent some of the terrible situations that arose during the COT case episode. The minister's assurance on customer privacy, however, needs further scrutiny. The report of the Australian Federal Police and action by the Director of Public Prosecutions are awaited by the public and by members of this parliament with great interest. We also await the Attorney-General's amendments to the Telecommunications Interception Act to see whether it limits sufficiently the exemptions now given to carrier employees.

Although I have said that the report contains many things that are positive, in many ways it shows that Telecom has a long way to go, particularly in terms of the standard of service in certain areas of the country. The minister and indeed the head of Telecom talk about Telecom's world-class service and in many areas that is true. However, one area in which there are great difficulties is that of rural service. Given how long telephony has been operating in this country, it is amazing that some rural areas still have such an appalling level of service. Indeed, it was shown in the COT cases that most of the problems that arose occurred because of a poor technical standard of equipment in certain areas which was creating most of the problem.

That the government is ignoring rural and regional Australia in terms of the adequacy of its telephony standard is very much in line with its approach in many other areas. Whether in terms of roads, rail, bridges and in this case telecommunications infrastructure, Labor's record to date is very poor. Senators will recall that the minister responsible for rural and regional affairs recently brought down a rural policy and spoke of spending $160 million over a period of four years. That is a pathetic sum of money to be spent over the whole of rural and regional Australia, particularly when one considers that `regional' as defined includes cities. The total amount to be spent next year on infrastructure under that program was $10 million across Australia, including big cities.

The government has a long history in this area and this most recent case of its rural and regional policies shows that sad history is continuing and that Labor is neglecting rural Australia. The case in point highlights even further that this government is neglecting the telephone system and its infrastructure in rural and regional Australia. Evidence has surfaced from internal technical documents that out there is a clapped out and, at best, second-rate network of service to country people. On top of this extraordinary drought and other areas of callous policies from this government—a government that has ignored rural Australia and the suffering that has arisen from the drought over a period of four years—farming families have to put up with a second-rate telephone system and have to pay high charges for what is delivered to them.

An internal Telecom document distributed by the Democrats highlights some of the damning problems with phone services to rural customers. I quote from a technical transmission group document in Telecom dated January 1994. It shows that the system contains a huge range of faults. So much for Minister Lee's lofty claims about a world-class telephone system that works. Let us defer to the Telecom technical experts for their assessment of the service to rural Australians. I quote from the document:

SPEECH.PARA: A selected group of staff in New South Wales south and west region (Consumer and Country Division) conducted an examination and testing process of cables feeding out of eight rural exchanges. The initial aim was to gather information about the real level of transmission-related faults. However, the findings create great concern over the degree of direct current faults.

That was the background to the findings and it amounts to a catalogue of disgraceful service delivery to the 93 per cent of rural households on such a telephone system in the regions. The report continued:
The servicing of the network investigated is totally understaffed. . .
There are no reliable records kept of completed repairs . . .
Faults are not being repaired at all—the service restoration method is to transpose around the problem. This applies to faults in joints as well as cable links. . .
There is a zero level of field staff understanding of transmission testing techniques and operating principles. . .
Modern testing equipment although adequately supplied, is only used by a minority of staff. . .
Lightning strike faults are being encouraged by our own actions. . .
Unless a customer is within a few hundred metres of an exchange, it is impossible to find a totally fault-free spare twisted copper pair to use. .
The document outlines poor standards of work that cause disruption to customer service. It instances long delays in fault repair work; deficiencies in the side tone level and quality of the service.

PARA.TAB: Given that these deficiencies are contained in an internal Telecom report, we demand that the minister should take this seriously. Let us have no airy, fancy words such as world-class service when one is facing a damning internal document of Telecom that reveals the real state of the system. Rural Australia is tired of such very poor treatment by what is supposed to be a highly competent technical company. Clearly Austel, the referee in telecommunications, needs to monitor much more closely the performance standards of Telecom in the bush.

Today at lunchtime I made a speech on the information superhighway—one of a series that I am doing. We were speaking of the roll-out of this sort of communication technology right across Australia to link this country into the rest of the world. What hope has rural and regional Australia to be linked into a high capacity, high quality world-wide system when after 60 years of telephony there is now such a poor standard of service in rural areas? In the United States there is talk of the information rich and the information poor in the new information age. If our rural and regional areas are so poorly connected to the information superhighway, people in those areas will certainly be part of the information poor. I call on the government to act on Telecom's own internal report showing the faults in the telephony system and to fix them immediately.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my earlier remarks on the motion to set up a Senate select committee of inquiry into the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, I referred to my experience on the Senate Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing. I learned many valuable lessons from service on that committee, three of which are relevant at this time.

PARA.TAB: The first lesson I learned was the importance of media to those people who are concerned about fraud or corrupt conduct within institutions, in government or in the public or private sector bureaucracies. The media and its presence as a last resort is very valuable to those people who have no other avenues open to them. The fact that people who make complaints in the public interest need appropriate mechanisms for expressing concerns when there is an error in the system was a matter addressed by the select committee.

It noted that the absence of those factors meant that the media operated often as a last resort—sometimes as the only avenue of expressing concerns. Had these been dealt with earlier and in a more constructive manner by the institutions about which those complaints were being made, it would have been far better.

The second thing I learnt was that, while media did have at certain times a very useful function for those people who were expressing concerns and allegations, when problems arose within the media itself, often those people had nowhere to turn.

I would like to refer to a particular section of the whistleblower report entitled In the Public Interest. In section 9.129, the committee discussed whistleblowing to the media and moved on. The committee received evidence which indicated concerns over whistleblowing within the media and the reaction to disclosures of wrongdoing involving the media. Witnesses referred to unscrupulous activities going on within the media, examples of media manipulation and the important role the media played in government and ministerial accountability. The committee reports states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee makes no judgment as to the comments received in evidence, but is concerned at the lack of response to this Inquiry from the media. The Committee believes that further parliamentary scrutiny of this area could be warranted. The Committee is concerned that if the media is not open and accountable itself then the openness and accountability of government could be jeopardised.

There is an intelligence test question that asks: what is the importance of a free press to a nation? I leave that question in the air because I believe that that is one of the principles underlying the basis for having a method of scrutiny for problems within the media itself which are not apparently being currently addressed through other systems.

PARA.TAB: The third lesson I learnt from my involvement in that committee was how valuable, positive and constructive a Senate select committee can be and that it can actually present a very helpful and positive approach to complex, sensitive and seemingly insoluble difficulties. It was a cross-party committee. It had a unanimous report, but it was the first committee where I have actually seen the role of parliament as mediator between the people and bureaucratic systems of all different kinds, whether they are government, private or public sector organisations. Because of that, I believe it is valuable to make this reference regarding the ABC to a Senate select committee.

The Democrats have foreshadowed some amendments and, while I may not have seen all of them, I can certainly say that the Greens support the ones that I have seen. I am willing to support the modifications to the reference as it has been placed. I will leave it up to the opposition to express its views, but I feel it is extremely constructive to have a cross-party analysis of these issues. I welcome the Australian Democrats' support, and I believe it will add to the depth of the inquiry and will make sure that what we are trying to do is not only perceived to be fair and open but will be so.

The centralisation of operations towards Sydney within the ABC, the proposal to amalgamate Radio Australia and ATV that was mooted and the increasing commercialisation of the broadcaster has brought to a head concern over the ABC. This is because the ABC represents the only alternative to commercial media in Australia. We believe the ABC needs to preserve its unique position as the national public broadcaster.

The broad terms of reference of the committee mean that a wide range of submissions will be considered from the community and people more closely connected with the broadcaster. Senate committees can take evidence in closed hearings, which will mean that persons will be able to appear before the committee without fear or favour. There must be a visible mechanism for the ABC to get over these problems rather than glossing over them. The purpose of the inquiry is not to emphasise any one of the particular issues but to be a wide-ranging inquiry, ensuring that nothing holds the ABC back from continuing its vital role in the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will support this motion. We have asked people to consider a couple of amendments, as Senator Chamarette mentioned. The main one is that we are concerned, as has always been the case, with the adequacy of funding of the ABC. It appears to us that over the last few years the ABC has been given additional charter obligations through legislation in general and it has been given one-off grants to fulfil those obligations. After that grant runs out its service has to be self-funding.

PARA.TAB: We are just not sure that that is the way we ought to be going with our national broadcaster. If we want to have a quality service, it seems reasonable to us that we pay for that quality service. If the Australian people as a nation want to have a quality service such as Australia Television, then we ought to be prepared to pay for that. We ought to think that the benefits of having it mean that it is worth while paying our tax dollars towards a good service.
Therefore I move:
Insert immediately before paragraph 2:

TAB.TAB: `(c)the extent to which inadequate budget funding is responsible for the ABC's increased dependence on external funding; and
(d)the impact and potential impact of external funding on the ABC's editorial independence.'

SPEECH.PARA: That is the main amendment that we wish to move.

PARA.TAB: We have had considerable qualms about the controversy surrounding appointments to the board of the ABC, and we have made them known. We do not necessarily think that the board has been politicised to an extent that it becomes not as unbiased as we would hope, but we would like to have a look at it and assure ourselves and the Australian public that that is not the case, if it is not the case. So I think it is worth while having a look into that aspect especially.
