Senator Chamarette has agreed, and I think Senator Alston and the government have also agreed, that it would be sensible to look into the matters which are being looked into by Mr George Palmer QC after he has reported and see if there is something we can reasonably add to those recommendations. So we recommend, hope and expect that the recommendations would be accepted and that we do not go into that section of this inquiry until that has happened. We think it probably will happen.

The other two amendments I would like to move are less important, but I think they make the process more democratic. I do not think that there necessarily should be an opposition chair of select committees. It is more reasonable, as far as we are concerned, to take the chair from the members of the committee as those members decide. That way, in the end, we will end up with what has been agreed. In the past—I think it was in May last year—we agreed that we would try to distribute chairs of select committees roughly according to the proportion of parties and members of this Senate. I think we have done that pretty well up until now, and I wish to continue to do that.
Therefore, I seek leave to move our two other amendments together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Delete from paragraph 4(a) the words `from the members nominated by the Leader of the Opposition'.
Delete from paragraph 4(c) the words `appointed by the chair from' and replace with `elected by'.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of those two amendments would be to make the members of the committee responsible for whom they elect as chair and deputy chair.

PARA.TAB: We are concerned with the fine line between finding and recommending constructive solutions to perceived problems within the ABC and the possibility of using an inquiry such as this for political ends. I have spoken to some people who I believe may be on the committee and I do not think that they would want to do that. I certainly hope that they would not want to do that. I certainly would not want to do that. But it is a possibility and it is one that we all have to keep in mind with every committee that is set up or with every committee that we are on.

We have to be very sure that it does not become a witch-hunt. We have to be very sure that it does not become something where people are worried about gaining their own political ends. This is something that I worry about with the government and the opposition—in fact, with all of us. We have to be very careful that we are unbiased. I will certainly try to do that and I hope that everybody else in this chamber would try to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, the coalition also strongly supports this proposal for the establishment of a select committee on ABC management and operations. Although it has been long in coming, we certainly welcome the initiative that has been taken today. I trust that the proposal will receive the support of the Senate and that this inquiry is established. It is certainly time that our national broadcaster was made more accountable to the people of Australia and I trust that the inquiry on which we are about to embark will achieve that end.

PARA.TAB: In recent months we have seen a growing public concern about the growth in the influence of the government over the direction and charter of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation with the undoubted aim of gaining political advantage. That is reflected in a number of recent appointments to the board of the ABC—most notably that of the former South Australian Labor premier, John Bannon, but also that of Wendy Silver from Western Australia and others—such that we now find that the board of the ABC has a majority of people on it with close and clearly identifiable links with the Labor Party. It is undoubtedly through that mechanism that this government is seeking to impose its influence upon the national broadcaster and that is directly contrary to the principles of independence and impartiality which we have long expected of the ABC.

Of course, the concern is not only with the political influence that has been brought to bear through those board appointments; the actual appropriateness of the appointments needs to be brought into question. As we have said in earlier debates in this place with regard to the constitution of the board of the ABC, the former Labor premier, Mr Bannon, took South Australia into financial oblivion with his involvement in the creation of a massive $3 billion debt which is now being shouldered by every South Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has that got to do with it?

—What it has to do with it is the appropriateness of this government appointing to the board people of demonstrable incompetence. I trust that this inquiry will look at those matters very closely and will look at the way in which this government has stacked the board with its mates to its own attempted advantage.

PARA.TAB: It is no wonder that the government is opposing this inquiry. It fears that the truth about those issues will come out. It fears that the truth about the continuing high level of resignations and departures from the ABC of senior, experienced broadcasting managers and cancellation of programs will also be uncovered by this inquiry. It obviously fears that further evidence may become public about the ABC's suspected involvement in breaches of sponsorship rules involving co-production. It fears that it might be implicated in allowing the huge wastage of public funds from the ABC's failed commercial activities to go unaccounted for. There is no doubt that the government would be opposing the establishment of a Senate inquiry by way of a select committee.

The ABC is a very vital part of our democratic community. The success that it has achieved in the past is due to the fact that it was always seen to be at arm's length from the government of the day. The reason the public is rapidly losing confidence in our national broadcaster, the reason we daily read in the newspapers, see on television news reports and current affairs programs and hear on the radio about the internal fighting and lack of morale in the ABC, and the reason so much abuse and misuse of taxpayers' funds is occurring in the ABC is that the government and the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) have not been accountable to the public for their actions with regard to the national broadcaster.

I trust that this inquiry will ensure that the government, in particular the minister and, indeed, the ABC itself will again be made accountable to the parliament and, through the parliament, to the Australian community. We need to ensure that our national broadcaster is given every opportunity to function properly without political interference or political hindrance.

Therefore, as I said at the outset, I welcome this proposal for a Senate select committee to inquire into the ABC with the terms of reference that have been proffered. I support it in the interests of ensuring that the ABC is properly administered and that the interests of the broader community are maintained by our national broadcaster and that it is not manipulated to political advantage, as we have seen occur in recent months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise to oppose the proposition for the establishment of a select committee on ABC management and operations. I realise that some opposite have a fascination with the media, as reflected in the comments made routinely by the coalition about the ABC in particular and the media generally.

PARA.TAB: We have seen through the workings of the print media committee just how a select committee can run off the rails very early never to return. We have also seen the voracious appetite for public dollars generated by the Senate print media committee, on which both Senator Sherry and I had the unhappy task of serving. We were initially promised that it would be concluded by the early part of this year—by the end of February, if I remember correctly. We have now seen efforts to extend it to March of 1995. I now confidently predict that we will not see the end of it then; it will run the length and life of this parliament.

The creation of a Senate select committee should be the basis for a contribution to public policy and a sense of perspective. But the essential precondition for creating a select committee that is going to work in that way—I do not doubt Senator Chamarette's spirit when she says that she would like to see this committee work in that way—is to approach matters in an objective manner and to endeavour to establish goodwill and a sense of trust all around the chamber from the moment the committee is created. That was not the case with the print media committee; the well was poisoned at the commencement.

The well has been poisoned at the commencement again because if we look at the mechanism by which the committee is created—if I am reading the proposition correctly—there would be two senators from the government, three from the opposition, one from the Democrats and one from the Greens (WA) or Senator Harradine. Circumstances being what they are, Ferdinand Marcos would have loved a system like that when it is looked at in terms of proportional representation. This is not only stacking the constituency, this is fixing the outcome as well.

A select committee is tarnished at its inception by that mechanism. So I really think we are not going to see a sense of perspective emerge on the basis that the committee will not be seen to be fair, impartial or objective at the time at which it is created.

There are some serious matters before the national broadcaster. I do not think that anyone would disagree with that. I think the Palmer inquiry is welcome. I have a very high regard for Mr Palmer and I have no doubt that his report will be beneficial to the corporation and for broadcasting policy. But to be honest, I grow a little tired of the crocodile tears opposite, accompanied on some occasions and replaced on others by endless assaults on the ABC from the conservative parties. In a number of respects, the ABC is doing well as a national broadcaster with the amount of Australian drama and public affairs programs going to air, its innovation and international outlook.

I acknowledge the contribution of Mr David Hill in that regard. He has brought significant and substantive changes to the broadcaster. I think that by and large the ABC's public affairs program is reliable, its news service is fair and objective and its analysis is informative. I acknowledge one program in particular—Lateline. That is not to say that from time to time I have not disagreed with things that have been said, reports that have gone to air, and so on. I think we all face that from time to time. But, by and large, I think the ABC does a very effective job, not only in the capital cities but also in the regions.

If the Senate decides to proceed down this path on the basis of a statutory declaration—frankly, I really cannot see why the government should participate in some of these bodies—all it will have achieved at the outset is to demonstrate the latent hostility that exists in this chamber towards the Labor government in the broad. We have seen that on different occasions and it might be part of the political process if it ever bore a result, if it ever achieved anything. But if the people opposite think this is going to lift their prospects for 1995-96, they are sadly mistaken.

Let us look at the fiasco of the print media committee again. No-one benefited from that; certainly public policy did not. The imbalance in the committee underlines the problem. There is a lack of equity that confirms the assessment which I am making.

I doubt that this initiative could be more ill-timed or that it could be based on a lesser premise. For example, only yesterday the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) tabled in the House of Representatives a report on the inquiry into financial and managerial aspects of the ABC's Australia Television service. It is simply a matter of public record.

That report, which was commissioned by the minister in response to allegations that this service is running funds within the ABC, found that support of the service by the ABC has not involved diversion of resources from budget funded activities. This is again a simple matter of fact. The minister wrote to the chairman of the board in relation to a number of issues raised by the report, matters which are being addressed by the board in conjunction with management. Surely that ought to be the first option.

In addition, the minister has publicly indicated that he will be continuing to work with the ABC in developing the Australia international service, a service that is acknowledged as making a significant contribution to promoting Australia in the region, something that, from memory, Senator Bourne and I saw first hand on our recent travels in the region.

It is ludicrous for the Senate to embark upon another inquiry into this service. All it will be is a forum for grandstanding. I make that prediction with absolute certainty. Senator Bourne made her usual thoughtful contribution and expressed the view that she hoped quite honestly and earnestly that this would not occur. I fear the absolute worst, given the absolute obsession with media opposite and the personalities who are going to be involved.

Let us look at the circumstances of Senator Alston's recent remarks to Mr Oakes on the Sunday program. He talked about pay TV involving `wishful thinking.' Going back to June of 1992, from memory, we should rhetorically ask who it was that insisted on the ABC embarking upon the pay television initiative? Was there not an amendment moved by Senator Alston in this chamber? Was there not a proposal that emerged from the same Senator Alston? Now he is talking about people with the deepest pockets in television as competitors. Now he is talking about the ABC's `wishful thinking.' This is the pirouette off the top diving board; there is no question about that.

Senator Chamarette referred to cross-party support. Cross-party support ought to extend around the chamber. There are enough committees that work well in this place—joint, standing and select—to demonstrate that that can be achieved fairly readily. As I said, it is an essential precondition for a select committee that it work. If it is not perceived as fair or as being able to make a thoughtful contribution to public policy, it simply will not work.

In respect of the inquiries that are under way, that are ongoing, the ABC, or separately the government, has instituted the Australia Television review, an independent inquiry by a senior Sydney barrister into the sponsorship matters, which I mentioned earlier, and detailed discussions between the board, the minister and the Department of Communications and the Arts to establish a rigorous and transparent framework for the ABC's involvement in pay television. So on the public record the government's bona fides are established. Little will be achieved by this initiative, which is a pity. Select committees are becoming Confederate currency—absolutely worthless.

To listen to the weasel words opposite that the ABC should be the fearless and independent broadcaster—at the margin as always, at the periphery as always—will not convince anyone on this side of the chamber or in the electorate at large that there is anything other than a political agenda inherent in what the coalition is doing with this proposition. If people wait to make a judgment on how this committee works, on what its report will contain and on what its findings will be, they will see my words borne out in several months time. In several months time we will see the emergence of a political agenda and political objectives being achieved by the coalition making findings on which it has already agreed, circumstances being what they are.

This inquiry into the ABC will achieve nothing more than to waste public money, take up the time of the Senate and further discredit the select committee system. It will serve nobody's ends except those of the opportunists opposite, who wanted to take $50 million out of the ABC's budget prior to the 1993 election, codified it in Fightback and told the ABC management it was an immutable commitment—I think those were Mr Carlton's words. They are the same people who are now saying that the fearlessness and independence of the broadcaster ought to be guaranteed. This committee will not do it. This committee will do nothing other than guarantee that there will be a series of political arguments raging over the months and a report which will mean nothing to broadcasting policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that the events of not just recent days but recent weeks would have made it clear why there is a need and indeed, I think, a very keen public interest in pursuing in a public forum all of the matters that are contained in Senator Chamarette's motion. It is one thing to have a debate, for what that amounts to in public life, by way of slanging matches in the chamber. It is another to actually address the issues on the basis of submissions and evidence given to a committee.

PARA.TAB: That process can work. It works very well in a number of instances. To suggest that having a committee that does not have a majority of government members amounts to fixing the outcome says a lot more about those who make those sorts of comments than it does about those of us who genuinely believe in the democratic process. In other words, the implication of what Senator Loosley has just said is that because the government does not have the numbers, everyone has decided in advance what the true agenda is, everyone has decided on an outcome which is fixed.

If one thing is abundantly clear it is that in the environment from which Senator Loosley comes having the numbers means fixing the outcome. That is really what he is complaining about. There is no hidden agenda here. The areas of concern are transparent. They have been specified. They are matters about which a number of people have made public comments. It is simply an attempt to divert attention from serious public issues to talk about questioning one side's bona fides but not the other's.

For our part, we are very much committed to the ABC. It ought to be a quality alternative to the commercial broadcasting sector. That does not, on my reading of it, find its way expressly into the charter, and I think that leads into a number of very important areas for proper analysis.

If we look at the areas that have been specified in this motion, I would have thought there is a very important public issue surrounding the future of both ATVI on the one hand and pay television on the other. I do not hold the view that the ABC should not be in any commercial activities, but I do hold the view that, if we look at the way in which the BBC has approached the matter, we will see that there are ways in which commercial activities can be quarantined, the costs of those programs can be separated out and it can be ensured that there is not a high degree of cross-subsidy. We cannot say that about the ABC at the moment.

Only a couple of weeks ago I was interested to discover the extent to which the ABC was funding a service called BNA, Broadcast News Australia, which has recently decided to go into competition with AAP, a news wire service which has been a monopoly activity in the private sector for 50 years or more. If we try to find out the extent of the ABC's commitment, we can barely find mention of the service in the annual report. In other words, it is very unclear to what extent ABC resources are being devoted to what seems to me to be a speculative commercial venture.

The same goes for ATVI. I have always thought that there was a great deal to be said for Australia having an international satellite service that is able to ensure that our culture is readily available to those in the region, not just expats but the very many hundreds of millions of people who are potential viewers of a service. But it is not an easy exercise. It has already proven to be a very difficult matter to estimate the extent to which there will be a take-up. There does not seem to be any serious research done on the matter. Indeed, there have been suggestions that the ABC does not particularly want to conduct research, because it will show that the level of sponsorship is such that it reflects the fact that there is a very poor level of audience participation. We just do not know the answers to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were told what the level of sponsorship was in response to a question you asked in August.

—What we have been told in the Hutchinson report is that for 1993-94 sponsorship raised $900,000, as against a projected figure of, I think, $2.6 million or $2.9 million. So it has been dramatically behind target in the last financial year. It also says that in the current financial year, which is only a few months old, it is well ahead of target. But again one has to rely on these sorts of figures emerging as a result of an inquiry of that sort.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought the idea that the ABC can be a successful international satellite operator by simply investing $5.4 million is drawing a very long bow. I am not at all satisfied that that amount is sufficient. I have a pretty good idea how it came about: there were those in cabinet who were not in favour of any involvement at all and there were those who were—as I recall, Senator Evans and Senator Collins were two in favour—and the compromise was that $5.4 million would be given on a one-off basis. The ABC was supposed to be self-funding. We now find from the Hutchinson report that what self-funding means to the ABC is quite different from what it means to the government.

Again, the idea of being able to run a fully fledged service for that sort of money is asking people to make some very heroic assumptions. The same goes for a pay service costing $12.5 million. That seems to me to be a pitifully small amount if one is serious about competing against others in the international arena.

Senator Loosley, I presume, was just reciting an answer that Mr Lee gave in the House of Representatives yesterday, but the facts are that the government and the Australian Democrats had agreed that the ABC would have two channels. The only amendment I moved was in relation to giving the ABC a separate transponder—well and truly after that commitment had been made, after it was locked in, after the numbers were there and after the ABC was well and truly provided for.

I am not saying that we disagreed with it. Indeed, I think the announcement of $12.5 million was made at the time. But that has got nothing to do with assessing progress two years down the track, and nothing to do with taking account of all the other commitments that have subsequently been entered into. That is why I think it is in everyone's best interests to investigate these matters in as impartial a manner as possible. I do not take the approach that Senator Loosley takes, which is to take no prisoners, basically, and that anyone who disagrees with the Labor Party is by definition grandstanding, by definition has a hidden agenda, and by definition is not committed. The corollary of that, of course, is that those on the government side have no hidden agenda, they are not in the business of grandstanding, they are entirely dedicated to the public interest and they are simply trying to achieve the best for all concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've got it. Terrific! I'm glad you have learned something.

—I am glad to hear those opposite confirm it, because it does not do them justice. Those in the real world do not believe that all wisdom resides on one side or the other, and neither do we. We have the honesty to concede that it is not just an exercise in point scoring; it is an exercise in sensible debate. To the extent that your arguments are not valid, then you will be laughed at in the public arena. Those opposite know it; they are the victim of it as much as we are when we make those sorts of statements. To somehow pretend that anyone who has a view that disagrees with those opposite is by definition grandstanding, is by definition acting improperly, is quite dishonest, should not be trusted, has a hidden agenda—all those things confirm the stereotypes of the New South Wales Right. And that is the great tragedy of this place.
—Senator Carr is not of the New South Wales Right.

—No, I know. The reason I say that is that they have reduced it to an art form and because the person who raised the proposition happens to be probably the archetypal thug from the New South Wales Right. I am happy to hear that those opposite are all very keen to be associated with that approach to politics. But the reality is that we do not subscribe to that view of the world.

PARA.TAB: We actually believe that there are some important public policy issues and that if people happen to take one position, it does not mean that they are dishonest because they disagree with the government, any more than we would accuse those opposite of rank dishonesty or grandstanding every time they disagreed with us. When a motion is put forward in this way that has multi-party support and which does address a number of major issues of concern—I think even Senator Loosley conceded in passing that a number of these matters were validly in the public arena—I would have thought that there was an obligation on us all to take those issues seriously.

I believe it can be done in a select committee process. I believe that there are a lot of people of goodwill towards the ABC who would be prepared to contribute by way of submissions and evidence, and that as a result the ABC would be a lot better and stronger for the process. It is not a matter of wasting resources. I have to say that I do not think that the Palmer inquiry is much more than an exercise in damage control. It is addressing a very important issue, but all it does is ask whether the guidelines have been breached.

The fact is that we need to know why they have been breached, we need to know the implications, and we need to know how it came about. Given that the guidelines require the Director of Radio and the Director of Television to satisfy themselves on a whole number of counts, they clearly, therefore, ought to have asked questions about what funds were provided by co-producers or financiers of co-producers, on what terms, and what limitations there might have been on editorial control. In other words, a whole range of questions are required to be asked so that the director can satisfy himself.

I would have thought that the first question to answer is whether the director carried out his obligations under the guidelines. If he did, was he then misled by those who simply said that there were no monies being paid indirectly, that there was not any editorial interference? Or, on the other hand, did he simply ignore those matters, even though they were brought to his attention in advance? To merely ask `whether' is in no way an adequate response to the allegations that have been raised. We need to know why, we need to know the circumstances and the background and, best of all, we need to know the implications and what ought to be done to ensure that problems do not arise in that area in the future.

All I can say is that the Palmer exercise is very narrowly based. The view we have taken, I think quite rightly, is that the Senate committee should not embark upon an examination of that particular term of reference until the Palmer report is to hand, and I understand that is to be November. I have no idea whether it is meant to be public, but I would have hoped so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope so.

—I hope so, too. I would hope that it is immediately put before the select committee so that it can then look at how far Palmer has managed to get and then take the matter further if necessary. As I have said, having looked at the terms of reference, I think that inevitably there is a lot more to be said about the whole area of co-production than will ever be brought to light by Mr Palmer's inquiry. That is no reflection on him; it is simply a reflection on the very narrow terms of reference which were probably the classic knee-jerk response to a television program. That is not the way to approach the very serious issue of the future of the ABC.

PARA.TAB: I will conclude by saying that I hope the Senate will pass this motion and that each of those matters will be able to be examined sensibly, soberly and impartially—as much as is possible in the political process. I do not pretend for a moment that there will not be political skirmishes; but we on our side of the chamber are very much committed to the ABC's emerging from this exercise in a stronger position, with a much clearer sense of what its charter obligations ought to be and with the public having a much greater degree of confidence that the ABC is able to cope with all the obligations it has taken upon itself, particularly in the commercial arena. If we go through that exercise, the public and the taxpayers who fund the ABC will be the beneficiaries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two sets of reasons why the government is opposed to the establishment of this committee. The first set of reasons relates to the ongoing, and unfortunately growing, abuse of Senate select committees. The other set of reasons has to do with the way in which policy analysis and what may be some valid criticisms of the ABC should be scrutinised and handled.

PARA.TAB: To start with, I will deal with the ongoing abuse of Senate select committees. I do not know whether it is coincidence, but on at least one of the last three Senate select committees that I have been on I have shared that privilege with Senator Alston. The first was the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. It was not just because I was chair or Senator Alston was deputy chair of the committee that it was generally accepted that the committee developed policy recommendations in a fairly objective and bipartisan way. It has a fairly substantial record, not just under the initial appointments to that committee but also more recently under the chair of Senator Watson who is an opposition senator.

I then moved on to what has now become known as the infamous loan council committee, the Senate Select Committee on the Australian Loan Council. That was the first indication to me that select committees were being established for political grandstanding and were failing to meet any sort of test of objectivity. I do not intend to relate all the circumstances we had on that committee. It was set up just prior to the last election. It increased its tempo of meetings as the election was called. There were meetings in airport terminals and we issued an interim report with under half—

TALK.START.PARA: —Even from a hospital bedroom.

—I am just about to get to the hospital bed interview that Senator Alston did. An interim report was issued with only half the evidence heard. This was all done because Senator Coulter wanted to build his profile during the election campaign—and we know what happened. Senator Alston did a famous interview from his hospital bed, because he had to participate in the meeting, and we did a phone vote. To this day, we do not know whether phone votes are legal; but it occurred. We had meetings called on and off; we had majority reports turning into minorities the next day. It became a total farce.

PARA.TAB: We then had another select committee, the media committee. That is still going; it will go for another six months because we are waiting for a response to a government report. Senator Alston obviously will be paid in the meantime, but we are not sure what the committee is going to do, other than wait for this report from the government. The media committee had an unfortunate series of events as well. We had Senator Kernot making some comments about wanting to put public servants in gaol. We had assurances that there would be objectivity, that there would be clear policy analysis, that there would not be grandstanding. But, unfortunately, the loans council committee and the media committee certainly indicate that the recent trend of Senate select committees is towards nothing more than political grandstanding and point scoring. They are not for the legitimate development of balanced policy.

Today we have another Senate committee proposed. I was in the chamber yesterday when the motion was tabled. I might say I was appalled for a number of reasons. Firstly, when we look through the terms of reference, we see that they are written in a totally negative way. They are not terms of reference that make legitimate, clear points of inquiry. For example, the first term of reference, subclause (a), says:

SPEECH.PARA: the failure of Australian Television International to penetrate its target markets in Asia.

There is a presumption before the inquiry commences. Terms of reference should not be written in this way. Let us flick over to the next couple of pages and look at the government membership of the committee. Again, I am appalled. It is a seven-person committee but how many members does the government get? It gets two out of seven. With every select committee that is set up the government is ending up with fewer and fewer members. We used to get the chairs—now there is a legitimate case for the government not getting the chair on every occasion. But we are down to two out of seven members. One of the arguments for rotating chairs was the proportional nature of this chamber. Well, two out of seven is much less than the proportion the government represents in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: Another interesting aspect of this motion which was tabled yesterday is that that was the first time the government saw the motion. We expect a bipartisan approach and a thorough policy analysis in a balanced way. Government members are expected to approach their duties in a responsible fashion but they are not even consulted about the terms of reference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you seriously suggesting that you may in some circumstances support it?

—We may; but we were not even asked. The terms of reference are set up in a negative way with totally unbalanced representation on the committee membership—and we are not even asked. With that sort of approach, I do not think it is reasonable to expect the sort of cooperation that those opposite could otherwise expect. It is a great way to start off a committee inquiry: not to consult with the government about any of the terms of reference or the membership.

PARA.TAB: Another reason this committee should not be set up is that we have just been through a fairly lengthy set of negotiations about reorganising our standing, legislative and estimates committees in this place. On a number of occasions I can recall not just opposition members but members from the Greens and the Australian Democrats arguing that we should have a more balanced approach to committee membership in terms of representation—sharing out committee chairs—and there are far too many select committees. They said that if we reform the committee structure, rather than setting up select committees on an ongoing basis—there have been more and more of them in recent years—we can look much more favourably on referring these types of references to the standing committees.

But what do we get? Shortly after we get agreement on this new committee system for the Senate—which has not even been tested and is not operational—we get the creation of another Senate select committee, rather than having this matter referred to the appropriate standing committee. I have to say that it could not be surprising to people listening or to other senators in this chamber that the government is a little concerned about this approach and rejects the approach that has been adopted in this case. Senator Loosley touched on other policy reasons as to why it is not appropriate for a Senate select committee to be established in the terms that have been outlined: to investigate various aspects of the ABC.

I do not believe in taking up the Senate's time by duplicating debate, but there is one issue I want to conclude on. Senator Chapman made a contribution to this debate and made an allegation that there had been funding cuts to the ABC in recent years. I hope Senator Chapman is put on this committee because he might learn some facts. There have been no funding cuts to the ABC in recent years. I do not know how Senator Chapman can come in here and make these bald assertions that are just totally incorrect.

Since 1988, the ABC has received guaranteed funding under the triennial funding arrangements. In the last budget the government agreed to maintain existing levels of funding for a further three years with a full adjustment for inflation. This advantage allows the ABC to plan for the future with a higher degree of certainty, and it is an indication of the importance which the government attaches to the ABC. So I hope Senator Chapman, if he is going to sit on yet another select committee, learns something at least about the funding of the ABC.

Contrast our commitment to the ABC in the funding area with the lack of commitment from the coalition. Indeed, one of the coalition members paid the ultimate price at the last election. Warwick Smith, the former member for Bass in the other place, lost his seat because of the opposition's commitment in Fightback to slash the funding of ABC by 10 per cent. He lost his seat of Bass by 41 or 42 votes. That was one of the three local issues that led to his defeat. So the opposition should be warned. The opposition has attempted to play games with the ABC in a variety of ways and it has not done it any good.

Those opposite want to set up yet another select committee, they want to trip around the country looking into these issues, but it will do them no political good. The opposition thought the select committee into the loans council would bring down the Treasurer at the time; that it would bring down the government; and that it would be very embarrassing to the government. Frankly, all it did was make the previous leader of the Democrats look a fool and wasted a lot of time of opposition members in the election campaign when they should have been out there defending their policy positions instead of wasting their time in airport lounges trying to get the majority when they could not count or could not get out of bed.

We have just been through another select committee into foreign ownership of the media. What has that accomplished? Very little. If the opposition's objective is to get on this side of the Senate chamber, it had better start identifying the real policy issues and the real approach to getting into government.

It is little wonder that the public treats the opposition with contempt. There is absolutely no respect for the opposition in the community. I am worried about that because governments need effective oppositions rather than the rabble and the shambles we have opposite. Even to the degree where those opposite attempt to produce some sort of policy direction—we cannot use the word `policy'; the opposition does not dare talk about policy. It does not want to have any policy. It produced some sort of document a couple of weeks ago; everyone has now forgotten the name of it, and it is an embarrassment to the opposition when people refer to the name of it.

Those opposite are an absolute shambles. They come up with propositions like this. By all means, they can go off, have their hearings and trip around the country. At the end of the day, in the sense of it developing good public policy, unfortunately it will not happen. We have seen the approach that has been adopted.

Senator Bourne and Senator Chamarette are very naive in their approach to this issue. The evidence has very clearly been that this is yet another disruption tactic by the opposition. If opposition senators want to waste their own time, so be it. Unfortunately, they are going to waste a lot more money. I do not know what the cost of the last couple of select committees has been. It would be in the vicinity of hundreds of thousands of dollars each. As well as that, those opposite will waste considerable time and, I am sure, significant financial resources of the ABC. For that reason and the reasons that Senator Loosley has outlined, this motion should be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal Sen B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to oppose this ill-conceived motion. Senator Chamarette has put forward several assertions about the ABC as justification for an inquiry. She has claimed that the Australian Television International network has failed to penetrate into Asian markets and is therefore `a waste of scarce resources'. She has referred to recent media speculation about inappropriate sponsorship. She has commented on the supposed low morale of the ABC staff. She has suggested that there is public concern about the future of the corporation. These claims are unfounded. Much as the opposition and the Greens would like to create an atmosphere of uncertainty about the ABC, the fact is that the corporation has never been stronger and its future never brighter.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette asserts that the activities of the Australian Television International network have been a failure in penetrating Asian markets. The reality is somewhat different. ATV is still in its formative stage. It has already played a vital role in strengthening our links with Asia. It has given many Asian nations an opportunity to discover that there is more to Australia than just tourism.

Australian Television International allows us to project a very positive profile of Australia into South-East Asia and provides corporate Australia with an unparalleled opportunity to market its goods, exports and activities. It is assisting the production of foreign language programs in Asia and has provided another avenue for Australia to sell itself as a commercial centre in the South-East Asian community. It broadcasts for 16 hours a day to 15 Asian nations, emphasising quality Australian and regional programs. Over the rest of this year there is a commitment that ATV will extend its new content to 30 per cent of total broadcast time, an essential service for many of our neighbours whose internal new services are poorly developed.

The achievements of Australian Television International in Asia are widely recognised. The former Prime Minister of Singapore, Mr Lee Kwan Yew, said of the Australian media in April at the National Press Club:

SPEECH.PARA: Only a few, like the Financial Review, the Australian, the Melbourne Age, the Sydney Morning Herald and Australian Television International provide intelligent coverage of Asia.

His sentiments have been echoed by other Asian leaders. The sole evidence relied upon by Senator Chamarette for the purported failure of ATV is the overrun of costs in the 1993-94 financial year. The government has already moved to deal with the problem of this budget overrun. Yesterday the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Mr Lee, tabled a report prepared by two senior officers of his department which clearly assessed the operational future of ATV.

PARA.TAB: This report spelt out the reasons for this accrued deficit. The report found that the costs were associated with the start-up of operations. ATV has been forced to cover an unforecastable 275 per cent jump in the cost of transponder hire to carry the signal to Asia. It has also had to meet the one-off capital costs of facilities in Darwin. The report found that by 1995-96 ATV would break even and would be able to repay its line of credit by the financial year 1999-2000.

ATV has played a valuable role in promoting Australia in the region. The minister sought an assurance that the service provided by ATV will not detract from the quality of services provided to Australian patrons of the ABC network and has subsequently expressed his confidence in the abilities of the ABC's directing manager, Mr Hill, to carry out this commitment. On this ground, therefore, there is no need for the Senate to rush into yet another expensive inquiry.

Senator Chamarette might like to reflect on the costs of setting up another committee and whether her motion will `waste scarce resources' that could have gone into more productive services for the community. Essentially, the problem has been identified, the reasons for it analysed and the solutions set in train.

The ABC operates within considerable financial restraints. Every effort is made to maximise the value received for every dollar of public funding as well as money received from other sources. This private money is sought and obtained under very strict guidelines and is required to be solicited in a manner which maintains the ABC's integrity as a public broadcaster. But the fact is that this source of funds is essential for the ABC to be able to provide the services that it does provide.

Recently, allegations have surfaced regarding possibly inappropriate sponsorship of ABC programs. The investigation of these allegations is fundamental to maintaining public confidence in the ABC and its operations. The ABC board has moved swiftly to deal with the claims. An independent investigation has been set up, headed by the respected barrister George Palmer QC. I have confidence in Mr Palmer's ability to conduct this matter. As the parliament, we should allow Mr Palmer to conduct his investigation without undue interference or media hype. I note that Senator Harradine has indicated his willingness to wait for the outcome of this inquiry before pursuing a parliamentary option. The Greens should perhaps take a leaf out of his book because, once again, the claim for the need for this Senate inquiry is being dealt with by Mr Palmer's inquiry.

I ask Senator Chamarette to consider the effect on staff morale of yet another inquiry into the activities of the ABC. The schoolboy behaviour of senators opposite has not helped to raise the spirits of ABC staff, who could be excused for feeling that Senator Alston would like to see them all sacked. I ask Senator Chamarette to see the foolishness of holding a morale-sapping inquiry into whether morale is low and whether it is declining.

Senator Chamarette must consider whether the thrust of her motion is really about improving ABC services or whether it is about giving the Greens and the opposition greater media exposure. Senator Chamarette must be aware that an inquisition into the ABC would be another media circus—that is, a media circus with Senator Alston as the ringmaster. This might be great entertainment, but the sad thing is that this entertainment will be funded by the public purse. None of the grounds for Senator Chamarette's motion can stand up to scrutiny. This motion, cobbled together and labelled `urgent' by the master tacticians in the Greens' office, will serve no purpose except to denigrate the role of the ABC in Australia.

The reality is that the ABC provides a quality source of information, news and mainstream culture to a broad section of the Australian community. All senators will be familiar with the quality programs such as AM, PM, Lateline and Foreign Correspondent. The ABC has expanded its network of overseas reporters in places such as Johannesburg, Moscow, Nairobi and Berlin. It has increased by 2 1/2 times the Australian production of quality drama, the most expensive television programs, with award winning programs such as Phoenix, Police Rescue and Brides of Christ.

Its documentary production is world renowned, with Cop it Sweet and Nobody's Children receiving wide local and international acclaim. Against the backdrop of imported programs and second-rate infotainment of the commercial networks, the ABC is able to offer a high standard of programming and education for Australians. There is no question that the ABC is a major player in creating a national identity across a country bigger than the European Union.

This role is not encouraged by the coalition. Senator Alston—the co-sponsor of this motion—has already shown his support for the ABC, despite his protestations earlier. He is the same Senator Alston who proposed a 10 per cent cut for all ABC services as part of the Fightback package—a cut of $50 million. I have not heard an answer here today as to how the ABC would continue to provide its present services with that sort of cut.

This was proposed in a climate in which the ABC has even greater demand for services than it has before. Senator Alston justified his budget slashing scheme by saying that there was too much administrative waste in the public sector; yet today we have Senator Alston supporting the setting up of another inquisition which would take public money away from service provision and feed another circus of an inquisition. I note the agreement reached this morning and that an amendment has been put forward to take away the automatic right for the opposition to elect the chair of this committee. I hope that, if this committee is established, the amendments are also incorporated.

The previous policies of the opposition, when it comes to the ABC, must disqualify it from chairing any committee relating to the ABC's operations. I have already mentioned the proposed cuts in the last election campaign pushed by Senator Alston. This cut was clearly dreamed up without consultation with any person associated with the communications industry.

The coalition should also be disqualified on the grounds of its past record in government. Senators would agree that, under the present Labor government, the ABC has become renowned for promoting Australian television content. In 1992 the percentage of ABC prime-time viewing—that is, from 7.00 p.m. to 11.00 p.m.—from Australian sources was 84 per cent. This was after nine years of Labor government. In 1982, after seven years of Liberal government, it was below 36 per cent. The ABC under the Liberals would return to being a pale clone of the commercial channels.

In closing, I would like to add that accountability and accessibility have been hallmarks of this government and its instrumentalities. The ABC is consistently being run on an open and impartial basis. It provides quality services to a great number of Australians. The situation is that if we went out there in the community and asked workers, the aged, students, every member of the community, `Would you prefer to see your money spent on better ABC services and better access to the services, or would you prefer the ABC to be dealt with and have your money spent in another inquiry?', their universal answer would be that they would like their funding spent on better services.

I urge senators not to be duped into holding this inquiry, to at least wait until the results of the Palmer inquiry are known and not to waste the scarce resources of the ABC by supporting this opposition-inspired trawling expedition.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I want to very briefly sum up so that we can finish this matter today. This inquiry is in order to set up a mechanism for scrutiny, accountability and consultation. The very best comeback to accusations of inappropriate behaviour, wrong emphasis or direction, or mismanagement, is to allow a framework for openness and transparency in which those accusations and allegations can be heard and answered.

PARA.TAB: This committee presents the opportunity of responding constructively to problems which, we all acknowledge, have occurred over the past year. The spirit in which it has been proposed is one of general supportiveness of the ABC and of its vital role as the national public broadcaster. I am disappointed in the pessimism expressed by the government, but I believe some of its concerns will be addressed by the amendments that have been advanced by the Democrats, and I have already indicated our support for them.

There is no disagreement that Senate select committees can go wrong and can be accused of political gain, but every member of parliament loses when this occurs because the community becomes increasingly disillusioned with politics. I urge people to approach this inquiry in the most positive way.
Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I understood that you were to call each of these four amendment items separately. I certainly registered a no for what I understood to be (d) but which would have been the first of Senator Bourne's amendments. I trust Hansard will record accurately what I was trying to do. If (c) and (d) were put as one, then the government registers a no vote, but for deleting paragraphs 4(a) and 4(c) the government registers a yes vote.

PARA.TAB: Motion, as amended, agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes the statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 21 September 1994 on drought assistance; and
(b)should debate the assistance measures contained in the Prime Minister's statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In his remarks on the debate just concluded on the reference of the ABC to a committee of inquiry, Senator Sherry claimed that in my remarks I had—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Order! It being 6.50 p.m., under the strict standing orders, I have to move to government documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to complete my personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In his remarks in the recently concluded debate regarding the reference of the ABC to a committee of inquiry, Senator Sherry claimed that in my remarks I had said that this government had cut funding to the ABC. I made no such remarks at all; I made no such claim. The only comment I made in relation to funding was that it was important that the ABC be accountable for its funding to ensure that there was no waste of funds. I said that an important reason for establishing this committee of inquiry was to ensure that accountability and to ensure that there had not been wastage of funds and, if there had been any such wastage, I hoped that it would be uncovered by this inquiry. At no time did I say that this government had cut funding to the ABC. I want that correction on the record. I hope that Senator Sherry will acknowledge that and perhaps, in due course, make an apology.
—There being no senator wishing to discuss government documents, I propose the question:
