TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, we had a package brought down by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins). It was called `A statement by the Prime Minister, the Honourable P.J. Keating, MP—drought assistance'. It would be quite churlish not to say that the package is welcome. At long last this government has realised that people are hurting and that more has to be done than was done in the past. The package picks up many of the coalition's proposals contained in its drought policy paper of a fortnight ago. That is the most impressive part about it. The NFF has come out strongly in favour of the government package. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has said that he consulted widely in the formulation of it.

PARA.TAB: But the government cannot have everything and I do not believe that this alleviation of the RAS can have everything in it, either. I heard the minister's arguments today in dismissing a fodder subsidy scheme. I maintain that there are no incentives in the package to protect the national herd and flock. It is in the best interests of Australia to maintain the national herd and flock; to protect our ability to meet our overseas trade obligations in the future.

The government has just provided a multi-million dollar handout to ANL in the national interest. Sheep and cattle breeding numbers are also in the national interest. I cannot see where today's package is going to ensure that we keep the breeding herd and the breeding flock intact so that when the drought breaks we are able to meet our obligations regarding our export of beef, lamb and wool—and as was said earlier today, wool is increasing in price and is obviously in demand around the world.

The release of the package today raises a number of questions that need to be addressed. The eligibility criteria for exceptional circumstances has been widely condemned as being too narrow in excluding those it is theoretically designed to help. I ask: have the criteria changed? How are the criteria going to be administered to make sure that people do not fall through the safety net? The RAS, as it is being administered at the moment, requires people to be able to show that by borrowing extra money they can increase productivity and increase their ability to survive an horrific drought.

We have had inquiries from all over Australia concerning the rural adjustment scheme and there has been a lot of misunderstanding. Has that been fixed? Tomorrow in this place I will be looking for the minister to tell us in finer detail what is happening there.

In his statement the Prime Minister said that the government did not want to give tax breaks; it wanted to give an incentive for people to make sure that they can solve their problems. The government does not talk about the taxes imposed on Australian farmers when Mr Keating was the Treasurer and since he has been the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister claimed that it is better to provide investment allowances rather than tax breaks on the basis that farmers are not paying taxes.

However, farmers are still slugged with fuel taxes, fringe benefits taxes, capital gains taxes and wholesale taxes, which have not been alleviated by today's announcement. They are still there. The fringe benefits tax is still causing pain to people in the Northern Territory and elsewhere. The classic example is the one we were given during the inquiry: it was costing $40-odd extra a week for supplying food and a bit of a gum branch over somebody on a mustering camp. There is something for the government to address there.

I am not slamming the package, but the government has a lot more to answer for before it gets things right. Will today's package expand rural debt or not? Everywhere we went on the inquiry people did not want to borrow more money; people wanted help to get out of the hole they are in. If the package expands rural debt, does that not fly in the face of farmers who have said that they do not want to take out any more loans? Does it? I think the minister has to answer some of those questions tomorrow—and I am quite sure he will.

The Prime Minister said, `We are going to talk with the banks'. What is going to happen? One of the complaints that we had from all around rural Australia was that a lot of this aid goes direct to the banks and not to the farmers—they do not even see it. This is not going to lift the morale of farmers unless that matter is clarified by the minister tomorrow.

The government admits that the biggest beneficiaries of the package will be the lending institutions. Yet it is those very institutions with their interest charges that have been the catalyst for the financial ruin of farmers. Will the government try to ensure that future packages give good long-term loans to the rural community? How seriously did the government look at debt write-off for accumulated interest? In this package did the government look at setting aside debt and interest payments for a certain period—not writing it off but just setting it aside so that farmers could actually see a bit of light at the end of the tunnel? Given that the banks and the pastoral houses will be the big winners, is there or has there been a trade-off with some accumulated interest debt? Those are the questions that everyone is asking today about this drought package.

The drought package is welcome because at long last the Prime Minister has got out to look at what is happening. We have been arguing in this place now for quite some time that something had to be done to stop the decay in the rural communities because of this horrific drought. Remember the first statement by the Prime Minister that drought is a naturally occurring phenomenon in Australia. At long last, he has recognised the fact that we have a drought of giant proportions. At long last, by the middle of October in some cases, the government will actually do something about it. It is still, though, a costing of $164 million over two years—about the same amount that the Prime Minister offered to pull down the Cahill Expressway.

Now that the government has realised there is a drought it has to do something about it. I hope that there will be good long-term measures to help the farming communities in the future. I do not want to see the debacle the government has allowed to develop, hitting the farming community in the guts and making sure they were down on their hands and knees before this drought even started by all the taxes and charges that it has imposed on them over the last 10 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we had the government's response to the disastrous drought partially affecting Queensland, a substantial part of northern New South Wales and beyond. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) waxed lyrical about the extensive consultation that has occurred but the drought in Queensland has been running for at least four years and it really is only in the last 10 days that the Prime Minister has apparently become involved.

PARA.TAB: As with all his involvements, he described this package as `most innovative'. But it was the coalition, through shadow minister John Anderson and through its drought policy, that pushed drought onto the front page of the national dailies and onto the television. I have had occasion in this place to commend John Anderson: he will make a truly informed and concerned minister for primary industries.

I am pleased that the government has seen the sense of adopting the coalition policy of suspending assets tests on welfare payments and Austudy. Senator Boswell has done more than anyone else to highlight the absurdity and unfairness of farm families being excluded from rights conferred on each and every other Australian. At his press conference this afternoon, the Prime Minister talked a lot about his concern for the family farm structure. It is good, even at this late stage, that he has had some conversion to this essential structure of rural and regional Australia.

There are a number of shortfalls in the package. The first is that there is no introduction of a drought relief fodder subsidy. Senator Collins said that it was rejected outright because it was `rorted to hell' in the 1982-83 drought. I asked Senator Collins to disclose whether any farmer was ever convicted for rorting the system because that is just plain humbug.

Secondly, the title, `exceptional drought' is used but not explained. Presumably, the test of exceptional circumstances is still appropriate. Nothing is said about placing `severe drought' in the national disaster relief arrangements which would provide more assistance and special concessional loans like low interest replanting loans essential for farmers at this time. These should apply additionally to drought affected small business. I commend the government for the increased funding provided to RAS. However, it is worth noting that accessing these interest rate subsidies is very difficult.

Thirdly, the planning for the future that the Prime Minister talks of in this package is just a pipedream. The government undertakes to encourage drought-proofing by investment allowances and further depreciation schedules for fodder and water conservation. The Prime Minister made the extraordinary comment that indiscriminate water conservation can lead to land degradation. If these areas of depreciation are so obviously in need of reform, why were they not addressed in the 1992 drought policy or in general taxation reform along the way in each year's budget?

Fourthly, the government has failed to look after the Australian farm worker. Many farm employees risk losing their jobs because of this drought. There is no provision to pay the jobsearch allowance to them so that they can be kept on farms until farmers can pay them again. Premier Fahey in New South Wales could see the value in this. The government has shown no heart in giving a fair go to Australian farmhands. They are a resource that needs to be protected until the drought is over.

Fifthly, the Prime Minister made much of the generosity of the package. The response to the government's $14 million last month was to describe it as pitiful, especially compared with the government's instant response of $150 million to the Cahill Expressway and the multi-millions thrown to the waterside workers to get them back to work after their recent strike. Indeed, if the same tax breaks extended to ANL were extended to farm workers, employees in the rural industry would be $350 million better off.

In the 1982-83 drought the coalition willingly provided $341 million—about $630 million in today's terms—for drought stricken farmers. When the drought broke this ensured that they preserved their breeding herds and flocks and were in a position to bounce back. It is important to put the drought relief package in its correct economic context by acknowledging that for every one per cent increase in interest rates farmers are slugged an extra $170 million in mortgages and repayments. I hope that when the Prime Minister asks the banks to play their part and resist foreclosing on farmers they tell him that the best thing he can do for farmers is to stop pursuing policies which push up interest rates.

Sixthly, there is no attempt to tackle the question of farm debt. I again call for a farm debt summit. Farmers, not including country small business, are sitting on a $17 billion—$17 billion!—raft of debt. The government must attempt to look at the options in handling that part of the debt which is unsustainable, and some of it of course will be. The Prime Minister at least admitted that the government is part of the solution, and it was pleasing to see him say that.

So the government has provided some relief for the social and economic hardship being felt by farmers in rural communities. It has provided little, however, to retain the breeding stock so essential for recovery and for bouncing back after the drought, and it has done virtually nothing to ensure recovery and economic and taxation planning for the future.

The government said it would do something but it has done very little. In fact, Senator Collins had the gall to say that IEDs, the income equalisation deposit schemes so successful in the early 1980s, have worked. He should go and ask a few farm accountants. The Australian Labor Party has an appalling macro-economic record for regional Australia. For years it ran a high inflation economy. Farmers, being price takers, saw profits eroded by costs rising between 10 per cent to 14 per cent a year throughout most of the 1980s.

Labor allowed interest rates far above those of our competitors—over 20 per cent—and even today rural counsellors tell you that most of their clients are paying in excess of 14 per cent. It made farmers bear the burden of deregulation in the economy while Labor's mates were feather-bedded. It gutted IEDs which were, and still are in the right form, the prudent farmer's drought assurance. Having stripped away everything else, as Senator Boswell said earlier today, and despite taxation incentives to help farmers plan for difficult times, the inevitable happened. We ran into another severe drought and the government was caught with very little in place to cope with the situation. I remind the Senate of the words that appear above the Land editorial every week:

SPEECH.PARA: Nations may battle and the world rock with revolution, but the land will care for him who cares for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish this evening to speak on the matter of the Western Australian royal commission and resulting prosecutions. Some Liberal members in the House of Representatives have used the occasion of the conviction of David Parker, former Deputy Premier of Western Australia, to attempt to smear and denigrate all associated with the Labor Party. I do not choose to respond to such base attacks. Those contributions say more about those Liberals members than they do about the ALP and its members.

PARA.TAB: My comments are made in response to some editorials, particularly that contained in today's Canberra Times. One such comment alleges:

SPEECH.PARA: But Labor as a party has never really conducted its own inquests, reformed its systems or repudiated those who let it, and those who voted for it, down.

Patently this is not the case and any examination of the record will so prove. As the former state secretary of the ALP, I am well placed to comment on the response of the ALP to the royal commission and its findings.

PARA.TAB: First I wish to deal with the response of the Lawrence government. The Labor Lawrence government called the royal commission and gave it very wide terms of reference and powers. The commission was extremely well-funded and received every assistance from that government. The Lawrence government on receiving the royal commission report provided for the proper resourcing of the office of the Director of Public Prosecutions to pursue any matter referred to that office by the royal commission. The Labor state government committed itself immediately to the implementation of the recommendations contained in the second report of the royal commission.

The major recommendation of the royal commission was for the formation of the Commission on Government. The state Liberal Party frustrated attempts to establish that commission prior to the 1993 state election. Now, two years after the royal commission's report, the Court government has still not implemented that major recommendation of the royal commission. The laws passed by the parliament to ensure public disclosure of donations in 1992 have still not been proclaimed. The Liberals' failure to implement the royal commission's recommendations and their political interference with the office of the DPP prevent the restoration of confidence in government in Western Australia.

I turn to the response of the ALP. Clearly it is inappropriate to make remarks, as some others have, about individuals facing trials or possible appeal processes. The ALP is very proud of its many achievements for the state during the terms of office of the Burke, Dowding and Lawrence governments. Equally, ALP members were disturbed and shocked by much of the evidence of the royal commission and subsequent trials.

The party was determined to respond immediately to any evidence of inappropriate behaviour or failure of party administration. Among many measures adopted by the ALP in response to that evidence, the ALP closed down the John Curtin Foundation; endorsed a mandatory fund-raising code of conduct; wrote into its state rules the most stringent possible rules in relation to the control of campaign finances, which included ensuring the candidate or member was at arm's length from the process. Part of the rules provide:

SPEECH.PARA: All monies deposited into campaign accounts shall be receipted and a complete financial record shall be maintained. Parliamentary members and endorsed ALP candidates shall not receipt donations. No anonymous donations are to be accepted.
All expenditure from the campaign account will be for the purposes of campaign expenditure authorised by the Campaign Committee.

The ALP cooperated fully with the royal commission investigators and with the office of the DPP. The ALP reimbursed $75,000 to the State Superannuation Board in recognition of an unauthorised payment made by a joint venture partner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does it make it right that you gave it back?

—Just listen, will you? The ALP sought unsuccessfully to obtain full and complete details of all leader's account matters. The ALP assisted the tax office with its inquiries regarding the taxation liability arising from leader's accounts and took a commercial decision to accept the taxation liability arising from leader's accounts despite the absence of full information as to the ownership of those funds. It is clearly not the case that the ALP organisation failed to respond to the findings of the royal commission.

PARA.TAB: The other issue raised again in recent days is the call for the repudiation of those facing trial or already convicted. Calls for the ALP to repudiate individuals misses the point. From the beginning the ALP formed the view that it should investigate any matters brought to its attention and pursue those issues where appropriate.

In relation to the action of individuals, the ALP resolved not to set itself up as judge and jury, but resolved to let the royal commission, the DPP and the courts do their job. Those law enforcement agencies at all times received the full cooperation of the ALP. The ALP has not indulged and should not indulge in an internal witch-hunt but has let the proper judicial processes take their course. Some individual members of the party have chosen to show their personal friendship and support for those facing charges. That is their right and they should not be criticised for that display of personal friendship.

The ALP organisation has supported the proper state processes for resolving the issue of guilt or innocence. The issue obviously has been a very painful one for the ALP, but to suggest that the WA branch of the ALP has not confronted the findings of the royal commission is patently wrong.

I have just been informed of the fact that a good friend, Mr David Smith, the member for Mitchell in the state parliament, has resigned from the shadow cabinet today. I understand that his resignation is related to allegations made by the honourable member for Moore, Mr Paul Filing, in the House of Representatives this afternoon. I wish to place on record my sadness at the news of David Smith's resignation and my respect for David's contribution to the state parliament and to the Labor Party. I also wish to place on record that, as I understand it, the allegations made by Mr Filing today are ill-founded, that the matters referred to in Mr Beahan's evidence to the Parker trial did not relate to Mr Smith. It is true that Mr Smith sought and obtained a personal loan from the ALP when in personal difficulty in 1992. I regret his decision to leave the shadow cabinet but wish him all the best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on an issue in regard to the aged care industry and the impact upon that industry of a recent article. Before I do so, I wish to declare an interest in that from time to time I consult for one of the leading health care groups in Australia involved in that industry, the Moran Health Care Group. I would add that it is because of those associations that I have a deeper understanding than would otherwise be the case of the aged care industry.

PARA.TAB: The particular issue in question is an editorial in the Australian Health and Aged Care Journal by its editor-in-chief, Ms Karen Linnell. The editorial is a vitriolic, unjustified, incorrect and completely unsubstantiated attack on one of the most caring industries in Australia today. While it focuses on the proprietors of nursing homes, it includes by intimation thousands of devoted nursing home staff, nurses and associated workers, and indeed by implication thousands of relatives of residents.

There are a number of unsubstantiated accusations in the article. Ms Linnell accuses owners of pocketing public funds while they run their nursing homes into the ground. Where is the evidence for this? The truth is exactly the opposite. Recently many proprietors have gone broke while trying to provide a caring environment within the financial constraints set by the Commonwealth government. Ms Linnell says that owners are greedy, corrupt and demand kickbacks and that this is a part of the system.

Ms Linnell produces not a single piece of evidence to support this, and I am not aware of a single substantiated case where this incident has happened. If Ms Linnell has any substantiating evidence, she should ensure that both the police and the Commonwealth authorities are provided with it. If there happen to be a few bad eggs in the nursing home basket—the majority of nursing home proprietors are, in fact, decent and devoted to the welfare of their residents—there is still no justification for defaming the whole industry in this way. The editor should put aside her prejudices and produce some facts to support these wild statements.

She says that some of the wealthiest nursing home proprietors run some of the most substandard homes. Again, I ask: where is there a shred of evidence to support this? In fact, the contrary is true. I am familiar with most of the proprietors. For example, Doug Moran, one of the wealthy proprietors whom I know very well, runs nursing homes which are second to none in this country. They are nursing homes which one would be happy to live in and which pass the `mum test'—which essentially means that a child would be happy for his or her mum to live in it—which is the most appropriate test in most cases. These are nursing homes which not only offer good physical environments, but are committed to the very high standards of care and caring. I am happy to acknowledge that the government's changes have had a significant part to play in this.

If Ms Linnell wants to regain any credibility, she must produce some substantiation, some facts to support these outrageous and nonsensical claims. For example, she says that many people in the industry know how poor the accommodation and services are in many nursing homes. This may well have been true 15 years ago, but nowadays it is simply wrong. I say again that this is partly due to the monitoring which goes on.

Is it possible that the editor of a magazine which purports to understand this industry is not aware of the standard monitoring teams or the outcome standards? It certainly seems so or, if she is aware of them, she is implying either incompetence on the part of the SMTs or, worse still, even corruption and, therefore, implying that these public servants are for one reason or another not doing their jobs properly. Again, I ask: where is the evidence? I am sure that Senator Crowley would support my view that the standard monitoring teams do a very thorough job—some would say too thorough in many cases. If anything, there is too much monitoring, in as much as there is duplication between the federal and state governments. The reality is far removed from this nonsensical article.

Similarly, Ms Linnell says that the debate is driven by self-interest and greed by proprietors who have rorted the system for years. What are the facts? They are completely at variance with this claim by Ms Linnell. The government's own 1991 review found an immediate payment of $1.56 per day per resident should be granted. Professor Gregory's report indicated that an extra $4.57 per resident per day was needed to cover the costs of building, upgrading and providing essential services. The Gregory report also stated that between $540 million and $1 billion was needed to bring nursing homes up to scratch, and that the Commonwealth funding had not met this necessary need. The other independent report, by Arthur Andersen, found that nursing homes across Australia received on average only 6c per resident per day as a return on their investment. So much for nursing home proprietors rorting the system or lining their own pockets, as was claimed in this article by Ms Linnell.

What are the facts? The facts are that the standards of care in the nursing home industry are very good. They compare with most other countries around the world. The facts are that it is an industry with a relatively poor financial return. It is not a goldmine for greedy individuals to pillage. It is an industry in which the vast majority of the owners and workers are caring and dedicated people. Ms Linnell's article is defamatory of everybody who works in this industry, and it is something which the author should be ashamed of. I received a letter today from George Hardi, a respected proprietor in Australia. He said:

I have seen during my 32 years in the industry many attacks on nursing homes but frankly I can not recall a more vicious, ill willed, defamatory article anywhere, not even during the darkest Whitlam years. This woman should be banned from working in the health care field.

SPEECH.PARA: They are sentiments which I think would receive wide support. I have had a number of phone calls from people involved in the area—proprietors and others—who are appalled at this article.

PARA.TAB: This unsubstantiated article defames a number of good people. It undermines the morale in the industry. But the person who suffers the most in the end is Ms Linnell, who is left with no credibility in this area. Sadly, this also reflects on the other staff of the journal, many of whom are known to have the highest professional standards. To prevent further damage to their reputation—not to mention her own—Ms Linnell should print an immediate retraction and apology. If this does not occur, the journal cannot claim in any way to understand the industry and will find that its circulation and advertising support will presumably fall accordingly.

What about the government's role in this? The government should take note of the recommendations in the Gregory report, in particular, and provide the appropriate funding as soon as possible. This is funding which will increase both the SAM and CAM element, and the capital grants element, which will mean that the residents will be able to live in the appropriate standards of comfort and care. The beneficiaries will be the residents in nursing homes. These are the people on whom we should be focusing and for whom we should be caring. That is the aim of the proprietors. It is the aim of the thousands of workers in the industry. It should be the aim of us all, including this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —To most Australians, the name Frank Moorhouse these days refers to a distinguished Australian author. It is his father, the late Frank Moorhouse Snr, who died earlier this year in his 90th year, of whom I wish to speak about tonight. In the dairy areas of Australia, especially on the south coast of New South Wales, the name Frank Moorhouse does not mean an author, but it means Moorhouse the Machinery Man whose products were a major factor in upgrading the Australian dairy industry.

PARA.TAB: I first met Frank Moorhouse about 20 years ago when he was a young, energetic 70-year-old, heavily involved in most of the worthwhile things being done in the Shoalhaven area. He was a genuine full-time citizen of the Shoalhaven. He was a wonderful supporter to me during my three terms as the member for Macarthur in the House of Representatives. I was fortunate to maintain my close friendship with him for many years.

His annual Christmas card was something quite different. It was a bit of a story about what had happened to him, his family and his beloved wife, Purth, during the year. Maybe that is where Frank Moorhouse Jnr inherited some of his literary skills. The thing about Frank Moorhouse was that I certainly never heard him raise his voice in anger—and I do not know of anyone else who did either—make any derogatory remarks about anyone or use a swear word, which is quite striking when one is running an engineering business.

He was born in Wanganui, New Zealand, into a dairy farming family in 1904. He left school at an early age and trained to be an electrical engineer. He was one of the first licensed electricians in that country, holding licence No. 4. He migrated, as so many New Zealanders do, such as my father, to Sydney in 1925—which was about the same time my father came as well—with about #10 in his pocket and an introductory letter to the Diabolo Separator Company, where he gained employment as a milking machine technician. The first task allotted to him in that firm was to install a milking machine in every dairying district in New South Wales, which he succeeded in doing.

In 1928, he married Purthenary Cutts. They moved to the Shoalhaven district, naturally one of Australia's best dairying areas, which was their home ever since. From this union there were three sons, Owen, Arthur and Frank, the author. There were seven grandchildren and six great-grandchildren.

In those days, the problem in the dairying industry was with boiling water for sterilising dairy utensils. With his engineering ability, he invented and manufactured a very efficient device that would boil water very rapidly with a minimum amount of fuel. This was marketed as the Moorhouse dairy boiler. Approximately 20,000 of these were manufactured and distributed throughout the three eastern states. From these early beginnings in a small factory, the business continued to grow and prosper with the manufacture of dairy equipment and machinery sales.

The name Moorhouse the Machinery Man became synonymous throughout eastern Australia with the dairy industry and with a high quality product. When Mr Jack Ferguson—a man known to you, Mr Acting Deputy President—was chairman of the New South Wales milk board in 1952, he made the remark that the Moorhouse dairy boiler was the greatest single contribution to good quality milk for Sydney and, certainly, the word `quality' and Frank Moorhouse are synonymous.

In 1956 he attended the world conference on farm mechanisation held in Paris. He was deputy leader of the New South Wales government trade mission to South Africa and Kenya in 1969. In 1975 he was a participant in the Australian international trade display in Fiji. In 1977 he represented the Department of Overseas Trade at the international farm machinery show in California. So he was certainly heavily involved in his industry.

His sons Owen and Arthur, after their technical education, joined the business and became Moorhouse the Machinery Man and Sons. The youngest son, Frank, began his career as a journalist and, as I mentioned, is now one of Australia's best known authors.

Frank Moorhouse served the Boy Scout movement in a very involved way as group chairman, scout commissioner and patron. In World War II he was a company commander in the Volunteer Defence Corps with the rank of captain. In 1944 he founded the Nowra Technical College and was chairman of the district advisory committee for 30 years. He served four years as an alderman with the Municipality of Nowra, and the council honoured him by naming the park at the entrance of the town Moorhouse Park.

In 1948 he became a justice of the peace and, in 1955, deputy sheriff, a position he held for 30 years. He used to produce and sell the Shoalhaven historic homes calendar, which earned a lot for the Shoalhaven Historical Society, of which he had been an active member for many years.

In the early 1930s he was initiated into freemasonry, an organisation he served with distinction, progressing through the offices until in 1991 he attained one of the highest honours in that organisation, the rank of past deputy grand master.

The instigation of supervision of the non-denominational chapel at the Shoalhaven District Hospital was his work and he did it to commemorate 100 years of freemasonry in the Shoalhaven district. In 1934 he was a charter member of the Rotary club of Nowra, holding almost every executive position, being president twice and district governor of district 275. He was awarded the Paul Harris Fellowship in 1977, one of Rotary's highest honours.

In 1984 he became Shoalhaven's senior citizen of the year and went on to become the state senior citizen of the year. One of the highlights of his life was in 1988 when he was honoured by the Commonwealth for his service to the community with an OAM.

I can say that Frank Moorhouse had a very full and a very distinguished life and I am certain that he will be sadly missed in the Shoalhaven area where he was a commanding presence. To his family, particularly to his wife Purth, I send my deepest commiserations.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 22 July 1994:

(2) What did this cover.
(3) How many press releases were distributed.
(4) Were any journalistic services provided; if so, what did they cover.
(5) Were any public relations services provided; if so, what did they cover.

(6) What other costs, including staffing costs, were met by the department in relation to media release, public relations exercises, press releases and launches over the 1992-93 financial years, and please provide a breakdown.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The $40,000 allocated for the purchase of media distribution through AAP Facilities Pty Ltd was raised as a purchase order for the current financial year and listed in the Office Services Gazette as is required for planned expenditure of amounts of $2000 or more. The money is held in the Department against the Public Relations Unit's budget. AAP bills the Department on a monthly basis and only for those services provided. Since the money is paid to AAP only on receipt of invoice, any of the allocated sum not spent is retained in the Department and goes back into general funds at the end of the financial year.

(2) The service provided by AAP is a electronic mailing service for press releases and media alerts generated in the PRU, the Minister's office, or by consultants. The originals are faxed to AAP which uses its network called MediaNet to distribute the material to stipulated media organisations.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 23 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Following the rejection of student visas from overseas applicants, how many students in total have received a refund of their fees by the department more than once.
(2) What audit and reconciliation procedures were adopted by either the China Task Force or the department to ensure that no overseas student received more than one refund.
(3) How did the China Task Force: (a) validate the cases for refund; and (b) ensure that documents used were genuine.
(4) How many students who received refunds according to departmental records were classified as having been initially rejected because they furnished false information.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) According to China Task Force records, no student received a refund of their fees from the Department more than once.

(2) A payment and management information system (REPS) was maintained by the China Task Force. It matched information provided by both institutions and students and did not permit a claim to be entered or assessed twice. Payments were registered and approved on REPS which, up to 30 June 1992, was electronically interfaced with FINEST (the Departmental financial management system). After 30 June 1992, due to the small number of claims still being processed, payments were made manually through FINEST and reports were provided to the Department's audit area and to the Australian National Audit Office. Access to REPS was limited to personnel within the China Task Force.

(3) According to China Task Force procedures, students applying for a refund were required to complete a claim form and provide a certificate signed by a notary public (equivalent to a JP) confirming their identity. Officers at overseas posts were responsible for checking the completeness and accuracy of these forms and sighting the original identification documents. Photocopies of accepted claims were sent to the China Task Force and matched with information provided by institutions. The information provided by both the institution and the student was assessed to ensure that there were no inconsistencies and that the claimants met the eligibility criteria.

(4) Officers at overseas posts sighted students' original documents and rejected claims from those who supplied false information. Statistics on these rejections were not collected by the China Task Force.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Papua New Guinea: Bougainville Copper Mine

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the current state of play between troops from the BRA and the Papua New Guinea (PNG) Defence Force at the Bougainville Copper Mine.
(2) Has the mine indeed been captured.
(3) What is the Government's response to the PNG Government about the military action at the copper mine.
(4) Does the Government support the PNG military action against the BRA at the Bougainville Copper Mine in Panguna; if so, why.

(5) Does the Minister agree with recommendations in the Report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Bougainville (18-22 April 1994) `Bougainville—A Pacific Solution' with respect to: (a) recommendation 6.2; (b) recommendation 6.6; and (c) recommendation 6.8; if so, please state reasons.

(6) Does the Government believe that the recent action of the PNG Defence Force in the Panguna mine area contravene any of the delegation's recommendations; if so, what action will the Government take to reinforce and articulate these recommendations to the PNG Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) entered the Panguna mine around 16 August 1994, receiving no casualties and encountering no resistance in the process. It immediately began to secure the mine area by establishing itself in key positions both in and around the mine. Following an initial period of non-confrontation lasting several days, the security forces suffered five deaths and several casualties as a result of BRA sniper fire. The Government is not aware of any reciprocal BRA casualties over this period. Under the terms of an ceasefire agreement signed between the BRA and the PNG Government on 8 September 1994, a ceasefire on Bougainville came into effect at midnight on 9 September 1994. Amongst a range of provisions, the ceasefire agreement stipulates that Panguna and three other areas are declared neutral zones and that parts of a South Pacific peacekeeping force shall be deployed to each area to supervise the withdrawal of the PNGDF.

(2) The fact that the PNGDF occupied and retained ground at Panguna could be read as amounting to `capture', notwithstanding the casualties suffered. But it cannot be said that the PNGDF secured the mine site completely.

(3) The Australian Government recognises that the PNGDF has a legitimate and useful role to play on Bougainville, a point acknowledged in the Report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation which visited Bougainville in April this year. The Government nevertheless believes that the conflict on Bougainville cannot be solved by purely military means, and that a lasting peace will only be established once all parties recognise this and negotiate a peaceful settlement. The Government welcomes, therefore, the signing on 3 September 1994 of the `Honiara Commitments to Peace on Bougainville' and the signing of the ceasefire agreement on 8 September 1994.

(4) As the Government has always supported a peaceful resolution to the Bougainville conflict, it follows that the Government prefers to see negotiation rather than military action on the island. The Government does not believe that military operations such as the one which occurred at Panguna will be ultimately constructive in resolving the situation. Indeed, Papua New Guinea's Prime Minister Sir Julius Chan acknowledged the negative effect on the peace process of the former PNG Government's decision to deploy troops into the mine area, by publicly apologising to the BRA on 4 September 1994.

(5) (a) The Government has always maintained that there can be no purely military solution to the conflict in Bougainville. It also agrees with the Delegation's assertion within recommendation 6.2 that secession through force is not an option. The Government believes that the BRA has no mandate from the Bougainvillean people to represent them and that the Papua New Guinea government is the democratically elected constitutional authority in North Solomons Province.

(b) The Government agrees with the delegation's assessment that the future of the Bougainville Copper Limited (BCL) mine at Panguna should not be addressed until there is normalcy in Bougainville. The Government recognises that the issue of the mine's future is sensitive to Bougainvilleans and that any discussion on its reopening, preceding general stability on the island, would only obstruct progress toward peace. In this context the Government welcomed comments by former PNG Prime Minister Paias Wingti on 16 August 1994 that "the Government is not going to rush in to open the mine. . . that is not our priority. . . our priority is not the mine. We want our people to get back to normal life". The Government also notes the fact that no mention has been made of the Panguna mine in the agenda for the proposed Bougainville Peace Conference to be held under the provisions of the Honiara Commitments and the ceasefire agreement.

(c) In the Government's response to the tabling of the Parliamentary delegation's report on 8 June 1994, I warmly welcomed the report and the useful suggestions it contained in terms of resolving the conflict, not the least of which was the `timetable for peaceful resolution' proposed within recommendation 6.8. The Government believes that the visit and recommendations of the Parliamentary delegation have assisted in bringing about the climate in which a process of dialogue has been able to commence. A similar timetable to that contained within recommendation 6.8 has been adopted by both parties in the Honiara Commitments, which the Government has also welcomed. The main provisions of the agreement are that:

ANSWER.PARA: all forces will maintain static positions and that a ceasefire will be declared within seven days of the signing of the agreement;

a South Pacific peacekeeping force will deployed to Bougainville as soon as practicably possible after the declaration of the ceasefire when the mechanisms and arrangements for the force are finalised in consultations with participating governments and through consultation between the commanders of the forces of both sides;
the official lifting of the blockade shall be implemented following consultations by the PNG Government with the Solomon Islands Government and a third party;
the questions of pardon, amnesty and temporary refuge; reconciliation and compensation and restoration and reconstruction shall be addressed in the agenda for the Bougainville Peace Conference; and

the Bougainville Peace Conference shall be convened at a place in Bougainville or at another venue in PNG on a date to be agreed by both parties, preferably such date shall be no later than 10 October 1994.

PARA.TAB: The ceasefire agreement further defines the roles and responsibilities of the proposed South Pacific peacekeeping force.

(6) As the Government and the Parliamentary delegation have acknowledged, the PNGDF does have a legitimate role to play on Bougainville. On this basis the Government does not believe the PNGDF contravened any of the recommendations of the Parliamentary delegation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has Australia responded to the United Nations' (UN) Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali's calls in 1990 and again in `An Agenda for Peace' to confirm which military personnel will, in principle, be available for new peace keeping missions; if so what was Australia's response to the UN.
(2) How many personnel is Australia capable of committing in principle to new UN peace keeping missions.
(3) What is the expertise of those military personnel.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) In August 1990, Australia responded to a United Nations (UN) questionnaire on the availability of personnel and equipment with a list of the types of forces which may be available for peace keeping operations. This list is updated annually and passed to the UN Secretariat in New York by the Military Adviser in Australia's Permanent Mission to the UN. The list assists the UN in its planning and in particular in identifying the type of contribution Australia could make to peace keeping operations. The last update was provided in January 1994 and is as follows:
an infantry group
an Armoured Personnel Carrier squadron
a signals squadron
a field engineer squadron
a joint force medical unit
a field supply company
a transport squadron
a field workshop
a light and medium helicopter flight
a military police platoon
a Force Commander and personal staff
military observers
individual specialist elements including movement control, explosive ordnance disposal, divers, and communicators
patrol craft
military sealift; and
airfield defence guard.

(2) The Australian Defence Force (ADF) forms only a part, albeit generally a large part, of Australia's contribution to UN peace operations. The numbers of personnel available in principle to participate in new UN operations varies depending on the type of operation being mounted and the capabilities required to carry out that operation. None of the above listed capabilities are of fixed size. Also, units would be supplemented or reduced depending on the tasks required to be carried out and the security environment in the area of operations. For example, the current joint medical unit of 115 deployed to Rwanda is being protected by an infantry group of 106 and supported by 81 support troops. It should be noted that Australia is regularly called upon by the UN to provide advanced technical capabilities (eg. communications, engineering) not readily available in all other countries, rather than large numbers of troops.

(3) Since the end of World War II, the UN has conducted 33 peace operations; Australia has contributed at varying levels to 19 of them. During this time, Australia has developed a reputation for providing well trained and well disciplined forces who adapt readily to these types of operations. Australia has been able to respond quickly and professionally to situations as they have arisen with forces that are maintained for the defence of Australia. Most military personnel deployed on UN operations are regular members of the ADF and are therefore professional military personnel. On occasions, where the operation requires specialist skills not available within the regular ADF (eg. specialist medical personnel), reserves may be seconded to the operation.
